entry.label: Debug information
entry.help: Say Y if you want the 9P subsystem to log debug information.

entry.name: CAIF
entry.label: CAIF support
entry.help:
The "Communication CPU to Application CPU Interface" (CAIF) is a packet based connection-oriented MUX protocol developed by ST-Ericsson for use with its modems. It is accessed from user space as sockets (PF_CAIF).
Say Y (or M) here if you build for a phone product (e.g. Android or MeeGo ) that uses CAIF as transport, if unsure say N.
If you select to build it as module then CAIF_NETDEV also needs to be built as modules. You will also need to say yes to any CAIF physical devices that your platform requires.
See Documentation/networking/caif for a further explanation on how to use and configure CAIF.

entry.name: CAIF_DEBUG
entry.label: Enable Debug
entry.help: Enable the inclusion of debug code in the CAIF stack. Be aware that doing this will impact performance. If unsure say N.

entry.name: CAIF_NETDEV
entry.label: CAIF GPRS Network device
entry.help: Say Y if you will be using a CAIF based GPRS network device. This can be either built-in or a loadable module, If you select to build it as a built-in then the main CAIF device must also be a built-in. If unsure say Y.

entry.name: CAIF_USB
entry.label: CAIF USB support
entry.help: Say Y if you are using CAIF over USB CDC NCM. This can be either built-in or a loadable module, If you select to build it as a built-in then the main CAIF device must also be a built-in. If unsure say N.

entry.name: CEPH_LIB
entry.label: Ceph core library
entry.help:
Choose Y or M here to include cephlib, which provides the common functionality to both the Ceph filesystem and to the rados block device (rbd).
More information at http://ceph.newdream.net/.
If unsure, say N.

entry.name: CEPH_LIB_PRETTYDEBUG
entry.label: Include file:line in ceph debug output
entry.help:
If you say Y here, debug output will include a filename and line to aid debugging. This increases kernel size and slows execution slightly when debug call sites are enabled (e.g., via CONFIG_DYNAMIC_DEBUG).
If unsure, say N.

entry.name: CEPH_LIB_USE_DNS_RESOLVER
entry.label: Use in-kernel support for DNS lookup
entry.help:
If you say Y here, hostnames (e.g. monitor addresses) will be resolved using the CONFIG_DNS_RESOLVER facility.
For information on how to use CONFIG_DNS_RESOLVER consult Documentation/networking/dns_resolver.txt
If unsure, say N.

entry.name: NFC
entry.label: NFC subsystem support
entry.help:
Say Y here if you want to build support for NFC (Near field communication) devices.
To compile this support as a module, choose M here: the module will be called nfc.

entry.name: NFC_DIGITAL
entry.label: NFC Digital Protocol stack support
entry.help:
Say Y if you want to build NFC digital protocol stack support. This is needed by NFC chipsets whose firmware only implement the NFC analog layer.
To compile this support as a module, choose M here: the module will be called nfc_digital.

entry.name: NFC_NCI
entry.label: NCI protocol support
entry.help:
NCI (NFC Controller Interface) is a communication protocol between an NFC Controller (NFCC) and a Device Host (DH).
Say Y here to compile NCI support into the kernel or say M to compile it as module (nci).

entry.name: NFC_NCI_SPI
entry.label: NCI over SPI protocol support
entry.help:
NCI (NFC Controller Interface) is a communication protocol between an NFC Controller (NFCC) and a Device Host (DH).
Say yes if you use an NCI driver that requires SPI link layer.

entry.name: NFC_NCI_UART
entry.label: NCI over UART protocol support
entry.help: Say yes if you use an NCI driver that requires UART link layer.

entry.name: NFC_HCI
entry.label: NFC HCI implementation
entry.help: Say Y here if you want to build support for a kernel NFC HCI implementation. This is mostly needed for devices that only process HCI frames, like for example the NXP pn544.

entry.name: NFC_SHDLC
entry.label: SHDLC link layer for HCI based NFC drivers
entry.help: Say yes if you use an NFC HCI driver that requires SHDLC link layer. If unsure, say N here.

entry.name: NFC_WILINK
entry.label: Texas Instruments NFC WiLink driver
entry.help:
This enables the NFC driver for Texas Instrument's BT/FM/GPS/NFC combo devices. This makes use of shared transport line discipline core driver to communicate with the NFC core of the combo chip.
Say Y here to compile support for Texas Instrument's NFC WiLink driver into the kernel or say M to compile it as module.

entry.name: NFC_TRF7970A
entry.label: Texas Instruments TRF7970a NFC driver
entry.help:
This option enables the NFC driver for Texas Instruments' TRF7970a device. Such device supports 5 different protocols: ISO14443A, ISO14443B, FeLiCa, ISO15693 and ISO18000-3.
Say Y here to compile support for TRF7970a into the kernel or say M to compile it as a module. The module will be called trf7970a.ko.

entry.name: NFC_MEI_PHY
entry.label: MEI bus NFC device support
entry.help:
This adds support to use an mei bus nfc device. Select this if you will use an HCI NFC driver for an NFC chip connected behind an Intel's Management Engine chip.
If unsure, say N.

entry.name: NFC_SIM
entry.label: NFC hardware simulator driver
entry.help:
This driver declares two virtual NFC devices supporting NFC-DEP protocol. An LLCP connection can be established between them and all packets sent from one device is sent back to the other, acting as loopback devices.
If unsure, say N.

entry.name: NFC_PORT100
entry.label: Sony NFC Port-100 Series USB device support
entry.help:
This adds support for Sony Port-100 chip based USB devices such as the RC-S380 dongle.
If unsure, say N.

entry.name: NFC_FDP
entry.label: Intel FDP NFC driver
entry.help:
Intel Fields Peak NFC controller core driver. This is a driver based on the NCI NFC kernel layers.
To compile this driver as a module, choose m here. The module will be called fdp. Say N if unsure.

entry.name: NFC_FDP_I2C
entry.label: NFC FDP i2c support
entry.help:
This module adds support for the Intel Fields Peak NFC controller i2c interface. Select this if your platform is using the i2c bus.
If you choose to build a module, it'll be called fdp_i2c. Say N if unsure.

entry.name: NFC_PN544
entry.help: NXP PN544 core driver. This is a driver based on the HCI NFC kernel layers and will thus not work with NXP libnfc library.

entry.name: NFC_PN544_I2C
entry.label: NXP PN544 device support (I2C)
entry.help:
This module adds support for the NXP pn544 i2c interface. Select this if your platform is using the i2c bus.
If you choose to build a module, it'll be called pn544_i2c. Say N if unsure.

entry.name: NFC_PN544_MEI
entry.label: NXP PN544 device support (MEI)
entry.help:
This module adds support for the mei interface of adapters using NXP pn544 chipsets. Select this if your pn544 chipset is handled by Intel's Management Engine Interface on your platform.
If you choose to build a module, it'll be called pn544_mei. Say N if unsure.

entry.name: NFC_PN533
entry.help: NXP PN533 core driver. This driver provides core functionality for NXP PN533 NFC devices.

entry.name: NFC_PN533_USB
entry.label: NFC PN533 device support (USB)
entry.help:
This module adds support for the NXP pn533 USB interface. Select this if your platform is using the USB bus.
If you choose to build a module, it'll be called pn533_usb. Say N if unsure.

entry.name: NFC_PN533_I2C
entry.label: NFC PN533 device support (I2C)
entry.help:
This module adds support for the NXP pn533 I2C interface. Select this if your platform is using the I2C bus.
If you choose to build a module, it'll be called pn533_i2c. Say N if unsure.

entry.name: NFC_MICROREAD
entry.help: This module contains the main code for Inside Secure microread NFC chipsets. It implements the chipset HCI logic and hooks into the NFC kernel APIs. Physical layers will register against it.

entry.name: NFC_MICROREAD_I2C
entry.label: Inside Secure Microread device support (I2C)
entry.help:
This module adds support for the i2c interface of adapters using Inside microread chipsets. Select this if your platform is using the i2c bus.
If you choose to build a module, it'll be called microread_i2c. Say N if unsure.

entry.name: NFC_MICROREAD_MEI
entry.label: Inside Secure Microread device support (MEI)
entry.help:
This module adds support for the mei interface of adapters using Inside microread chipsets. Select this if your microread chipset is handled by Intel's Management Engine Interface on your platform.
If you choose to build a module, it'll be called microread_mei. Say N if unsure.

entry.name: NFC_MRVL
entry.help:
The core driver to support Marvell NFC devices.
This driver is required if you want to support Marvell NFC device 8897.

entry.name: NFC_MRVL_USB
entry.label: Marvell NFC-over-USB driver
entry.help:
Marvell NFC-over-USB driver.
This driver provides support for Marvell NFC-over-USB devices: 8897.
Say Y here to compile support for Marvell NFC-over-USB driver into the kernel or say M to compile it as module.

entry.name: NFC_MRVL_UART
entry.label: Marvell NFC-over-UART driver
entry.help:
Marvell NFC-over-UART driver.
This driver provides support for Marvell NFC-over-UART devices
Say Y here to compile support for Marvell NFC-over-UART driver into the kernel or say M to compile it as module.

entry.name: NFC_MRVL_I2C
entry.label: Marvell NFC-over-I2C driver
entry.help:
Marvell NFC-over-I2C driver.
This driver provides support for Marvell NFC-over-I2C devices.
Say Y here to compile support for Marvell NFC-over-I2C driver into the kernel or say M to compile it as module.

entry.name: NFC_MRVL_SPI
entry.label: Marvell NFC-over-SPI driver
entry.help:
Marvell NFC-over-SPI driver.
This driver provides support for Marvell NFC-over-SPI devices.
Say Y here to compile support for Marvell NFC-over-SPI driver into the kernel or say M to compile it as module.

entry.name: NFC_ST21NFCA
entry.help: STMicroelectronics ST21NFCA core driver. It implements the chipset HCI logic and hooks into the NFC kernel APIs. Physical layers will register against it.

entry.name: NFC_ST21NFCA_I2C
entry.label: STMicroelectronics ST21NFCA NFC driver (I2C)
entry.help:
This module adds support for the STMicroelectronics st21nfca i2c interface. Select this if your platform is using the i2c bus.
If you choose to build a module, it'll be called st21nfca_i2c. Say N if unsure.

entry.name: NFC_ST_NCI
entry.help: STMicroelectronics NFC NCI chips core driver. It implements the chipset NCI logic and hooks into the NFC kernel APIs. Physical layers will register against it.

entry.name: NFC_ST_NCI_I2C
entry.label: STMicroelectronics ST NCI NFC driver (I2C)
entry.help:
This module adds support for an I2C interface to the STMicroelectronics NFC NCI chips familly. Select this if your platform is using the i2c bus.
If you choose to build a module, it'll be called st-nci_i2c. Say N if unsure.

entry.name: NFC_ST_NCI_SPI
entry.label: STMicroelectronics ST NCI NFC driver (SPI)
entry.help:
This module adds support for an SPI interface to the STMicroelectronics NFC NCI chips familly. Select this if your platform is using the spi bus.
If you choose to build a module, it'll be called st-nci_spi. Say N if unsure.

entry.name: NFC_NXP_NCI
entry.label: NXP-NCI NFC driver
entry.help:
Generic core driver for NXP NCI chips such as the NPC100 or PN7150 families. This is a driver based on the NCI NFC kernel layers and will thus not work with NXP libnfc library.
To compile this driver as a module, choose m here. The module will be called nxp_nci. Say N if unsure.

entry.name: NFC_NXP_NCI_I2C
entry.label: NXP-NCI I2C support
entry.help:
This module adds support for an I2C interface to the NXP NCI chips. Select this if your platform is using the I2C bus.
To compile this driver as a module, choose m here. The module will be called nxp_nci_i2c. Say Y if unsure.

entry.name: NFC_S3FWRN5
entry.help: Core driver for Samsung S3FWRN5 NFC chip. Contains core utilities of chip. It's intended to be used by PHYs to avoid duplicating lots of common code.

entry.name: NFC_S3FWRN5_I2C
entry.label: Samsung S3FWRN5 I2C support
entry.help:
This module adds support for an I2C interface to the S3FWRN5 chip. Select this if your platform is using the I2C bus.
To compile this driver as a module, choose m here. The module will be called s3fwrn5_i2c.ko. Say N if unsure.

entry.name: NFC_ST95HF
entry.label: ST95HF NFC Transceiver driver
entry.help:
This enables the ST NFC driver for ST95HF NFC transceiver. This makes use of SPI framework to communicate with transceiver and registered with NFC digital core to support Linux NFC framework.
Say Y here to compile support for ST NFC transceiver ST95HF linux driver into the kernel or say M to compile it as module.

entry.name: LWTUNNEL
entry.label: Network light weight tunnels
entry.help: This feature provides an infrastructure to support light weight tunnels like mpls. There is no netdevice associated with a light weight tunnel endpoint. Tunnel encapsulation parameters are stored with light weight tunnel state associated with fib routes.

entry.name: NET_DEVLINK
entry.label: Network physical/parent device Netlink interface
entry.help: Network physical/parent device Netlink interface provides infrastructure to support access to physical chip-wide config and monitoring.

entry.name: MAY_USE_DEVLINK
entry.help: Drivers using the devlink infrastructure should have a dependency on MAY_USE_DEVLINK to ensure they do not cause link errors when devlink is a loadable module and the driver using it is built-in.

entry.name: TEGRA_AHB
entry.help: Adds AHB configuration functionality for NVIDIA Tegra SoCs, which controls AHB bus master arbitration and some performance parameters (priority, prefetch size).

entry.name: UEVENT_HELPER
entry.label: Support for uevent helper
entry.help: The uevent helper program is forked by the kernel for every uevent. Before the switch to the netlink-based uevent source, this was used to hook hotplug scripts into kernel device events. It usually pointed to a shell script at /sbin/hotplug. This should not be used today, because usual systems create many events at bootup or device discovery in a very short time frame. One forked process per event can create so many processes that it creates a high system load, or on smaller systems it is known to create out-of-memory situations during bootup.

entry.name: UEVENT_HELPER_PATH
entry.label: path to uevent helper
entry.help: To disable user space helper program execution at by default specify an empty string here. This setting can still be altered via /proc/sys/kernel/hotplug or via /sys/kernel/uevent_helper later at runtime.

entry.name: DEVTMPFS
entry.label: Maintain a devtmpfs filesystem to mount at /dev
entry.help:
This creates a tmpfs/ramfs filesystem instance early at bootup. In this filesystem, the kernel driver core maintains device nodes with their default names and permissions for all registered devices with an assigned major/minor number. Userspace can modify the filesystem content as needed, add symlinks, and apply needed permissions. It provides a fully functional /dev directory, where usually udev runs on top, managing permissions and adding meaningful symlinks. In very limited environments, it may provide a sufficient functional /dev without any further help. It also allows simple rescue systems, and reliably handles dynamic major/minor numbers.
Notice: if CONFIG_TMPFS isn't enabled, the simpler ramfs file system will be used instead.

entry.name: DEVTMPFS_MOUNT
entry.label: Automount devtmpfs at /dev, after the kernel mounted the rootfs
entry.help: This will instruct the kernel to automatically mount the devtmpfs filesystem at /dev, directly after the kernel has mounted the root filesystem. The behavior can be overridden with the commandline parameter: devtmpfs.mount=0|1. This option does not affect initramfs based booting, here the devtmpfs filesystem always needs to be mounted manually after the rootfs is mounted. With this option enabled, it allows to bring up a system in rescue mode with init=/bin/sh, even when the /dev directory on the rootfs is completely empty.

entry.name: STANDALONE
entry.label: Select only drivers that don't need compile-time external firmware
entry.help:
Select this option if you don't have magic firmware for drivers that need it.
If unsure, say Y.

entry.name: PREVENT_FIRMWARE_BUILD
entry.label: Prevent firmware from being built
entry.help: Say yes to avoid building firmware. Firmware is usually shipped with the driver and only when updating the firmware should a rebuild be made. If unsure, say Y here.

entry.name: FW_LOADER
entry.label: Userspace firmware loading support" if EXPERT
entry.help: This option is provided for the case where none of the in-tree modules require userspace firmware loading support, but a module built out-of-tree does.

entry.name: FIRMWARE_IN_KERNEL
entry.label: Include in-kernel firmware blobs in kernel binary
entry.help:
The kernel source tree includes a number of firmware 'blobs' that are used by various drivers. The recommended way to use these is to run "make firmware_install", which, after converting ihex files to binary, copies all of the needed binary files in firmware/ to /lib/firmware/ on your system so that they can be loaded by userspace helpers on request.
Enabling this option will build each required firmware blob into the kernel directly, where request_firmware() will find them without having to call out to userspace. This may be useful if your root file system requires a device that uses such firmware and do not wish to use an initrd.
This single option controls the inclusion of firmware for every driver that uses request_firmware() and ships its firmware in the kernel source tree, which avoids a proliferation of 'Include firmware for xxx device' options.
Say 'N' and let firmware be loaded from userspace.

entry.name: EXTRA_FIRMWARE
entry.label: External firmware blobs to build into the kernel binary
entry.help:
This option allows firmware to be built into the kernel for the case where the user either cannot or doesn't want to provide it from userspace at runtime (for example, when the firmware in question is required for accessing the boot device, and the user doesn't want to use an initrd).
This option is a string and takes the (space-separated) names of the firmware files -- the same names that appear in MODULE_FIRMWARE() and request_firmware() in the source. These files should exist under the directory specified by the EXTRA_FIRMWARE_DIR option, which is by default the firmware subdirectory of the kernel source tree.
For example, you might set CONFIG_EXTRA_FIRMWARE="usb8388.bin", copy the usb8388.bin file into the firmware directory, and build the kernel. Then any request_firmware("usb8388.bin") will be satisfied internally without needing to call out to userspace.
WARNING: If you include additional firmware files into your binary kernel image that are not available under the terms of the GPL, then it may be a violation of the GPL to distribute the resulting image since it combines both GPL and non-GPL work. You should consult a lawyer of your own before distributing such an image.

entry.name: EXTRA_FIRMWARE_DIR
entry.label: Firmware blobs root directory
entry.help: This option controls the directory in which the kernel build system looks for the firmware files listed in the EXTRA_FIRMWARE option. The default is firmware/ in the kernel source tree, but by changing this option you can point it elsewhere, such as /lib/firmware/ or some other directory containing the firmware files.

entry.name: FW_LOADER_USER_HELPER_FALLBACK
entry.label: Fallback user-helper invocation for firmware loading
entry.help:
This option enables / disables the invocation of user-helper (e.g. udev) for loading firmware files as a fallback after the direct file loading in kernel fails. The user-mode helper is no longer required unless you have a special firmware file that resides in a non-standard path. Moreover, the udev support has been deprecated upstream.
If you are unsure about this, say N here.

entry.name: WANT_DEV_COREDUMP
entry.help: Drivers should "select" this option if they desire to use the device coredump mechanism.

entry.name: ALLOW_DEV_COREDUMP
entry.label: Allow device coredump" if EXPERT
entry.help:
This option controls if the device coredump mechanism is available or not; if disabled, the mechanism will be omitted even if drivers that can use it are enabled. Say 'N' for more sensitive systems or systems that don't want to ever access the information to not have the code, nor keep any data.
If unsure, say Y.

entry.name: DEBUG_DRIVER
entry.label: Driver Core verbose debug messages
entry.help:
Say Y here if you want the Driver core to produce a bunch of debug messages to the system log. Select this if you are having a problem with the driver core and want to see more of what is going on.
If you are unsure about this, say N here.

entry.name: DEBUG_DEVRES
entry.label: Managed device resources verbose debug messages
entry.help:
This option enables kernel parameter devres.log. If set to non-zero, devres debug messages are printed. Select this if you are having a problem with devres or want to debug resource management for a managed device. devres.log can be switched on and off from sysfs node.
If you are unsure about this, Say N here.

entry.name: DMA_SHARED_BUFFER
entry.help: This option enables the framework for buffer-sharing between multiple drivers. A buffer is associated with a file using driver APIs extension; the file's descriptor can then be passed on to other driver.

entry.name: FENCE_TRACE
entry.label: Enable verbose FENCE_TRACE messages
entry.help: Enable the FENCE_TRACE printks. This will add extra spam to the console log, but will make it easier to diagnose lockup related problems for dma-buffers shared across multiple devices.

entry.name: DMA_CMA
entry.label: DMA Contiguous Memory Allocator
entry.help:
This enables the Contiguous Memory Allocator which allows drivers to allocate big physically-contiguous blocks of memory for use with hardware components that do not support I/O map nor scatter-gather.
You can disable CMA by specifying "cma=0" on the kernel's command line.
For more information see <include/linux/dma-contiguous.h>. If unsure, say "n".

entry.name: CMA_SIZE_MBYTES
entry.label: Size in Mega Bytes
entry.help: Defines the size (in MiB) of the default memory area for Contiguous Memory Allocator. If the size of 0 is selected, CMA is disabled by default, but it can be enabled by passing cma=size[MG] to the kernel.

entry.name: CMA_SIZE_PERCENTAGE
entry.label: Percentage of total memory
entry.help: Defines the size of the default memory area for Contiguous Memory Allocator as a percentage of the total memory in the system. If 0 percent is selected, CMA is disabled by default, but it can be enabled by passing cma=size[MG] to the kernel.

entry.name: CMA_ALIGNMENT
entry.label: Maximum PAGE_SIZE order of alignment for contiguous buffers
entry.help:
DMA mapping framework by default aligns all buffers to the smallest PAGE_SIZE order which is greater than or equal to the requested buffer size. This works well for buffers up to a few hundreds kilobytes, but for larger buffers it just a memory waste. With this parameter you can specify the maximum PAGE_SIZE order for contiguous buffers. Larger buffers will be aligned only to this specified order. The order is expressed as a power of two multiplied by the PAGE_SIZE.
For example, if your system defaults to 4KiB pages, the order value of 8 means that the buffers will be aligned up to 1MiB only.
If unsure, leave the default value "8".

entry.name: ARM_CCI400_PMU
entry.label: ARM CCI400 PMU support
entry.help: Support for PMU events monitoring on the ARM CCI-400 (cache coherent interconnect). CCI-400 supports counting events related to the connected slave/master interfaces.

entry.name: ARM_CCI400_PORT_CTRL
entry.help: Low level power management driver for CCI400 cache coherent interconnect for ARM platforms.

entry.name: ARM_CCI5xx_PMU
entry.label: ARM CCI-500/CCI-550 PMU support
entry.help:
Support for PMU events monitoring on the ARM CCI-500/CCI-550 cache coherent interconnects. Both of them provide 8 independent event counters, which can count events pertaining to the slave/master interfaces as well as the internal events to the CCI.
If unsure, say Y

entry.name: ARM_CCN
entry.label: ARM CCN driver support
entry.help: PMU (perf) driver supporting the ARM CCN (Cache Coherent Network) interconnect.

entry.name: BRCMSTB_GISB_ARB
entry.label: Broadcom STB GISB bus arbiter
entry.help: Driver for the Broadcom Set Top Box System-on-a-chip internal bus arbiter. This driver provides timeout and target abort error handling and internal bus master decoding.

entry.name: IMX_WEIM
entry.label: Freescale EIM DRIVER
entry.help: Driver for i.MX WEIM controller. The WEIM(Wireless External Interface Module) works like a bus. You can attach many different devices on it, such as NOR, onenand.

entry.name: MIPS_CDMM
entry.label: MIPS Common Device Memory Map (CDMM) Driver
entry.help:
Driver needed for the MIPS Common Device Memory Map bus in MIPS cores. This bus is for per-CPU tightly coupled devices such as the Fast Debug Channel (FDC).
For this to work, either your bootloader needs to enable the CDMM region at an unused physical address on the boot CPU, or else your platform code needs to implement mips_cdmm_phys_base() (see asm/cdmm.h).

entry.name: MVEBU_MBUS
entry.help: Driver needed for the MBus configuration on Marvell EBU SoCs (Kirkwood, Dove, Orion5x, MV78XX0 and Armada 370/XP).

entry.name: OMAP_INTERCONNECT
entry.label: OMAP INTERCONNECT DRIVER
entry.help: Driver to enable OMAP interconnect error handling driver.

entry.name: OMAP_OCP2SCP
entry.label: OMAP OCP2SCP DRIVER
entry.help: Driver to enable ocp2scp module which transforms ocp interface protocol to scp protocol. In OMAP4, USB PHY is connected via OCP2SCP and in OMAP5, both USB PHY and SATA PHY is connected via OCP2SCP.

entry.name: SIMPLE_PM_BUS
entry.label: Simple Power-Managed Bus Driver
entry.help: Driver for transparent busses that don't need a real driver, but where the bus controller is part of a PM domain, or under the control of a functional clock, and thus relies on runtime PM for managing this PM domain and/or clock. An example of such a bus controller is the Renesas Bus State Controller (BSC, sometimes called "LBSC within Bus Bridge", or "External Bus Interface") as found on several Renesas ARM SoCs.

entry.name: SUNXI_RSB
entry.label: Allwinner sunXi Reduced Serial Bus Driver
entry.help: Say y here to enable support for Allwinner's Reduced Serial Bus (RSB) support. This controller is responsible for communicating with various RSB based devices, such as AXP223, AXP8XX PMICs, and AC100/AC200 ICs.

entry.name: TEGRA_ACONNECT
entry.label: Tegra ACONNECT Bus Driver
entry.help: Driver for the Tegra ACONNECT bus which is used to interface with the devices inside the Audio Processing Engine (APE) for Tegra210.

entry.name: UNIPHIER_SYSTEM_BUS
entry.label: UniPhier System Bus driver
entry.help: Support for UniPhier System Bus, a simple external bus. This is needed to use on-board devices connected to UniPhier SoCs.

entry.name: VEXPRESS_CONFIG
entry.label: Versatile Express configuration bus
entry.help: Platform configuration infrastructure for the ARM Ltd. Versatile Express.

entry.name: CONNECTOR
entry.label: Connector - unified userspace <-> kernelspace linker
entry.help:
This is unified userspace <-> kernelspace connector working on top of the netlink socket protocol.
Connector support can also be built as a module. If so, the module will be called cn.

entry.name: PROC_EVENTS
entry.label: Report process events to userspace
entry.help: Provide a connector that reports process events to userspace. Send events such as fork, exec, id change (uid, gid, suid, etc), and exit.

entry.name: MTD
entry.label: Memory Technology Device (MTD) support
entry.help: Memory Technology Devices are flash, RAM and similar chips, often used for solid state file systems on embedded devices. This option will provide the generic support for MTD drivers to register themselves with the kernel and for potential users of MTD devices to enumerate the devices which are present and obtain a handle on them. It will also allow you to select individual drivers for particular hardware and users of MTD devices. If unsure, say N.

entry.name: MTD_TESTS
entry.label: MTD tests support (DANGEROUS)
entry.help:
This option includes various MTD tests into compilation. The tests should normally be compiled as kernel modules. The modules perform various checks and verifications when loaded.
WARNING: some of the tests will ERASE entire MTD device which they test. Do not use these tests unless you really know what you do.

entry.name: MTD_REDBOOT_PARTS
entry.label: RedBoot partition table parsing
entry.help:
RedBoot is a ROM monitor and bootloader which deals with multiple 'images' in flash devices by putting a table one of the erase blocks on the device, similar to a partition table, which gives the offsets, lengths and names of all the images stored in the flash.
If you need code which can detect and parse this table, and register MTD 'partitions' corresponding to each image in the table, enable this option.
You will still need the parsing functions to be called by the driver for your particular device. It won't happen automatically. The SA1100 map driver (CONFIG_MTD_SA1100) has an option for this, for example.

entry.name: MTD_REDBOOT_DIRECTORY_BLOCK
entry.label: Location of RedBoot partition table
entry.help:
This option is the Linux counterpart to the CYGNUM_REDBOOT_FIS_DIRECTORY_BLOCK RedBoot compile time option.
The option specifies which Flash sectors holds the RedBoot partition table. A zero or positive value gives an absolute erase block number. A negative value specifies a number of sectors before the end of the device.
For example "2" means block number 2, "-1" means the last block and "-2" means the penultimate block.

entry.name: MTD_REDBOOT_PARTS_UNALLOCATED
entry.label: Include unallocated flash regions
entry.help: If you need to register each unallocated flash region as a MTD 'partition', enable this option.

entry.name: MTD_REDBOOT_PARTS_READONLY
entry.label: Force read-only for RedBoot system images
entry.help: If you need to force read-only for 'RedBoot', 'RedBoot Config' and 'FIS directory' images, enable this option.

entry.name: MTD_CMDLINE_PARTS
entry.label: Command line partition table parsing
entry.help:
Allow generic configuration of the MTD partition tables via the kernel command line. Multiple flash resources are supported for hardware where different kinds of flash memory are available.
You will still need the parsing functions to be called by the driver for your particular device. It won't happen automatically. The SA1100 map driver (CONFIG_MTD_SA1100) has an option for this, for example.
The format for the command line is as follows:
mtdparts=<mtddef>[;<mtddef] <mtddef> := <mtd-id>:<partdef>[,<partdef>] <partdef> := <size>[@offset][<name>][ro] <mtd-id> := unique id used in mapping driver/device <size> := standard linux memsize OR "-" to denote all remaining space <name> := (NAME)
Due to the way Linux handles the command line, no spaces are allowed in the partition definition, including mtd id's and partition names.
Examples:
1 flash resource (mtd-id "sa1100"), with 1 single writable partition: mtdparts=sa1100:-
Same flash, but 2 named partitions, the first one being read-only: mtdparts=sa1100:256k(ARMboot)ro,-(root)
If unsure, say 'N'.

entry.name: MTD_AFS_PARTS
entry.label: ARM Firmware Suite partition parsing
entry.help:
The ARM Firmware Suite allows the user to divide flash devices into multiple 'images'. Each such image has a header containing its name and offset/size etc.
If you need code which can detect and parse these tables, and register MTD 'partitions' corresponding to each image detected, enable this option.
You will still need the parsing functions to be called by the driver for your particular device. It won't happen automatically. The 'physmap' map driver (CONFIG_MTD_PHYSMAP) does this, for example.

entry.name: MTD_OF_PARTS
entry.label: OpenFirmware partitioning information support
entry.help: This provides a partition parsing function which derives the partition map from the children of the flash node, as described in Documentation/devicetree/bindings/mtd/partition.txt.

entry.name: MTD_AR7_PARTS
entry.label: TI AR7 partitioning support
entry.help: TI AR7 partitioning support

entry.name: MTD_BCM63XX_PARTS
entry.label: BCM63XX CFE partitioning support
entry.help: This provides partions parsing for BCM63xx devices with CFE bootloaders.

entry.name: MTD_BCM47XX_PARTS
entry.label: BCM47XX partitioning support
entry.help: This provides partitions parser for devices based on BCM47xx boards.

entry.name: MTD_BLOCK
entry.label: Caching block device access to MTD devices
entry.help:
Although most flash chips have an erase size too large to be useful as block devices, it is possible to use MTD devices which are based on RAM chips in this manner. This block device is a user of MTD devices performing that function.
At the moment, it is also required for the Journalling Flash File System(s) to obtain a handle on the MTD device when it's mounted (although JFFS and JFFS2 don't actually use any of the functionality of the mtdblock device).
Later, it may be extended to perform read/erase/modify/write cycles on flash chips to emulate a smaller block size. Needless to say, this is very unsafe, but could be useful for file systems which are almost never written to.
You do not need this option for use with the DiskOnChip devices. For those, enable NFTL support (CONFIG_NFTL) instead.

entry.name: MTD_BLOCK_RO
entry.label: Readonly block device access to MTD devices
entry.help:
This allows you to mount read-only file systems (such as cramfs) from an MTD device, without the overhead (and danger) of the caching driver.
You do not need this option for use with the DiskOnChip devices. For those, enable NFTL support (CONFIG_NFTL) instead.

entry.name: FTL
entry.label: FTL (Flash Translation Layer) support
entry.help:
This provides support for the original Flash Translation Layer which is part of the PCMCIA specification. It uses a kind of pseudo- file system on a flash device to emulate a block device with 512-byte sectors, on top of which you put a 'normal' file system.
You may find that the algorithms used in this code are patented unless you live in the Free World where software patents aren't legal - in the USA you are only permitted to use this on PCMCIA hardware, although under the terms of the GPL you're obviously permitted to copy, modify and distribute the code as you wish. Just not use it.

entry.name: NFTL
entry.label: NFTL (NAND Flash Translation Layer) support
entry.help:
This provides support for the NAND Flash Translation Layer which is used on M-Systems' DiskOnChip devices. It uses a kind of pseudo- file system on a flash device to emulate a block device with 512-byte sectors, on top of which you put a 'normal' file system.
You may find that the algorithms used in this code are patented unless you live in the Free World where software patents aren't legal - in the USA you are only permitted to use this on DiskOnChip hardware, although under the terms of the GPL you're obviously permitted to copy, modify and distribute the code as you wish. Just not use it.

entry.name: NFTL_RW
entry.label: Write support for NFTL
entry.help: Support for writing to the NAND Flash Translation Layer, as used on the DiskOnChip.

entry.name: INFTL
entry.label: INFTL (Inverse NAND Flash Translation Layer) support
entry.help:
This provides support for the Inverse NAND Flash Translation Layer which is used on M-Systems' newer DiskOnChip devices. It uses a kind of pseudo-file system on a flash device to emulate a block device with 512-byte sectors, on top of which you put a 'normal' file system.
You may find that the algorithms used in this code are patented unless you live in the Free World where software patents aren't legal - in the USA you are only permitted to use this on DiskOnChip hardware, although under the terms of the GPL you're obviously permitted to copy, modify and distribute the code as you wish. Just not use it.

entry.name: RFD_FTL
entry.label: Resident Flash Disk (Flash Translation Layer) support
entry.help:
This provides support for the flash translation layer known as the Resident Flash Disk (RFD), as used by the Embedded BIOS of General Software. There is a blurb at:
http://www.gensw.com/pages/prod/bios/rfd.htm

entry.name: SSFDC
entry.label: NAND SSFDC (SmartMedia) read only translation layer
entry.help: This enables read only access to SmartMedia formatted NAND flash. You can mount it with FAT file system.

entry.name: SM_FTL
entry.label: SmartMedia/xD new translation layer
entry.help: This enables EXPERIMENTAL R/W support for SmartMedia/xD FTL (Flash translation layer). Write support is only lightly tested, therefore this driver isn't recommended to use with valuable data (anyway if you have valuable data, do backups regardless of software/hardware you use, because you never know what will eat your data...) If you only need R/O access, you can use older R/O driver (CONFIG_SSFDC)

entry.name: MTD_OOPS
entry.label: Log panic/oops to an MTD buffer
entry.help: This enables panic and oops messages to be logged to a circular buffer in a flash partition where it can be read back at some later point.

entry.name: MTD_SWAP
entry.label: Swap on MTD device support
entry.help: Provides volatile block device driver on top of mtd partition suitable for swapping. The mapping of written blocks is not saved. The driver provides wear leveling by storing erase counter into the OOB.

entry.name: MTD_PARTITIONED_MASTER
entry.label: Retain master device when partitioned
entry.help: For historical reasons, by default, either a master is present or several partitions are present, but not both. The concern was that data listed in multiple partitions was dangerous; however, SCSI does this and it is frequently useful for applications. This config option leaves the master in even if the device is partitioned. It also makes the parent of the partition device be the master device, rather than what lies behind the master.

entry.name: MTD_CFI
entry.label: Detect flash chips by Common Flash Interface (CFI) probe
entry.help: The Common Flash Interface specification was developed by Intel, AMD and other flash manufactures that provides a universal method for probing the capabilities of flash devices. If you wish to support any device that is CFI-compliant, you need to enable this option. Visit <http://www.amd.com/products/nvd/overview/cfi.html> for more information on CFI.

entry.name: MTD_JEDECPROBE
entry.label: Detect non-CFI AMD/JEDEC-compatible flash chips
entry.help: This option enables JEDEC-style probing of flash chips which are not compatible with the Common Flash Interface, but will use the common CFI-targeted flash drivers for any chips which are identified which are in fact compatible in all but the probe method. This actually covers most AMD/Fujitsu-compatible chips and also non-CFI Intel chips.

entry.name: MTD_CFI_ADV_OPTIONS
entry.label: Flash chip driver advanced configuration options
entry.help:
If you need to specify a specific endianness for access to flash chips, or if you wish to reduce the size of the kernel by including support for only specific arrangements of flash chips, say 'Y'. This option does not directly affect the code, but will enable other configuration options which allow you to do so.
If unsure, say 'N'.

entry.name: MTD_CFI_GEOMETRY
entry.label: Specific CFI Flash geometry selection
entry.help: This option does not affect the code directly, but will enable some other configuration options which would allow you to reduce the size of the kernel by including support for only certain arrangements of CFI chips. If unsure, say 'N' and all options which are supported by the current code will be enabled.

entry.name: MTD_MAP_BANK_WIDTH_1
entry.label: Support 8-bit buswidth" if MTD_CFI_GEOMETRY
entry.help: If you wish to support CFI devices on a physical bus which is 8 bits wide, say 'Y'.

entry.name: MTD_MAP_BANK_WIDTH_2
entry.label: Support 16-bit buswidth" if MTD_CFI_GEOMETRY
entry.help: If you wish to support CFI devices on a physical bus which is 16 bits wide, say 'Y'.

entry.name: MTD_MAP_BANK_WIDTH_4
entry.label: Support 32-bit buswidth" if MTD_CFI_GEOMETRY
entry.help: If you wish to support CFI devices on a physical bus which is 32 bits wide, say 'Y'.

entry.name: MTD_MAP_BANK_WIDTH_8
entry.label: Support 64-bit buswidth" if MTD_CFI_GEOMETRY
entry.help: If you wish to support CFI devices on a physical bus which is 64 bits wide, say 'Y'.

entry.name: MTD_MAP_BANK_WIDTH_16
entry.label: Support 128-bit buswidth" if MTD_CFI_GEOMETRY
entry.help: If you wish to support CFI devices on a physical bus which is 128 bits wide, say 'Y'.

entry.name: MTD_MAP_BANK_WIDTH_32
entry.label: Support 256-bit buswidth" if MTD_CFI_GEOMETRY
entry.help: If you wish to support CFI devices on a physical bus which is 256 bits wide, say 'Y'.

entry.name: MTD_CFI_I1
entry.label: Support 1-chip flash interleave" if MTD_CFI_GEOMETRY
entry.help: If your flash chips are not interleaved - i.e. you only have one flash chip addressed by each bus cycle, then say 'Y'.

entry.name: MTD_CFI_I2
entry.label: Support 2-chip flash interleave" if MTD_CFI_GEOMETRY
entry.help: If your flash chips are interleaved in pairs - i.e. you have two flash chips addressed by each bus cycle, then say 'Y'.

entry.name: MTD_CFI_I4
entry.label: Support 4-chip flash interleave" if MTD_CFI_GEOMETRY
entry.help: If your flash chips are interleaved in fours - i.e. you have four flash chips addressed by each bus cycle, then say 'Y'.

entry.name: MTD_CFI_I8
entry.label: Support 8-chip flash interleave" if MTD_CFI_GEOMETRY
entry.help: If your flash chips are interleaved in eights - i.e. you have eight flash chips addressed by each bus cycle, then say 'Y'.

entry.name: MTD_OTP
entry.label: Protection Registers aka one-time programmable (OTP) bits
entry.help:
This enables support for reading, writing and locking so called "Protection Registers" present on some flash chips. A subset of them are pre-programmed at the factory with a unique set of values. The rest is user-programmable.
The user-programmable Protection Registers contain one-time programmable (OTP) bits; when programmed, register bits cannot be erased. Each Protection Register can be accessed multiple times to program individual bits, as long as the register remains unlocked.
Each Protection Register has an associated Lock Register bit. When a Lock Register bit is programmed, the associated Protection Register can only be read; it can no longer be programmed. Additionally, because the Lock Register bits themselves are OTP, when programmed, Lock Register bits cannot be erased. Therefore, when a Protection Register is locked, it cannot be unlocked.
This feature should therefore be used with extreme care. Any mistake in the programming of OTP bits will waste them.

entry.name: MTD_CFI_INTELEXT
entry.label: Support for CFI command set 0001 (Intel/Sharp chips)
entry.help: The Common Flash Interface defines a number of different command sets which a CFI-compliant chip may claim to implement. This code provides support for command set 0001, used on Intel StrataFlash and other parts.

entry.name: MTD_CFI_AMDSTD
entry.label: Support for CFI command set 0002 (AMD/Fujitsu/Spansion chips)
entry.help: The Common Flash Interface defines a number of different command sets which a CFI-compliant chip may claim to implement. This code provides support for command set 0002, used on chips including the AMD Am29LV320.

entry.name: MTD_CFI_STAA
entry.label: Support for CFI command set 0020 (ST (Advanced Architecture) chips)
entry.help: The Common Flash Interface defines a number of different command sets which a CFI-compliant chip may claim to implement. This code provides support for command set 0020.

entry.name: MTD_RAM
entry.label: Support for RAM chips in bus mapping
entry.help: This option enables basic support for RAM chips accessed through a bus mapping driver.

entry.name: MTD_ROM
entry.label: Support for ROM chips in bus mapping
entry.help: This option enables basic support for ROM chips accessed through a bus mapping driver.

entry.name: MTD_ABSENT
entry.label: Support for absent chips in bus mapping
entry.help: This option enables support for a dummy probing driver used to allocated placeholder MTD devices on systems that have socketed or removable media. Use of this driver as a fallback chip probe preserves the expected registration order of MTD device nodes on the system regardless of media presence. Device nodes created with this driver will return -ENODEV upon access.

entry.name: MTD_XIP
entry.label: XIP aware MTD support
entry.help: This allows MTD support to work with flash memory which is also used for XIP purposes. If you're not sure what this is all about then say N.

entry.name: MTD_COMPLEX_MAPPINGS
entry.label: Support non-linear mappings of flash chips
entry.help: This causes the chip drivers to allow for complicated paged mappings of flash chips.

entry.name: MTD_PHYSMAP
entry.label: Flash device in physical memory map
entry.help:
This provides a 'mapping' driver which allows the NOR Flash and ROM driver code to communicate with chips which are mapped physically into the CPU's memory. You will need to configure the physical address and size of the flash chips on your particular board as well as the bus width, either statically with config options or at run-time.
To compile this driver as a module, choose M here: the module will be called physmap.

entry.name: MTD_PHYSMAP_COMPAT
entry.label: Physmap compat support
entry.help:
Setup a simple mapping via the Kconfig options. Normally the physmap configuration options are done via your board's resource file.
If unsure, say N here.

entry.name: MTD_PHYSMAP_BANKWIDTH
entry.label: Bank width in octets
entry.help: This is the total width of the data bus of the flash devices in octets. For example, if you have a data bus width of 32 bits, you would set the bus width octet value to 4. This is used internally by the CFI drivers.

entry.name: MTD_PHYSMAP_OF
entry.label: Memory device in physical memory map based on OF description
entry.help: This provides a 'mapping' driver which allows the NOR Flash, ROM and RAM driver code to communicate with chips which are mapped physically into the CPU's memory. The mapping description here is taken from OF device tree.

entry.name: MTD_PHYSMAP_OF_VERSATILE
entry.label: Support ARM Versatile physmap OF
entry.help: This provides some extra DT physmap parsing for the ARM Versatile platforms, basically to add a VPP (write protection) callback so the flash can be taken out of write protection.

entry.name: MTD_PMC_MSP_EVM
entry.label: CFI Flash device mapped on PMC-Sierra MSP
entry.help: This provides a 'mapping' driver which supports the way in which user-programmable flash chips are connected on the PMC-Sierra MSP eval/demo boards.

entry.name: MTD_SUN_UFLASH
entry.label: Sun Microsystems userflash support
entry.help: This provides a 'mapping' driver which supports the way in which user-programmable flash chips are connected on various Sun Microsystems boardsets. This driver will require CFI support in the kernel, so if you did not enable CFI previously, do that now.

entry.name: MTD_SC520CDP
entry.label: CFI Flash device mapped on AMD SC520 CDP
entry.help: The SC520 CDP board has two banks of CFI-compliant chips and one Dual-in-line JEDEC chip. This 'mapping' driver supports that arrangement, implementing three MTD devices.

entry.name: MTD_NETSC520
entry.label: CFI Flash device mapped on AMD NetSc520
entry.help: This enables access routines for the flash chips on the AMD NetSc520 demonstration board. If you have one of these boards and would like to use the flash chips on it, say 'Y'.

entry.name: MTD_TS5500
entry.label: JEDEC Flash device mapped on Technologic Systems TS-5500
entry.help:
This provides a driver for the on-board flash of the Technologic System's TS-5500 board. The 2MB flash is split into 3 partitions which are accessed as separate MTD devices.
mtd0 and mtd2 are the two BIOS drives, which use the resident flash disk (RFD) flash translation layer.
mtd1 allows you to reprogram your BIOS. BE VERY CAREFUL.
Note that jumper 3 ("Write Enable Drive A") must be set otherwise detection won't succeed.

entry.name: MTD_SBC_GXX
entry.label: CFI Flash device mapped on Arcom SBC-GXx boards
entry.help: This provides a driver for the on-board flash of Arcom Control Systems' SBC-GXn family of boards, formerly known as SBC-MediaGX. By default the flash is split into 3 partitions which are accessed as separate MTD devices. This board utilizes Intel StrataFlash. More info at <http://www.arcomcontrols.com/products/icp/pc104/processors/SBC_GX1.htm>.

entry.name: MTD_PXA2XX
entry.label: CFI Flash device mapped on Intel XScale PXA2xx based boards
entry.help: This provides a driver for the NOR flash attached to a PXA2xx chip.

entry.name: MTD_SCx200_DOCFLASH
entry.label: Flash device mapped with DOCCS on NatSemi SCx200
entry.help:
Enable support for a flash chip mapped using the DOCCS signal on a National Semiconductor SCx200 processor.
If you don't know what to do here, say N.
If compiled as a module, it will be called scx200_docflash.

entry.name: MTD_AMD76XROM
entry.label: BIOS flash chip on AMD76x southbridge
entry.help:
Support for treating the BIOS flash chip on AMD76x motherboards as an MTD device - with this you can reprogram your BIOS.
BE VERY CAREFUL.

entry.name: MTD_ICHXROM
entry.label: BIOS flash chip on Intel Controller Hub 2/3/4/5
entry.help:
Support for treating the BIOS flash chip on ICHX motherboards as an MTD device - with this you can reprogram your BIOS.
BE VERY CAREFUL.

entry.name: MTD_ESB2ROM
entry.label: BIOS flash chip on Intel ESB Controller Hub 2
entry.help:
Support for treating the BIOS flash chip on ESB2 motherboards as an MTD device - with this you can reprogram your BIOS.
BE VERY CAREFUL.

entry.name: MTD_CK804XROM
entry.label: BIOS flash chip on Nvidia CK804
entry.help:
Support for treating the BIOS flash chip on nvidia motherboards as an MTD device - with this you can reprogram your BIOS.
BE VERY CAREFUL.

entry.name: MTD_SCB2_FLASH
entry.label: BIOS flash chip on Intel SCB2 boards
entry.help:
Support for treating the BIOS flash chip on Intel SCB2 boards as an MTD device - with this you can reprogram your BIOS.
BE VERY CAREFUL.

entry.name: MTD_TSUNAMI
entry.label: Flash chips on Tsunami TIG bus
entry.help: Support for the flash chip on Tsunami TIG bus.

entry.name: MTD_NETtel
entry.label: CFI flash device on SnapGear/SecureEdge
entry.help: Support for flash chips on NETtel/SecureEdge/SnapGear boards.

entry.name: MTD_LANTIQ
entry.label: Lantiq SoC NOR support
entry.help: Support for NOR flash attached to the Lantiq SoC's External Bus Unit.

entry.name: MTD_L440GX
entry.label: BIOS flash chip on Intel L440GX boards
entry.help:
Support for treating the BIOS flash chip on Intel L440GX motherboards as an MTD device - with this you can reprogram your BIOS.
BE VERY CAREFUL.

entry.name: MTD_CFI_FLAGADM
entry.label: CFI Flash device mapping on FlagaDM
entry.help: Mapping for the Flaga digital module. If you don't have one, ignore this setting.

entry.name: MTD_SOLUTIONENGINE
entry.label: CFI Flash device mapped on Hitachi SolutionEngine
entry.help: This enables access to the flash chips on the Hitachi SolutionEngine and similar boards. Say 'Y' if you are building a kernel for such a board.

entry.name: MTD_SA1100
entry.label: CFI Flash device mapped on StrongARM SA11x0
entry.help: This enables access to the flash chips on most platforms based on the SA1100 and SA1110, including the Assabet and the Compaq iPAQ. If you have such a board, say 'Y'.

entry.name: MTD_DC21285
entry.label: CFI Flash device mapped on DC21285 Footbridge
entry.help: This provides a driver for the flash accessed using Intel's 21285 bridge used with Intel's StrongARM processors. More info at <http://www.intel.com/design/bridge/docs/21285_documentation.htm>.

entry.name: MTD_IXP4XX
entry.label: CFI Flash device mapped on Intel IXP4xx based systems
entry.help: This enables MTD access to flash devices on platforms based on Intel's IXP4xx family of network processors such as the IXDP425 and Coyote. If you have an IXP4xx based board and would like to use the flash chips on it, say 'Y'.

entry.name: MTD_IMPA7
entry.label: JEDEC Flash device mapped on impA7
entry.help: This enables access to the NOR Flash on the impA7 board of implementa GmbH. If you have such a board, say 'Y' here.

entry.name: MTD_PCI
entry.label: PCI MTD driver
entry.help:
Mapping for accessing flash devices on add-in cards like the Intel XScale IQ80310 card, and the Intel EBSA285 card in blank ROM programming mode (please see the manual for the link settings).
If you are not sure, say N.

entry.name: MTD_PCMCIA
entry.label: PCMCIA MTD driver
entry.help: Map driver for accessing PCMCIA linear flash memory cards. These cards are usually around 4-16MiB in size. This does not include Compact Flash cards which are treated as IDE devices.

entry.name: MTD_PCMCIA_ANONYMOUS
entry.label: Use PCMCIA MTD drivers for anonymous PCMCIA cards
entry.help:
If this option is enabled, PCMCIA cards which do not report anything about themselves are assumed to be MTD cards.
If unsure, say N.

entry.name: MTD_BFIN_ASYNC
entry.label: Blackfin BF533-STAMP Flash Chip Support
entry.help:
Map driver which allows for simultaneous utilization of ethernet and CFI parallel flash.
If compiled as a module, it will be called bfin-async-flash.

entry.name: MTD_GPIO_ADDR
entry.label: GPIO-assisted Flash Chip Support
entry.help:
Map driver which allows flashes to be partially physically addressed and assisted by GPIOs.
If compiled as a module, it will be called gpio-addr-flash.

entry.name: MTD_UCLINUX
entry.label: Generic uClinux RAM/ROM filesystem support
entry.help: Map driver to support image based filesystems for uClinux.

entry.name: MTD_INTEL_VR_NOR
entry.label: NOR flash on Intel Vermilion Range Expansion Bus CS0
entry.help: Map driver for a NOR flash bank located on the Expansion Bus of the Intel Vermilion Range chipset.

entry.name: MTD_RBTX4939
entry.label: Map driver for RBTX4939 board
entry.help: Map driver for NOR flash chips on RBTX4939 board.

entry.name: MTD_PLATRAM
entry.label: Map driver for platform device RAM (mtd-ram)
entry.help:
Map driver for RAM areas described via the platform device system.
This selection automatically selects the map_ram driver.

entry.name: MTD_VMU
entry.label: Map driver for Dreamcast VMU
entry.help:
This driver enables access to the Dreamcast Visual Memory Unit (VMU).
Most Dreamcast users will want to say Y here.
To build this as a module select M here, the module will be called vmu-flash.

entry.name: MTD_PISMO
entry.label: MTD discovery driver for PISMO modules
entry.help:
This driver allows for discovery of PISMO modules - see <http://www.pismoworld.org/>. These are small modules containing up to five memory devices (eg, SRAM, flash, DOC) described by an I2C EEPROM.
This driver does not create any MTD maps itself; instead it creates MTD physmap and MTD SRAM platform devices. If you enable this option, you should consider enabling MTD_PHYSMAP and/or MTD_PLATRAM according to the devices on your module.
When built as a module, it will be called pismo.ko

entry.name: MTD_LATCH_ADDR
entry.label: Latch-assisted Flash Chip Support
entry.help:
Map driver which allows flashes to be partially physically addressed and have the upper address lines set by a board specific code.
If compiled as a module, it will be called latch-addr-flash.

entry.name: MTD_PMC551
entry.label: Ramix PMC551 PCI Mezzanine RAM card support
entry.help:
This provides a MTD device driver for the Ramix PMC551 RAM PCI card from Ramix Inc. <http://www.ramix.com/products/memory/pmc551.html>. These devices come in memory configurations from 32M - 1G. If you have one, you probably want to enable this.
If this driver is compiled as a module you get the ability to select the size of the aperture window pointing into the devices memory. What this means is that if you have a 1G card, normally the kernel will use a 1G memory map as its view of the device. As a module, you can select a 1M window into the memory and the driver will "slide" the window around the PMC551's memory. This was particularly useful on the 2.2 kernels on PPC architectures as there was limited kernel space to deal with.

entry.name: MTD_PMC551_BUGFIX
entry.label: PMC551 256M DRAM Bugfix
entry.help: Some of Ramix's PMC551 boards with 256M configurations have invalid column and row mux values. This option will fix them, but will break other memory configurations. If unsure say N.

entry.name: MTD_PMC551_DEBUG
entry.label: PMC551 Debugging
entry.help: This option makes the PMC551 more verbose during its operation and is only really useful if you are developing on this driver or suspect a possible hardware or driver bug. If unsure say N.

entry.name: MTD_MS02NV
entry.label: DEC MS02-NV NVRAM module support
entry.help:
This is an MTD driver for the DEC's MS02-NV (54-20948-01) battery backed-up NVRAM module. The module was originally meant as an NFS accelerator. Say Y here if you have a DECstation 5000/2x0 or a DECsystem 5900 equipped with such a module.
If you want to compile this driver as a module ( = code which can be inserted in and removed from the running kernel whenever you want), say M here and read <file:Documentation/kbuild/modules.txt>. The module will be called ms02-nv.

entry.name: MTD_DATAFLASH
entry.label: Support for AT45xxx DataFlash
entry.help: This enables access to AT45xxx DataFlash chips, using SPI. Sometimes DataFlash chips are packaged inside MMC-format cards; at this writing, the MMC stack won't handle those.

entry.name: MTD_DATAFLASH_WRITE_VERIFY
entry.label: Verify DataFlash page writes
entry.help: This adds an extra check when data is written to the flash. It may help if you are verifying chip setup (timings etc) on your board. There is a rare possibility that even though the device thinks the write was successful, a bit could have been flipped accidentally due to device wear or something else.

entry.name: MTD_DATAFLASH_OTP
entry.label: DataFlash OTP support (Security Register)
entry.help: Newer DataFlash chips (revisions C and D) support 128 bytes of one-time-programmable (OTP) data. The first half may be written (once) with up to 64 bytes of data, such as a serial number or other key product data. The second half is programmed with a unique-to-each-chip bit pattern at the factory.

entry.name: MTD_M25P80
entry.label: Support most SPI Flash chips (AT26DF, M25P, W25X, ...)
entry.help:
This enables access to most modern SPI flash chips, used for program and data storage. Series supported include Atmel AT26DF, Spansion S25SL, SST 25VF, ST M25P, and Winbond W25X. Other chips are supported as well. See the driver source for the current list, or to add other chips.
Note that the original DataFlash chips (AT45 series, not AT26DF), need an entirely different driver.
Set up your spi devices with the right board-specific platform data, if you want to specify device partitioning or to use a device which doesn't support the JEDEC ID instruction.

entry.name: MTD_SPEAR_SMI
entry.label: SPEAR MTD NOR Support through SMI controller
entry.help: This enable SNOR support on SPEAR platforms using SMI controller

entry.name: MTD_SST25L
entry.label: Support SST25L (non JEDEC) SPI Flash chips
entry.help:
This enables access to the non JEDEC SST25L SPI flash chips, used for program and data storage.
Set up your spi devices with the right board-specific platform data, if you want to specify device partitioning.

entry.name: MTD_BCM47XXSFLASH
entry.label: Support for serial flash on BCMA bus
entry.help: BCMA bus can have various flash memories attached, they are registered by bcma as platform devices. This enables driver for serial flash memories.

entry.name: MTD_SLRAM
entry.label: Uncached system RAM
entry.help: If your CPU cannot cache all of the physical memory in your machine, you can still use it for storage or swap by using this driver to present it to the system as a Memory Technology Device.

entry.name: MTD_PHRAM
entry.label: Physical system RAM
entry.help:
This is a re-implementation of the slram driver above.
Use this driver to access physical memory that the kernel proper doesn't have access to, memory beyond the mem=xxx limit, nvram, memory on the video card, etc...

entry.name: MTD_LART
entry.label: 28F160xx flash driver for LART

entry.name: MTD_MTDRAM
entry.label: Test driver using RAM
entry.help: This enables a test MTD device driver which uses vmalloc() to provide storage. You probably want to say 'N' unless you're testing stuff.

entry.name: MTDRAM_TOTAL_SIZE
entry.label: MTDRAM device size in KiB
entry.help: This allows you to configure the total size of the MTD device emulated by the MTDRAM driver. If the MTDRAM driver is built as a module, it is also possible to specify this as a parameter when loading the module.

entry.name: MTDRAM_ERASE_SIZE
entry.label: MTDRAM erase block size in KiB
entry.help: This allows you to configure the size of the erase blocks in the device emulated by the MTDRAM driver. If the MTDRAM driver is built as a module, it is also possible to specify this as a parameter when loading the module.

entry.name: MTD_BLOCK2MTD
entry.label: MTD using block device
entry.help:
This driver allows a block device to appear as an MTD. It would generally be used in the following cases:
Using Compact Flash as an MTD, these usually present themselves to the system as an ATA drive. Testing MTD users (eg JFFS2) on large media and media that might be removed during a write (using the floppy drive).

entry.name: MTD_POWERNV_FLASH
entry.label: powernv flash MTD driver
entry.help: This provides an MTD device to access flash on powernv OPAL platforms from Linux. This device abstracts away the firmware interface for flash access.

entry.name: MTD_DOCG3
entry.label: M-Systems Disk-On-Chip G3
entry.help:
This provides an MTD device driver for the M-Systems DiskOnChip G3 devices.
The driver provides access to G3 DiskOnChip, distributed by M-Systems and now Sandisk. The support is very experimental, and doesn't give access to any write operations.

entry.name: MTD_ST_SPI_FSM
entry.label: ST Microelectronics SPI FSM Serial Flash Controller
entry.help: This provides an MTD device driver for the ST Microelectronics SPI Fast Sequence Mode (FSM) Serial Flash Controller and support for a subset of connected Serial Flash devices.

entry.name: MTD_NAND_ECC_SMC
entry.label: NAND ECC Smart Media byte order
entry.help: Software ECC according to the Smart Media Specification. The original Linux implementation had byte 0 and 1 swapped.

entry.name: MTD_NAND
entry.label: NAND Device Support
entry.help: This enables support for accessing all type of NAND flash devices. For further information see <http://www.linux-mtd.infradead.org/doc/nand.html>.

entry.name: MTD_NAND_ECC_BCH
entry.label: Support software BCH ECC
entry.help: This enables support for software BCH error correction. Binary BCH codes are more powerful and cpu intensive than traditional Hamming ECC codes. They are used with NAND devices requiring more than 1 bit of error correction.

entry.name: MTD_NAND_DENALI_PCI
entry.label: Support Denali NAND controller on Intel Moorestown
entry.help: Enable the driver for NAND flash on Intel Moorestown, using the Denali NAND controller core.

entry.name: MTD_NAND_DENALI_DT
entry.label: Support Denali NAND controller as a DT device
entry.help: Enable the driver for NAND flash on platforms using a Denali NAND controller as a DT device.

entry.name: MTD_NAND_GPIO
entry.label: GPIO assisted NAND Flash driver
entry.help: This enables a NAND flash driver where control signals are connected to GPIO pins, and commands and data are communicated via a memory mapped interface.

entry.name: MTD_NAND_AMS_DELTA
entry.label: NAND Flash device on Amstrad E3
entry.help: Support for NAND flash on Amstrad E3 (Delta).

entry.name: MTD_NAND_OMAP2
entry.label: NAND Flash device on OMAP2, OMAP3 and OMAP4
entry.help: Support for NAND flash on Texas Instruments OMAP2, OMAP3 and OMAP4 platforms.

entry.name: MTD_NAND_OMAP_BCH
entry.label: Support hardware based BCH error correction
entry.help: This config enables the ELM hardware engine, which can be used to locate and correct errors when using BCH ECC scheme. This offloads the cpu from doing ECC error searching and correction. However some legacy OMAP families like OMAP2xxx, OMAP3xxx do not have ELM engine so this is optional for them.

entry.name: MTD_NAND_RICOH
entry.label: Ricoh xD card reader
entry.help: Enable support for Ricoh R5C852 xD card reader You also need to enable ether NAND SSFDC (SmartMedia) read only translation layer' or new expermental, readwrite 'SmartMedia/xD new translation layer'

entry.name: MTD_NAND_AU1550
entry.label: Au1550/1200 NAND support
entry.help: This enables the driver for the NAND flash controller on the AMD/Alchemy 1550 SOC.

entry.name: MTD_NAND_BF5XX
entry.label: Blackfin on-chip NAND Flash Controller driver
entry.help:
This enables the Blackfin on-chip NAND flash controller
No board specific support is done by this driver, each board must advertise a platform_device for the driver to attach.
This driver can also be built as a module. If so, the module will be called bf5xx-nand.

entry.name: MTD_NAND_BF5XX_HWECC
entry.label: BF5XX NAND Hardware ECC
entry.help: Enable the use of the BF5XX's internal ECC generator when using NAND.

entry.name: MTD_NAND_BF5XX_BOOTROM_ECC
entry.label: Use Blackfin BootROM ECC Layout
entry.help:
If you wish to modify NAND pages and allow the Blackfin on-chip BootROM to boot from them, say Y here. This is only necessary if you are booting U-Boot out of NAND and you wish to update U-Boot from Linux' userspace. Otherwise, you should say N here.
If unsure, say N.

entry.name: MTD_NAND_S3C2410
entry.label: NAND Flash support for Samsung S3C SoCs
entry.help:
This enables the NAND flash controller on the S3C24xx and S3C64xx SoCs
No board specific support is done by this driver, each board must advertise a platform_device for the driver to attach.

entry.name: MTD_NAND_S3C2410_DEBUG
entry.label: Samsung S3C NAND driver debug
entry.help: Enable debugging of the S3C NAND driver

entry.name: MTD_NAND_S3C2410_HWECC
entry.label: Samsung S3C NAND Hardware ECC
entry.help: Enable the use of the controller's internal ECC generator when using NAND. Early versions of the chips have had problems with incorrect ECC generation, and if using these, the default of software ECC is preferable.

entry.name: MTD_NAND_NDFC
entry.label: NDFC NanD Flash Controller
entry.help: NDFC Nand Flash Controllers are integrated in IBM/AMCC's 4xx SoCs

entry.name: MTD_NAND_S3C2410_CLKSTOP
entry.label: Samsung S3C NAND IDLE clock stop
entry.help: Stop the clock to the NAND controller when there is no chip selected to save power. This will mean there is a small delay when the is NAND chip selected or released, but will save approximately 5mA of power when there is nothing happening.

entry.name: MTD_NAND_DISKONCHIP
entry.label: DiskOnChip 2000, Millennium and Millennium Plus (NAND reimplementation)
entry.help: This is a reimplementation of M-Systems DiskOnChip 2000, Millennium and Millennium Plus as a standard NAND device driver, as opposed to the earlier self-contained MTD device drivers. This should enable, among other things, proper JFFS2 operation on these devices.

entry.name: MTD_NAND_DISKONCHIP_PROBE_ADVANCED
entry.label: Advanced detection options for DiskOnChip
entry.help: This option allows you to specify nonstandard address at which to probe for a DiskOnChip, or to change the detection options. You are unlikely to need any of this unless you are using LinuxBIOS. Say 'N'.

entry.name: MTD_NAND_DISKONCHIP_PROBE_HIGH
entry.label: Probe high addresses
entry.help: By default, the probe for DiskOnChip devices will look for a DiskOnChip at every multiple of 0x2000 between 0xC8000 and 0xEE000. This option changes to make it probe between 0xFFFC8000 and 0xFFFEE000. Unless you are using LinuxBIOS, this is unlikely to be useful to you. Say 'N'.

entry.name: MTD_NAND_DISKONCHIP_BBTWRITE
entry.label: Allow BBT writes on DiskOnChip Millennium and 2000TSOP
entry.help: On DiskOnChip devices shipped with the INFTL filesystem (Millennium and 2000 TSOP/Alon), Linux reserves some space at the end of the device for the Bad Block Table (BBT). If you have existing INFTL data on your device (created by non-Linux tools such as M-Systems' DOS drivers), your data might overlap the area Linux wants to use for the BBT. If this is a concern for you, leave this option disabled and Linux will not write BBT data into this area. The downside of leaving this option disabled is that if bad blocks are detected by Linux, they will not be recorded in the BBT, which could cause future problems. Once you enable this option, new filesystems (INFTL or others, created in Linux or other operating systems) will not use the reserved area. The only reason not to enable this option is to prevent damage to preexisting filesystems. Even if you leave this disabled, you can enable BBT writes at module load time (assuming you build diskonchip as a module) with the module parameter "inftl_bbt_write=1".

entry.name: MTD_NAND_DOCG4
entry.label: Support for DiskOnChip G4
entry.help:
Support for diskonchip G4 nand flash, found in various smartphones and PDAs, among them the Palm Treo680, HTC Prophet and Wizard, Toshiba Portege G900, Asus P526, and O2 XDA Zinc.
With this driver you will be able to use UBI and create a ubifs on the device, so you may wish to consider enabling UBI and UBIFS as well.
These devices ship with the Mys/Sandisk SAFTL formatting, for which there is currently no mtd parser, so you may want to use command line partitioning to segregate write-protected blocks. On the Treo680, the first five erase blocks (256KiB each) are write-protected, followed by the block containing the saftl partition table. This is probably typical.

entry.name: MTD_NAND_SHARPSL
entry.label: Support for NAND Flash on Sharp SL Series (C7xx + others)

entry.name: MTD_NAND_CAFE
entry.label: NAND support for OLPC CAF chip
entry.help: Use NAND flash attached to the CAF chip designed for the OLPC laptop.

entry.name: MTD_NAND_CS553X
entry.label: NAND support for CS5535/CS5536 (AMD Geode companion chip)
entry.help:
The CS553x companion chips for the AMD Geode processor include NAND flash controllers with built-in hardware ECC capabilities; enabling this option will allow you to use these. The driver will check the MSRs to verify that the controller is enabled for NAND, and currently requires that the controller be in MMIO mode.
If you say "m", the module will be called cs553x_nand.

entry.name: MTD_NAND_ATMEL
entry.label: Support for NAND Flash / SmartMedia on AT91 and AVR32
entry.help: Enables support for NAND Flash / Smart Media Card interface on Atmel AT91 and AVR32 processors.

entry.name: MTD_NAND_PXA3xx
entry.label: NAND support on PXA3xx and Armada 370/XP
entry.help: This enables the driver for the NAND flash device found on PXA3xx processors (NFCv1) and also on Armada 370/XP (NFCv2).

entry.name: MTD_NAND_SLC_LPC32XX
entry.label: NXP LPC32xx SLC Controller
entry.help:
Enables support for NXP's LPC32XX SLC (i.e. for Single Level Cell chips) NAND controller. This is the default for the PHYTEC 3250 reference board which contains a NAND256R3A2CZA6 chip.
Please check the actual NAND chip connected and its support by the SLC NAND controller.

entry.name: MTD_NAND_MLC_LPC32XX
entry.label: NXP LPC32xx MLC Controller
entry.help:
Uses the LPC32XX MLC (i.e. for Multi Level Cell chips) NAND controller. This is the default for the WORK92105 controller board.
Please check the actual NAND chip connected and its support by the MLC NAND controller.

entry.name: MTD_NAND_CM_X270
entry.label: Support for NAND Flash on CM-X270 modules

entry.name: MTD_NAND_PASEMI
entry.label: NAND support for PA Semi PWRficient
entry.help: Enables support for NAND Flash interface on PA Semi PWRficient based boards

entry.name: MTD_NAND_TMIO
entry.label: NAND Flash device on Toshiba Mobile IO Controller
entry.help: Support for NAND flash connected to a Toshiba Mobile IO Controller in some PDAs, including the Sharp SL6000x.

entry.name: MTD_NAND_NANDSIM
entry.label: Support for NAND Flash Simulator
entry.help: The simulator may simulate various NAND flash chips for the MTD nand layer.

entry.name: MTD_NAND_GPMI_NAND
entry.label: GPMI NAND Flash Controller driver
entry.help: Enables NAND Flash support for IMX23, IMX28 or IMX6. The GPMI controller is very powerful, with the help of BCH module, it can do the hardware ECC. The GPMI supports several NAND flashs at the same time. The GPMI may conflicts with other block, such as SD card. So pay attention to it when you enable the GPMI.

entry.name: MTD_NAND_BRCMNAND
entry.label: Broadcom STB NAND controller
entry.help: Enables the Broadcom NAND controller driver. The controller was originally designed for Set-Top Box but is used on various BCM7xxx, BCM3xxx, BCM63xxx, iProc/Cygnus and more.

entry.name: MTD_NAND_BCM47XXNFLASH
entry.label: Support for NAND flash on BCM4706 BCMA bus
entry.help: BCMA bus can have various flash memories attached, they are registered by bcma as platform devices. This enables driver for NAND flash memories. For now only BCM4706 is supported.

entry.name: MTD_NAND_PLATFORM
entry.label: Support for generic platform NAND driver
entry.help: This implements a generic NAND driver for on-SOC platform devices. You will need to provide platform-specific functions via platform_data.

entry.name: MTD_NAND_ORION
entry.label: NAND Flash support for Marvell Orion SoC
entry.help:
This enables the NAND flash controller on Orion machines.
No board specific support is done by this driver, each board must advertise a platform_device for the driver to attach.

entry.name: MTD_NAND_FSL_ELBC
entry.label: NAND support for Freescale eLBC controllers
entry.help: Various Freescale chips, including the 8313, include a NAND Flash Controller Module with built-in hardware ECC capabilities. Enabling this option will enable you to use this to control external NAND devices.

entry.name: MTD_NAND_FSL_IFC
entry.label: NAND support for Freescale IFC controller
entry.help: Various Freescale chips e.g P1010, include a NAND Flash machine with built-in hardware ECC capabilities. Enabling this option will enable you to use this to control external NAND devices.

entry.name: MTD_NAND_FSL_UPM
entry.label: Support for NAND on Freescale UPM
entry.help: Enables support for NAND Flash chips wired onto Freescale PowerPC processor localbus with User-Programmable Machine support.

entry.name: MTD_NAND_MPC5121_NFC
entry.label: MPC5121 built-in NAND Flash Controller support
entry.help: This enables the driver for the NAND flash controller on the MPC5121 SoC.

entry.name: MTD_NAND_VF610_NFC
entry.label: Support for Freescale NFC for VF610/MPC5125
entry.help: Enables support for NAND Flash Controller on some Freescale processors like the VF610, MPC5125, MCF54418 or Kinetis K70. The driver supports a maximum 2k page size. With 2k pages and 64 bytes or more of OOB, hardware ECC with up to 32-bit error correction is supported. Hardware ECC is only enabled through device tree.

entry.name: MTD_NAND_MXC
entry.label: MXC NAND support
entry.help: This enables the driver for the NAND flash controller on the MXC processors.

entry.name: MTD_NAND_SH_FLCTL
entry.label: Support for NAND on Renesas SuperH FLCTL
entry.help: Several Renesas SuperH CPU has FLCTL. This option enables support for NAND Flash using FLCTL.

entry.name: MTD_NAND_DAVINCI
entry.label: Support NAND on DaVinci/Keystone SoC
entry.help: Enable the driver for NAND flash chips on Texas Instruments DaVinci/Keystone processors.

entry.name: MTD_NAND_TXX9NDFMC
entry.label: NAND Flash support for TXx9 SoC
entry.help: This enables the NAND flash controller on the TXx9 SoCs.

entry.name: MTD_NAND_SOCRATES
entry.label: Support for NAND on Socrates board
entry.help: Enables support for NAND Flash chips wired onto Socrates board.

entry.name: MTD_NAND_NUC900
entry.label: Support for NAND on Nuvoton NUC9xx/w90p910 evaluation boards.
entry.help: This enables the driver for the NAND Flash on evaluation board based on w90p910 / NUC9xx.

entry.name: MTD_NAND_JZ4740
entry.label: Support for JZ4740 SoC NAND controller
entry.help: Enables support for NAND Flash on JZ4740 SoC based boards.

entry.name: MTD_NAND_JZ4780
entry.label: Support for NAND on JZ4780 SoC
entry.help: Enables support for NAND Flash connected to the NEMC on JZ4780 SoC based boards, using the BCH controller for hardware error correction.

entry.name: MTD_NAND_FSMC
entry.label: Support for NAND on ST Micros FSMC
entry.help: Enables support for NAND Flash chips on the ST Microelectronics Flexible Static Memory Controller (FSMC)

entry.name: MTD_NAND_XWAY
entry.label: Support for NAND on Lantiq XWAY SoC
entry.help: Enables support for NAND Flash chips on Lantiq XWAY SoCs. NAND is attached to the External Bus Unit (EBU).

entry.name: MTD_NAND_SUNXI
entry.label: Support for NAND on Allwinner SoCs
entry.help: Enables support for NAND Flash chips on Allwinner SoCs.

entry.name: MTD_NAND_HISI504
entry.label: Support for NAND controller on Hisilicon SoC Hip04
entry.help: Enables support for NAND controller on Hisilicon SoC Hip04.

entry.name: MTD_NAND_QCOM
entry.label: Support for NAND on QCOM SoCs
entry.help: Enables support for NAND flash chips on SoCs containing the EBI2 NAND controller. This controller is found on IPQ806x SoC.

entry.name: MTD_NAND_MTK
entry.label: Support for NAND controller on MTK SoCs
entry.help: Enables support for NAND controller on MTK SoCs. This controller is found on mt27xx, mt81xx, mt65xx SoCs.

entry.name: MTD_ONENAND
entry.label: OneNAND Device Support
entry.help: This enables support for accessing all type of OneNAND flash devices. For further information see <http://www.samsung.com/Products/Semiconductor/OneNAND/index.htm>

entry.name: MTD_ONENAND_VERIFY_WRITE
entry.label: Verify OneNAND page writes
entry.help: This adds an extra check when data is written to the flash. The OneNAND flash device internally checks only bits transitioning from 1 to 0. There is a rare possibility that even though the device thinks the write was successful, a bit could have been flipped accidentally due to device wear or something else.

entry.name: MTD_ONENAND_GENERIC
entry.label: OneNAND Flash device via platform device driver
entry.help: Support for OneNAND flash via platform device driver.

entry.name: MTD_ONENAND_OMAP2
entry.label: OneNAND on OMAP2/OMAP3 support
entry.help: Support for a OneNAND flash device connected to an OMAP2/OMAP3 CPU via the GPMC memory controller.

entry.name: MTD_ONENAND_SAMSUNG
entry.label: OneNAND on Samsung SOC controller support
entry.help: Support for a OneNAND flash device connected to an Samsung SOC. S3C64XX uses command mapping method. S5PC110/S5PC210 use generic OneNAND method.

entry.name: MTD_ONENAND_OTP
entry.label: OneNAND OTP Support
entry.help:
One Block of the NAND Flash Array memory is reserved as a One-Time Programmable Block memory area. Also, 1st Block of NAND Flash Array can be used as OTP.
