entry.name: SCSI_PPA
entry.label: IOMEGA parallel port (ppa - older drives)
entry.help:
This driver supports older versions of IOMEGA's parallel port ZIP drive (a 100 MB removable media device).
Note that you can say N here if you have the SCSI version of the ZIP drive: it will be supported automatically if you said Y to the generic "SCSI disk support", above.
If you have the ZIP Plus drive or a more recent parallel port ZIP drive (if the supplied cable with the drive is labeled "AutoDetect") then you should say N here and Y to "IOMEGA parallel port (imm - newer drives)", below.
For more information about this driver and how to use it you should read the file <file:Documentation/scsi/ppa.txt>. You should also read the SCSI-HOWTO, which is available from <http://www.tldp.org/docs.html#howto>. If you use this driver, you will still be able to use the parallel port for other tasks, such as a printer; it is safe to compile both drivers into the kernel.
To compile this driver as a module, choose M here: the module will be called ppa.

entry.name: SCSI_IMM
entry.label: IOMEGA parallel port (imm - newer drives)
entry.help:
This driver supports newer versions of IOMEGA's parallel port ZIP drive (a 100 MB removable media device).
Note that you can say N here if you have the SCSI version of the ZIP drive: it will be supported automatically if you said Y to the generic "SCSI disk support", above.
If you have the ZIP Plus drive or a more recent parallel port ZIP drive (if the supplied cable with the drive is labeled "AutoDetect") then you should say Y here; if you have an older ZIP drive, say N here and Y to "IOMEGA Parallel Port (ppa - older drives)", above.
For more information about this driver and how to use it you should read the file <file:Documentation/scsi/ppa.txt>. You should also read the SCSI-HOWTO, which is available from <http://www.tldp.org/docs.html#howto>. If you use this driver, you will still be able to use the parallel port for other tasks, such as a printer; it is safe to compile both drivers into the kernel.
To compile this driver as a module, choose M here: the module will be called imm.

entry.name: SCSI_IZIP_EPP16
entry.label: ppa/imm option - Use slow (but safe) EPP-16
entry.help:
EPP (Enhanced Parallel Port) is a standard for parallel ports which allows them to act as expansion buses that can handle up to 64 peripheral devices.
Some parallel port chipsets are slower than their motherboard, and so we have to control the state of the chipset's FIFO queue every now and then to avoid data loss. This will be done if you say Y here.
Generally, saying Y is the safe option and slows things down a bit.

entry.name: SCSI_IZIP_SLOW_CTR
entry.label: ppa/imm option - Assume slow parport control register
entry.help:
Some parallel ports are known to have excessive delays between changing the parallel port control register and good data being available on the parallel port data/status register. This option forces a small delay (1.0 usec to be exact) after changing the control register to let things settle out. Enabling this option may result in a big drop in performance but some very old parallel ports (found in 386 vintage machines) will not work properly.
Generally, saying N is fine.

entry.name: SCSI_NCR53C406A
entry.label: NCR53c406a SCSI support
entry.help:
This is support for the NCR53c406a SCSI host adapter. For user configurable parameters, check out <file:drivers/scsi/NCR53c406a.c> in the kernel source. Also read the SCSI-HOWTO, available from <http://www.tldp.org/docs.html#howto>.
To compile this driver as a module, choose M here: the module will be called NCR53c406.

entry.name: SCSI_NCR_D700
entry.label: NCR Dual 700 MCA SCSI support
entry.help:
This is a driver for the MicroChannel Dual 700 card produced by NCR and commonly used in 345x/35xx/4100 class machines. It always tries to negotiate sync and uses tag command queueing.
Unless you have an NCR manufactured machine, the chances are that you do not have this SCSI card, so say N.

entry.name: SCSI_LASI700
entry.label: HP Lasi SCSI support for 53c700/710
entry.help: This is a driver for the SCSI controller in the Lasi chip found in many PA-RISC workstations & servers. If you do not know whether you have a Lasi chip, it is safe to say "Y" here.

entry.name: SCSI_SNI_53C710
entry.label: SNI RM SCSI support for 53c710
entry.help: This is a driver for the onboard SCSI controller found in older SNI RM workstations & servers.

entry.name: SCSI_STEX
entry.label: Promise SuperTrak EX Series support
entry.help:
This driver supports Promise SuperTrak EX series storage controllers.
Promise provides Linux RAID configuration utility for these controllers. Please visit <http://www.promise.com> to download.
To compile this driver as a module, choose M here: the module will be called stex.

entry.name: SCSI_SYM53C8XX_2
entry.label: SYM53C8XX Version 2 SCSI support
entry.help:
This driver supports the whole NCR53C8XX/SYM53C8XX family of PCI-SCSI controllers. It also supports the subset of LSI53C10XX Ultra-160 controllers that are based on the SYM53C8XX SCRIPTS language. It does not support LSI53C10XX Ultra-320 PCI-X SCSI controllers; you need to use the Fusion MPT driver for that.
Please read <file:Documentation/scsi/sym53c8xx_2.txt> for more information.

entry.name: SCSI_SYM53C8XX_DMA_ADDRESSING_MODE
entry.label: DMA addressing mode
entry.help:
This option only applies to PCI-SCSI chips that are PCI DAC capable (875A, 895A, 896, 1010-33, 1010-66, 1000).
When set to 0, the driver will program the chip to only perform 32-bit DMA. When set to 1, the chip will be able to perform DMA to addresses up to 1TB. When set to 2, the driver supports the full 64-bit DMA address range, but can only address 16 segments of 4 GB each. This limits the total addressable range to 64 GB.
Most machines with less than 4GB of memory should use a setting of 0 for best performance. If your machine has 4GB of memory or more, you should set this option to 1 (the default).
The still experimental value 2 (64 bit DMA addressing with 16 x 4GB segments limitation) can be used on systems that require PCI address bits past bit 39 to be set for the addressing of memory using PCI DAC cycles.

entry.name: SCSI_SYM53C8XX_DEFAULT_TAGS
entry.label: Default tagged command queue depth
entry.help: This is the default value of the command queue depth the driver will announce to the generic SCSI layer for devices that support tagged command queueing. This value can be changed from the boot command line. This is a soft limit that cannot exceed CONFIG_SCSI_SYM53C8XX_MAX_TAGS.

entry.name: SCSI_SYM53C8XX_MAX_TAGS
entry.label: Maximum number of queued commands
entry.help: This option allows you to specify the maximum number of commands that can be queued to any device, when tagged command queuing is possible. The driver supports up to 256 queued commands per device. This value is used as a compiled-in hard limit.

entry.name: SCSI_SYM53C8XX_MMIO
entry.label: Use memory mapped IO
entry.help: Memory mapped IO is faster than Port IO. Most people should answer Y here, but some machines may have problems. If you have to answer N here, please report the problem to the maintainer.

entry.name: SCSI_IPR
entry.label: IBM Power Linux RAID adapter support
entry.help: This driver supports the IBM Power Linux family RAID adapters. This includes IBM pSeries 5712, 5703, 5709, and 570A, as well as IBM iSeries 5702, 5703, 5709, and 570A.

entry.name: SCSI_IPR_TRACE
entry.label: enable driver internal trace
entry.help: If you say Y here, the driver will trace all commands issued to the adapter. Performance impact is minimal. Trace can be dumped using /sys/bus/class/scsi_host/hostXX/trace.

entry.name: SCSI_IPR_DUMP
entry.label: enable adapter dump support
entry.help: If you say Y here, the driver will support adapter crash dump. If you enable this support, the iprdump daemon can be used to capture adapter failure analysis information.

entry.name: SCSI_ZALON
entry.label: Zalon SCSI support
entry.help: The Zalon is a GSC/HSC bus interface chip that sits between the PA-RISC processor and the NCR 53c720 SCSI controller on C100, C110, J200, J210 and some D, K & R-class machines. It's also used on the add-in Bluefish, Barracuda & Shrike SCSI cards. Say Y here if you have one of these machines or cards.

entry.name: SCSI_NCR_Q720
entry.label: NCR Quad 720 MCA SCSI support
entry.help:
This is a driver for the MicroChannel Quad 720 card produced by NCR and commonly used in 345x/35xx/4100 class machines. It always tries to negotiate sync and uses tag command queueing.
Unless you have an NCR manufactured machine, the chances are that you do not have this SCSI card, so say N.

entry.name: SCSI_NCR53C8XX_DEFAULT_TAGS
entry.label: default tagged command queue depth
entry.help:
"Tagged command queuing" is a feature of SCSI-2 which improves performance: the host adapter can send several SCSI commands to a device's queue even if previous commands haven't finished yet. Because the device is intelligent, it can optimize its operations (like head positioning) based on its own request queue. Some SCSI devices don't implement this properly; if you want to disable this feature, enter 0 or 1 here (it doesn't matter which).
The default value is 8 and should be supported by most hard disks. This value can be overridden from the boot command line using the 'tags' option as follows (example): 'ncr53c8xx=tags:4/t2t3q16/t0u2q10' will set default queue depth to 4, set queue depth to 16 for target 2 and target 3 on controller 0 and set queue depth to 10 for target 0 / lun 2 on controller 1.
The normal answer therefore is to go with the default 8 and to use a boot command line option for devices that need to use a different command queue depth.
There is no safe option other than using good SCSI devices.

entry.name: SCSI_NCR53C8XX_MAX_TAGS
entry.label: maximum number of queued commands
entry.help:
This option allows you to specify the maximum number of commands that can be queued to any device, when tagged command queuing is possible. The default value is 32. Minimum is 2, maximum is 64. Modern hard disks are able to support 64 tags and even more, but do not seem to be faster when more than 32 tags are being used.
So, the normal answer here is to go with the default value 32 unless you are using very large hard disks with large cache (>= 1 MB) that are able to take advantage of more than 32 tagged commands.
There is no safe option and the default answer is recommended.

entry.name: SCSI_NCR53C8XX_SYNC
entry.label: synchronous transfers frequency in MHz
entry.help:
The SCSI Parallel Interface-2 Standard defines 5 classes of transfer rates: FAST-5, FAST-10, FAST-20, FAST-40 and FAST-80. The numbers are respectively the maximum data transfer rates in mega-transfers per second for each class. For example, a FAST-20 Wide 16 device is able to transfer data at 20 million 16 bit packets per second for a total rate of 40 MB/s.
You may specify 0 if you want to only use asynchronous data transfers. This is the safest and slowest option. Otherwise, specify a value between 5 and 80, depending on the capability of your SCSI controller. The higher the number, the faster the data transfer. Note that 80 should normally be ok since the driver decreases the value automatically according to the controller's capabilities.
Your answer to this question is ignored for controllers with NVRAM, since the driver will get this information from the user set-up. It also can be overridden using a boot setup option, as follows (example): 'ncr53c8xx=sync:12' will allow the driver to negotiate for FAST-20 synchronous data transfer (20 mega-transfers per second).
The normal answer therefore is not to go with the default but to select the maximum value 80 allowing the driver to use the maximum value supported by each controller. If this causes problems with your SCSI devices, you should come back and decrease the value.
There is no safe option other than using good cabling, right terminations and SCSI conformant devices.

entry.name: SCSI_NCR53C8XX_NO_DISCONNECT
entry.label: not allow targets to disconnect
entry.help: This option is only provided for safety if you suspect some SCSI device of yours to not support properly the target-disconnect feature. In that case, you would say Y here. In general however, to not allow targets to disconnect is not reasonable if there is more than 1 device on a SCSI bus. The normal answer therefore is N.

entry.name: SCSI_PAS16
entry.label: PAS16 SCSI support
entry.help:
This is support for a SCSI host adapter. It is explained in section 3.10 of the SCSI-HOWTO, available from <http://www.tldp.org/docs.html#howto>. If it doesn't work out of the box, you may have to change some settings in <file:drivers/scsi/pas16.h>.
To compile this driver as a module, choose M here: the module will be called pas16.

entry.name: SCSI_QLOGIC_FAS
entry.label: Qlogic FAS SCSI support
entry.help:
This is a driver for the ISA, VLB, and PCMCIA versions of the Qlogic FastSCSI! cards as well as any other card based on the FASXX chip (including the Control Concepts SCSI/IDE/SIO/PIO/FDC cards).
This driver does NOT support the PCI versions of these cards. The PCI versions are supported by the Qlogic ISP driver ("Qlogic ISP SCSI support"), below.
Information about this driver is contained in <file:Documentation/scsi/qlogicfas.txt>. You should also read the SCSI-HOWTO, available from <http://www.tldp.org/docs.html#howto>.
To compile this driver as a module, choose M here: the module will be called qlogicfas.

entry.name: SCSI_QLOGIC_1280
entry.label: Qlogic QLA 1240/1x80/1x160 SCSI support
entry.help:
Say Y if you have a QLogic ISP1240/1x80/1x160 SCSI host adapter.
To compile this driver as a module, choose M here: the module will be called qla1280.

entry.name: SCSI_QLOGICPTI
entry.label: PTI Qlogic, ISP Driver
entry.help:
This driver supports SBUS SCSI controllers from PTI or QLogic. These controllers are known under Solaris as qpti and in the openprom as PTI,ptisp or QLGC,isp. Note that PCI QLogic SCSI controllers are driven by a different driver.
To compile this driver as a module, choose M here: the module will be called qlogicpti.

entry.name: SCSI_QLA_FC
entry.label: QLogic QLA2XXX Fibre Channel Support
entry.help:
This qla2xxx driver supports all QLogic Fibre Channel PCI and PCIe host adapters.
By default, firmware for the ISP parts will be loaded via the Firmware Loader interface.
ISP Firmware Filename ---------- ----------------- 21xx ql2100_fw.bin 22xx ql2200_fw.bin 2300, 2312, 6312 ql2300_fw.bin 2322, 6322 ql2322_fw.bin 24xx, 54xx ql2400_fw.bin 25xx ql2500_fw.bin
Upon request, the driver caches the firmware image until the driver is unloaded.
Firmware images can be retrieved from:
http://ldriver.qlogic.com/firmware/
They are also included in the linux-firmware tree as well.

entry.name: TCM_QLA2XXX
entry.label: TCM_QLA2XXX fabric module for QLogic 24xx+ series target mode HBAs
entry.help: Say Y here to enable the TCM_QLA2XXX fabric module for QLogic 24xx+ series target mode HBAs

entry.name: TCM_QLA2XXX_DEBUG
entry.label: TCM_QLA2XXX fabric module DEBUG mode for QLogic 24xx+ series target mode HBAs
entry.help: Say Y here to enable the TCM_QLA2XXX fabric module DEBUG for QLogic 24xx+ series target mode HBAs This will include code to enable the SCSI command jammer

entry.name: SCSI_QLA_ISCSI
entry.label: QLogic ISP4XXX and ISP82XX host adapter family support
entry.help: This driver supports the QLogic 40xx (ISP4XXX), 8022 (ISP82XX) and 8032 (ISP83XX) iSCSI host adapter family.

entry.name: SCSI_LPFC
entry.label: Emulex LightPulse Fibre Channel Support
entry.help: This lpfc driver supports the Emulex LightPulse Family of Fibre Channel PCI host adapters.

entry.name: SCSI_LPFC_DEBUG_FS
entry.label: Emulex LightPulse Fibre Channel debugfs Support
entry.help: This makes debugging information from the lpfc driver available via the debugfs filesystem.

entry.name: SCSI_SIM710
entry.label: Simple 53c710 SCSI support (Compaq, NCR machines)
entry.help:
This driver is for NCR53c710 based SCSI host adapters.
It currently supports Compaq EISA cards and NCR MCA cards

entry.name: SCSI_SYM53C416
entry.label: Symbios 53c416 SCSI support
entry.help:
This is support for the sym53c416 SCSI host adapter, the SCSI adapter that comes with some HP scanners. This driver requires that the sym53c416 is configured first using some sort of PnP configuration program (e.g. isapnp) or by a PnP aware BIOS. If you are using isapnp then you need to compile this driver as a module and then load it using insmod after isapnp has run. The parameters of the configured card(s) should be passed to the driver. The format is:
insmod sym53c416 sym53c416=<base>,<irq> [sym53c416_1=<base>,<irq>]
To compile this driver as a module, choose M here: the module will be called sym53c416.

entry.name: SCSI_DC395x
entry.label: Tekram DC395(U/UW/F) and DC315(U) SCSI support
entry.help:
This driver supports PCI SCSI host adapters based on the ASIC TRM-S1040 chip, e.g Tekram DC395(U/UW/F) and DC315(U) variants.
This driver works, but is still in experimental status. So better have a bootable disk and a backup in case of emergency.
Documentation can be found in <file:Documentation/scsi/dc395x.txt>.
To compile this driver as a module, choose M here: the module will be called dc395x.

entry.name: SCSI_AM53C974
entry.label: Tekram DC390(T) and Am53/79C974 SCSI support (new driver)
entry.help:
This driver supports PCI SCSI host adapters based on the Am53C974A chip, e.g. Tekram DC390(T), DawiControl 2974 and some onboard PCscsi/PCnet (Am53/79C974) solutions. This is a new implementation base on the generic esp_scsi driver.
Documentation can be found in <file:Documentation/scsi/tmscsim.txt>.
Note that this driver does NOT support Tekram DC390W/U/F, which are based on NCR/Symbios chips. Use "NCR53C8XX SCSI support" for those.
To compile this driver as a module, choose M here: the module will be called am53c974.

entry.name: SCSI_T128
entry.label: Trantor T128/T128F/T228 SCSI support
entry.help:
This is support for a SCSI host adapter. It is explained in section 3.11 of the SCSI-HOWTO, available from <http://www.tldp.org/docs.html#howto>. If it doesn't work out of the box, you may have to change some settings in <file:drivers/scsi/t128.h>. Note that Trantor was purchased by Adaptec, and some former Trantor products are being sold under the Adaptec name.
To compile this driver as a module, choose M here: the module will be called t128.

entry.name: SCSI_U14_34F
entry.label: UltraStor 14F/34F support
entry.help:
This is support for the UltraStor 14F and 34F SCSI-2 host adapters. The source at <file:drivers/scsi/u14-34f.c> contains some information about this hardware. If the driver doesn't work out of the box, you may have to change some settings in <file: drivers/scsi/u14-34f.c>. Read the SCSI-HOWTO, available from <http://www.tldp.org/docs.html#howto>. Note that there is also another driver for the same hardware: "UltraStor SCSI support", below. You should say Y to both only if you want 24F support as well.
To compile this driver as a module, choose M here: the module will be called u14-34f.

entry.name: SCSI_U14_34F_TAGGED_QUEUE
entry.label: enable tagged command queueing
entry.help: This is a feature of SCSI-2 which improves performance: the host adapter can send several SCSI commands to a device's queue even if previous commands haven't finished yet. This is equivalent to the "u14-34f=tc:y" boot option.

entry.name: SCSI_U14_34F_LINKED_COMMANDS
entry.label: enable elevator sorting
entry.help: This option enables elevator sorting for all probed SCSI disks and CD-ROMs. It definitely reduces the average seek distance when doing random seeks, but this does not necessarily result in a noticeable performance improvement: your mileage may vary... This is equivalent to the "u14-34f=lc:y" boot option.

entry.name: SCSI_U14_34F_MAX_TAGS
entry.label: maximum number of queued commands
entry.help: This specifies how many SCSI commands can be maximally queued for each probed SCSI device. You should reduce the default value of 8 only if you have disks with buggy or limited tagged command support. Minimum is 2 and maximum is 14. This value is also the window size used by the elevator sorting option above. The effective value used by the driver for each probed SCSI device is reported at boot time. This is equivalent to the "u14-34f=mq:8" boot option.

entry.name: SCSI_ULTRASTOR
entry.label: UltraStor SCSI support
entry.help:
This is support for the UltraStor 14F, 24F and 34F SCSI-2 host adapter family. This driver is explained in section 3.12 of the SCSI-HOWTO, available from <http://www.tldp.org/docs.html#howto>. If it doesn't work out of the box, you may have to change some settings in <file:drivers/scsi/ultrastor.h>.
Note that there is also another driver for the same hardware: "UltraStor 14F/34F support", above.
To compile this driver as a module, choose M here: the module will be called ultrastor.

entry.name: SCSI_NSP32
entry.label: Workbit NinjaSCSI-32Bi/UDE support
entry.help:
This is support for the Workbit NinjaSCSI-32Bi/UDE PCI/Cardbus SCSI host adapter. Please read the SCSI-HOWTO, available from <http://www.tldp.org/docs.html#howto>.
To compile this driver as a module, choose M here: the module will be called nsp32.

entry.name: SCSI_WD719X
entry.label: Western Digital WD7193/7197/7296 support
entry.help: This is a driver for Western Digital WD7193, WD7197 and WD7296 PCI SCSI controllers (based on WD33C296A chip).

entry.name: SCSI_DEBUG
entry.label: SCSI debugging host and device simulator
entry.help: This pseudo driver simulates one or more hosts (SCSI initiators), each with one or more targets, each with one or more logical units. Defaults to one of each, creating a small RAM disk device. Many parameters found in the /sys/bus/pseudo/drivers/scsi_debug directory can be tweaked at run time. See <http://sg.danny.cz/sg/sdebug26.html> for more information. Mainly used for testing and best as a module. If unsure, say N.

entry.name: SCSI_MESH
entry.label: MESH (Power Mac internal SCSI) support
entry.help:
Many Power Macintoshes and clones have a MESH (Macintosh Enhanced SCSI Hardware) SCSI bus adaptor (the 7200 doesn't, but all of the other Power Macintoshes do). Say Y to include support for this SCSI adaptor.
To compile this driver as a module, choose M here: the module will be called mesh.

entry.name: SCSI_MESH_SYNC_RATE
entry.label: maximum synchronous transfer rate (MB/s) (0 = async)
entry.help: On Power Macintoshes (and clones) where the MESH SCSI bus adaptor drives a bus which is entirely internal to the machine (such as the 7500, 7600, 8500, etc.), the MESH is capable of synchronous operation at up to 10 MB/s. On machines where the SCSI bus controlled by the MESH can have external devices connected, it is usually rated at 5 MB/s. 5 is a safe value here unless you know the MESH SCSI bus is internal only; in that case you can say 10. Say 0 to disable synchronous operation.

entry.name: SCSI_MESH_RESET_DELAY_MS
entry.label: initial bus reset delay (ms) (0 = no reset)

entry.name: SCSI_MAC53C94
entry.label: 53C94 (Power Mac external SCSI) support
entry.help:
On Power Macintoshes (and clones) with two SCSI buses, the external SCSI bus is usually controlled by a 53C94 SCSI bus adaptor. Older machines which only have one SCSI bus, such as the 7200, also use the 53C94. Say Y to include support for the 53C94.
To compile this driver as a module, choose M here: the module will be called mac53c94.

entry.name: SCSI_ACORNSCSI_3
entry.label: Acorn SCSI card (aka30) support
entry.help: This enables support for the Acorn SCSI card (aka30). If you have an Acorn system with one of these, say Y. If unsure, say N.

entry.name: SCSI_ACORNSCSI_TAGGED_QUEUE
entry.label: Support SCSI 2 Tagged queueing
entry.help:
Say Y here to enable tagged queuing support on the Acorn SCSI card.
This is a feature of SCSI-2 which improves performance: the host adapter can send several SCSI commands to a device's queue even if previous commands haven't finished yet. Some SCSI devices don't implement this properly, so the safe answer is N.

entry.name: SCSI_ACORNSCSI_SYNC
entry.label: Support SCSI 2 Synchronous Transfers
entry.help:
Say Y here to enable synchronous transfer negotiation with all targets on the Acorn SCSI card.
In general, this improves performance; however some SCSI devices don't implement it properly, so the safe answer is N.

entry.name: SCSI_ARXESCSI
entry.label: ARXE SCSI support
entry.help: Around 1991, Arxe Systems Limited released a high density floppy disc interface for the Acorn Archimedes range, to allow the use of HD discs from the then new A5000 on earlier models. This interface was either sold on its own or with an integral SCSI controller. Technical details on this NCR53c94-based device are available at <http://www.cryton.demon.co.uk/acornbits/scsi_arxe.html> Say Y here to compile in support for the SCSI controller.

entry.name: SCSI_CUMANA_2
entry.label: CumanaSCSI II support
entry.help: This enables support for the Cumana SCSI II card. If you have an Acorn system with one of these, say Y. If unsure, say N.

entry.name: SCSI_EESOXSCSI
entry.label: EESOX support
entry.help: This enables support for the EESOX SCSI card. If you have an Acorn system with one of these, say Y, otherwise say N.

entry.name: SCSI_POWERTECSCSI
entry.label: PowerTec support
entry.help: This enables support for the Powertec SCSI card on Acorn systems. If you have one of these, say Y. If unsure, say N.

entry.name: SCSI_CUMANA_1
entry.label: CumanaSCSI I support
entry.help: This enables support for the Cumana SCSI I card. If you have an Acorn system with one of these, say Y. If unsure, say N.

entry.name: SCSI_OAK1
entry.label: Oak SCSI support
entry.help: This enables support for the Oak SCSI card. If you have an Acorn system with one of these, say Y. If unsure, say N.

entry.name: JAZZ_ESP
entry.label: MIPS JAZZ FAS216 SCSI support
entry.help: This is the driver for the onboard SCSI host adapter of MIPS Magnum 4000, Acer PICA, Olivetti M700-10 and a few other identical OEM systems.

entry.name: A3000_SCSI
entry.label: A3000 WD33C93A support
entry.help:
If you have an Amiga 3000 and have SCSI devices connected to the built-in SCSI controller, say Y. Otherwise, say N.
To compile this driver as a module, choose M here: the module will be called a3000.

entry.name: A2091_SCSI
entry.label: A2091/A590 WD33C93A support
entry.help:
If you have a Commodore A2091 SCSI controller, say Y. Otherwise, say N.
To compile this driver as a module, choose M here: the module will be called a2091.

entry.name: GVP11_SCSI
entry.label: GVP Series II WD33C93A support
entry.help:
If you have a Great Valley Products Series II SCSI controller, answer Y. Also say Y if you have a later model of GVP SCSI controller (such as the GVP A4008 or a Combo board). Otherwise, answer N. This driver does NOT work for the T-Rex series of accelerators from TekMagic and GVP-M.
To compile this driver as a module, choose M here: the module will be called gvp11.

entry.name: SCSI_A4000T
entry.label: A4000T NCR53c710 SCSI support
entry.help:
If you have an Amiga 4000T and have SCSI devices connected to the built-in SCSI controller, say Y. Otherwise, say N.
To compile this driver as a module, choose M here: the module will be called a4000t.

entry.name: SCSI_ZORRO7XX
entry.label: Zorro NCR53c710 SCSI support
entry.help: Support for various NCR53c710-based SCSI controllers on Zorro expansion boards for the Amiga. This includes: - the Amiga 4091 Zorro III SCSI-2 controller, - the MacroSystem Development's WarpEngine Amiga SCSI-2 controller (info at <http://www.lysator.liu.se/amiga/ar/guide/ar310.guide?FEATURE5>), - the SCSI controller on the Phase5 Blizzard PowerUP 603e+ accelerator card for the Amiga 1200, - the SCSI controller on the GVP Turbo 040/060 accelerator.

entry.name: ATARI_SCSI
entry.label: Atari native SCSI support
entry.help:
If you have an Atari with built-in NCR5380 SCSI controller (TT, Falcon, ...) say Y to get it supported. Of course also, if you have a compatible SCSI controller (e.g. for Medusa).
To compile this driver as a module, choose M here: the module will be called atari_scsi.
This driver supports both styles of NCR integration into the system: the TT style (separate DMA), and the Falcon style (via ST-DMA, replacing ACSI). It does NOT support other schemes, like in the Hades (without DMA).

entry.name: MAC_SCSI
entry.label: Macintosh NCR5380 SCSI
entry.help: This is the NCR 5380 SCSI controller included on most of the 68030 based Macintoshes. If you have one of these say Y and read the SCSI-HOWTO, available from <http://www.tldp.org/docs.html#howto>.

entry.name: SCSI_MAC_ESP
entry.label: Macintosh NCR53c9[46] SCSI
entry.help:
This is the NCR 53c9x SCSI controller found on most of the 68040 based Macintoshes.
To compile this driver as a module, choose M here: the module will be called mac_esp.

entry.name: MVME147_SCSI
entry.label: WD33C93 SCSI driver for MVME147
entry.help: Support for the on-board SCSI controller on the Motorola MVME147 single-board computer.

entry.name: MVME16x_SCSI
entry.label: NCR53C710 SCSI driver for MVME16x
entry.help: The Motorola MVME162, 166, 167, 172 and 177 boards use the NCR53C710 SCSI controller chip. Almost everyone using one of these boards will want to say Y to this question.

entry.name: BVME6000_SCSI
entry.label: NCR53C710 SCSI driver for BVME6000
entry.help: The BVME4000 and BVME6000 boards from BVM Ltd use the NCR53C710 SCSI controller chip. Almost everyone using one of these boards will want to say Y to this question.

entry.name: SUN3_SCSI
entry.label: Sun3 NCR5380 SCSI
entry.help: This option will enable support for the OBIO (onboard io) NCR5380 SCSI controller found in the Sun 3/50 and 3/60, as well as for "Sun3" type VME scsi controllers also based on the NCR5380. General Linux information on the Sun 3 series (now discontinued) is at <http://www.angelfire.com/ca2/tech68k/sun3.html>.

entry.name: SUN3X_ESP
entry.label: Sun3x ESP SCSI
entry.help: The ESP was an on-board SCSI controller used on Sun 3/80 machines. Say Y here to compile in support for it.

entry.name: SCSI_SUNESP
entry.label: Sparc ESP Scsi Driver
entry.help:
This is the driver for the Sun ESP SCSI host adapter. The ESP chipset is present in most SPARC SBUS-based computers and supports the Emulex family of ESP SCSI chips (esp100, esp100A, esp236, fas101, fas236) as well as the Qlogic fas366 SCSI chip.
To compile this driver as a module, choose M here: the module will be called sun_esp.

entry.name: ZFCP
entry.label: FCP host bus adapter driver for IBM eServer zSeries
entry.help:
If you want to access SCSI devices attached to your IBM eServer zSeries by means of Fibre Channel interfaces say Y. For details please refer to the documentation provided by IBM at <http://oss.software.ibm.com/developerworks/opensource/linux390>
This driver is also available as a module. This module will be called zfcp. If you want to compile it as a module, say M here and read <file:Documentation/kbuild/modules.txt>.

entry.name: SCSI_PMCRAID
entry.label: PMC SIERRA Linux MaxRAID adapter support
entry.help: This driver supports the PMC SIERRA MaxRAID adapters.

entry.name: SCSI_PM8001
entry.label: PMC-Sierra SPC 8001 SAS/SATA Based Host Adapter driver
entry.help: This driver supports PMC-Sierra PCIE SAS/SATA 8x6G SPC 8001 chip based host adapters.

entry.name: SCSI_BFA_FC
entry.label: Brocade BFA Fibre Channel Support
entry.help:
This bfa driver supports all Brocade PCIe FC/FCOE host adapters.
To compile this driver as a module, choose M here. The module will be called bfa.

entry.name: SCSI_VIRTIO
entry.label: virtio-scsi support
entry.help: This is the virtual HBA driver for virtio. If the kernel will be used in a virtual machine, say Y or M.

entry.name: SCSI_CHELSIO_FCOE
entry.label: Chelsio Communications FCoE support
entry.help:
This driver supports FCoE Offload functionality over Chelsio T4-based 10Gb Converged Network Adapters.
For general information about Chelsio and our products, visit our website at <http://www.chelsio.com>.
For customer support, please visit our customer support page at <http://www.chelsio.com/support.html>.
Please send feedback to <linux-bugs@chelsio.com>.
To compile this driver as a module choose M here; the module will be called csiostor.

entry.name: PCMCIA_AHA152X
entry.label: Adaptec AHA152X PCMCIA support
entry.help:
Say Y here if you intend to attach this type of PCMCIA SCSI host adapter to your computer.
To compile this driver as a module, choose M here: the module will be called aha152x_cs.

entry.name: PCMCIA_FDOMAIN
entry.label: Future Domain PCMCIA support
entry.help:
Say Y here if you intend to attach this type of PCMCIA SCSI host adapter to your computer.
To compile this driver as a module, choose M here: the module will be called fdomain_cs.

entry.name: PCMCIA_NINJA_SCSI
entry.label: NinjaSCSI-3 / NinjaSCSI-32Bi (16bit) PCMCIA support
entry.help:
If you intend to attach this type of PCMCIA SCSI host adapter to your computer, say Y here and read <file:Documentation/scsi/NinjaSCSI.txt>.
Supported cards:
NinjaSCSI-3: (version string: "WBT","NinjaSCSI-3","R1.0") IO-DATA PCSC-FP ALPHA DATA AD-PCS201 CyQ've SFC-201 LOGITECH LPM-SCSI2E Pioneer PCR-PR24's card I-O DATA CDPS-PX24's card (PCSC-F) Panasonic KXL-RW10AN CD-RW's card etc.
NinjaSCSI-32Bit (in 16bit mode): [Workbit (version string: "WORKBIT","UltraNinja-16","1")] Jazz SCP050 [I-O DATA (OEM) (version string: "IO DATA","CBSC16 ","1")] I-O DATA CBSC-II [Kyusyu Matsushita Kotobuki (OEM) (version string: "KME ","SCSI-CARD-001","1")] KME KXL-820AN's card HP M820e CDRW's card etc.
To compile this driver as a module, choose M here: the module will be called nsp_cs.

entry.name: PCMCIA_QLOGIC
entry.label: Qlogic PCMCIA support
entry.help:
Say Y here if you intend to attach this type of PCMCIA SCSI host adapter to your computer.
To compile this driver as a module, choose M here: the module will be called qlogic_cs.

entry.name: PCMCIA_SYM53C500
entry.label: Symbios 53c500 PCMCIA support
entry.help:
Say Y here if you have a New Media Bus Toaster or other PCMCIA SCSI adapter based on the Symbios 53c500 controller.
To compile this driver as a module, choose M here: the module will be called sym53c500_cs.

entry.name: SCSI_DH
entry.label: SCSI Device Handlers
entry.help: SCSI Device Handlers provide device specific support for devices utilized in multipath configurations. Say Y here to select support for specific hardware.

entry.name: SCSI_DH_RDAC
entry.label: LSI RDAC Device Handler
entry.help: If you have a LSI RDAC select y. Otherwise, say N.

entry.name: SCSI_DH_HP_SW
entry.label: HP/COMPAQ MSA Device Handler
entry.help: If you have a HP/COMPAQ MSA device that requires START_STOP to be sent to start it and cannot upgrade the firmware then select y. Otherwise, say N.

entry.name: SCSI_DH_EMC
entry.label: EMC CLARiiON Device Handler
entry.help: If you have a EMC CLARiiON select y. Otherwise, say N.

entry.name: SCSI_DH_ALUA
entry.label: SPC-3 ALUA Device Handler
entry.help: SCSI Device handler for generic SPC-3 Asymmetric Logical Unit Access (ALUA).

entry.name: SCSI_OSD_INITIATOR
entry.label: OSD-Initiator library
entry.help: Enable the OSD-Initiator library (libosd.ko). NOTE: You must also select CRYPTO_SHA1 + CRYPTO_HMAC and their dependencies

entry.name: SCSI_OSD_ULD
entry.label: OSD Upper Level driver
entry.help: Build a SCSI upper layer driver that exports /dev/osdX devices to user-mode for testing and controlling OSD devices. It is also needed by exofs, for mounting an OSD based file system.

entry.name: SCSI_OSD_DPRINT_SENSE
entry.label: (0-2) When sense is returned, DEBUG print all sense descriptors
entry.help: When a CHECK_CONDITION status is returned from a target, and a sense-buffer is retrieved, turning this on will dump a full sense-decoding message. Setting to 2 will also print recoverable errors that might be regularly returned for some filesystem operations.

entry.name: SCSI_OSD_DEBUG
entry.label: Compile All OSD modules with lots of DEBUG prints
entry.help: OSD Code is populated with lots of OSD_DEBUG(..) printouts to dmesg. Enable this if you found a bug and you want to help us track the problem (see also MAINTAINERS). Setting this will also force SCSI_OSD_DPRINT_SENSE=2.

entry.name: HAVE_PATA_PLATFORM
entry.help: This is an internal configuration node for any machine that uses pata-platform driver to enable the relevant driver in the configuration structure without having to submit endless patches to update the PATA_PLATFORM entry.

entry.name: ATA
entry.label: Serial ATA and Parallel ATA drivers (libata)
entry.help:
If you want to use an ATA hard disk, ATA tape drive, ATA CD-ROM or any other ATA device under Linux, say Y and make sure that you know the name of your ATA host adapter (the card inside your computer that "speaks" the ATA protocol, also called ATA controller), because you will be asked for it.
NOTE: ATA enables basic SCSI support; *however*, 'SCSI disk support', 'SCSI tape support', or 'SCSI CDROM support' may also be needed, depending on your hardware configuration.

entry.name: ATA_VERBOSE_ERROR
entry.label: Verbose ATA error reporting
entry.help:
This option adds parsing of ATA command descriptions and error bits in libata kernel output, making it easier to interpret. This option will enlarge the kernel by approx. 6KB. Disable it only if kernel size is more important than ease of debugging.
If unsure, say Y.

entry.name: ATA_ACPI
entry.label: ATA ACPI Support
entry.help: This option adds support for ATA-related ACPI objects. These ACPI objects add the ability to retrieve taskfiles from the ACPI BIOS and write them to the disk controller. These objects may be related to performance, security, power management, or other areas. You can disable this at kernel boot time by using the option libata.noacpi=1

entry.name: SATA_ZPODD
entry.label: SATA Zero Power Optical Disc Drive (ZPODD) support
entry.help:
This option adds support for SATA Zero Power Optical Disc Drive (ZPODD). It requires both the ODD and the platform support, and if enabled, will automatically power on/off the ODD when certain condition is satisfied. This does not impact end user's experience of the ODD, only power is saved when the ODD is not in use (i.e. no disc inside).
If unsure, say N.

entry.name: SATA_PMP
entry.label: SATA Port Multiplier support
entry.help: This option adds support for SATA Port Multipliers (the SATA version of an ethernet hub, or SAS expander).

entry.name: SATA_AHCI
entry.label: AHCI SATA support
entry.help:
This option enables support for AHCI Serial ATA.
If unsure, say N.

entry.name: SATA_AHCI_PLATFORM
entry.label: Platform AHCI SATA support
entry.help:
This option enables support for Platform AHCI Serial ATA controllers.
If unsure, say N.

entry.name: AHCI_BRCM
entry.label: Broadcom AHCI SATA support
entry.help:
This option enables support for the AHCI SATA3 controller found on Broadcom SoC's.
If unsure, say N.

entry.name: AHCI_DA850
entry.label: DaVinci DA850 AHCI SATA support
entry.help:
This option enables support for the DaVinci DA850 SoC's onboard AHCI SATA.
If unsure, say N.

entry.name: AHCI_ST
entry.label: ST AHCI SATA support
entry.help:
This option enables support for ST AHCI SATA controller.
If unsure, say N.

entry.name: AHCI_IMX
entry.label: Freescale i.MX AHCI SATA support
entry.help:
This option enables support for the Freescale i.MX SoC's onboard AHCI SATA.
If unsure, say N.

entry.name: AHCI_CEVA
entry.label: CEVA AHCI SATA support
entry.help:
This option enables support for the CEVA AHCI SATA. It can be found on the Xilinx Zynq UltraScale+ MPSoC.
If unsure, say N.

entry.name: AHCI_MVEBU
entry.label: Marvell EBU AHCI SATA support
entry.help:
This option enables support for the Marvebu EBU SoC's onboard AHCI SATA.
If unsure, say N.

entry.name: AHCI_OCTEON
entry.label: Cavium Octeon Soc Serial ATA
entry.help:
This option enables support for Cavium Octeon SoC Serial ATA.
If unsure, say N.

entry.name: AHCI_SUNXI
entry.label: Allwinner sunxi AHCI SATA support
entry.help:
This option enables support for the Allwinner sunxi SoC's onboard AHCI SATA.
If unsure, say N.

entry.name: AHCI_TEGRA
entry.label: NVIDIA Tegra124 AHCI SATA support
entry.help:
This option enables support for the NVIDIA Tegra124 SoC's onboard AHCI SATA.
If unsure, say N.

entry.name: AHCI_XGENE
entry.label: APM X-Gene 6.0Gbps AHCI SATA host controller support
entry.help: This option enables support for APM X-Gene SoC SATA host controller.

entry.name: AHCI_QORIQ
entry.label: Freescale QorIQ AHCI SATA support
entry.help:
This option enables support for the Freescale QorIQ AHCI SoC's onboard AHCI SATA.
If unsure, say N.

entry.name: SATA_FSL
entry.label: Freescale 3.0Gbps SATA support
entry.help:
This option enables support for Freescale 3.0Gbps SATA controller. It can be found on MPC837x and MPC8315.
If unsure, say N.

entry.name: SATA_AHCI_SEATTLE
entry.label: AMD Seattle 6.0Gbps AHCI SATA host controller support
entry.help:
This option enables support for AMD Seattle SATA host controller.
If unsure, say N

entry.name: SATA_INIC162X
entry.label: Initio 162x SATA support (Very Experimental)
entry.help: This option enables support for Initio 162x Serial ATA.

entry.name: SATA_ACARD_AHCI
entry.label: ACard AHCI variant (ATP 8620)
entry.help:
This option enables support for Acard.
If unsure, say N.

entry.name: SATA_SIL24
entry.label: Silicon Image 3124/3132 SATA support
entry.help:
This option enables support for Silicon Image 3124/3132 Serial ATA.
If unsure, say N.

entry.name: ATA_SFF
entry.label: ATA SFF support (for legacy IDE and PATA)
entry.help:
This option adds support for ATA controllers with SFF compliant or similar programming interface.
SFF is the legacy IDE interface that has been around since the dawn of time. Almost all PATA controllers have an SFF interface. Many SATA controllers have an SFF interface when configured into a legacy compatibility mode.
For users with exclusively modern controllers like AHCI, Silicon Image 3124, or Marvell 6440, you may choose to disable this unneeded SFF support.
If unsure, say Y.

entry.name: PDC_ADMA
entry.label: Pacific Digital ADMA support
entry.help:
This option enables support for Pacific Digital ADMA controllers
If unsure, say N.

entry.name: PATA_OCTEON_CF
entry.label: OCTEON Boot Bus Compact Flash support
entry.help:
This option enables a polled compact flash driver for use with compact flash cards attached to the OCTEON boot bus.
If unsure, say N.

entry.name: SATA_QSTOR
entry.label: Pacific Digital SATA QStor support
entry.help:
This option enables support for Pacific Digital Serial ATA QStor.
If unsure, say N.

entry.name: SATA_SX4
entry.label: Promise SATA SX4 support (Experimental)
entry.help:
This option enables support for Promise Serial ATA SX4.
If unsure, say N.

entry.name: ATA_BMDMA
entry.label: ATA BMDMA support
entry.help:
This option adds support for SFF ATA controllers with BMDMA capability. BMDMA stands for bus-master DMA and is the de facto DMA interface for SFF controllers.
If unsure, say Y.

entry.name: ATA_PIIX
entry.label: Intel ESB, ICH, PIIX3, PIIX4 PATA/SATA support
entry.help:
This option enables support for ICH5/6/7/8 Serial ATA and support for PATA on the Intel ESB/ICH/PIIX3/PIIX4 series host controllers.
If unsure, say N.

entry.name: SATA_DWC
entry.label: DesignWare Cores SATA support
entry.help:
This option enables support for the on-chip SATA controller of the AppliedMicro processor 460EX.
If unsure, say N.

entry.name: SATA_DWC_OLD_DMA
entry.label: Support old device trees
entry.help: This option enables support for old device trees without the "dmas" property.

entry.name: SATA_DWC_DEBUG
entry.label: Debugging driver version
entry.help: This option enables debugging output in the driver.

entry.name: SATA_DWC_VDEBUG
entry.label: Verbose debug output
entry.help: This option enables the taskfile dumping and NCQ debugging.

entry.name: SATA_HIGHBANK
entry.label: Calxeda Highbank SATA support
entry.help:
This option enables support for the Calxeda Highbank SoC's onboard SATA.
If unsure, say N.

entry.name: SATA_MV
entry.label: Marvell SATA support
entry.help:
This option enables support for the Marvell Serial ATA family. Currently supports 88SX[56]0[48][01] PCI(-X) chips, as well as the newer [67]042 PCI-X/PCIe and SOC devices.
If unsure, say N.

entry.name: SATA_NV
entry.label: NVIDIA SATA support
entry.help:
This option enables support for NVIDIA Serial ATA.
If unsure, say N.

entry.name: SATA_PROMISE
entry.label: Promise SATA TX2/TX4 support
entry.help:
This option enables support for Promise Serial ATA TX2/TX4.
If unsure, say N.

entry.name: SATA_RCAR
entry.label: Renesas R-Car SATA support
entry.help:
This option enables support for Renesas R-Car Serial ATA.
If unsure, say N.

entry.name: SATA_SIL
entry.label: Silicon Image SATA support
entry.help:
This option enables support for Silicon Image Serial ATA.
If unsure, say N.

entry.name: SATA_SIS
entry.label: SiS 964/965/966/180 SATA support
entry.help: This option enables support for SiS Serial ATA on SiS 964/965/966/180 and Parallel ATA on SiS 180. The PATA support for SiS 180 requires additionally to enable the PATA_SIS driver in the config. If unsure, say N.

entry.name: SATA_SVW
entry.label: ServerWorks Frodo / Apple K2 SATA support
entry.help:
This option enables support for Broadcom/Serverworks/Apple K2 SATA support.
If unsure, say N.

entry.name: SATA_ULI
entry.label: ULi Electronics SATA support
entry.help:
This option enables support for ULi Electronics SATA.
If unsure, say N.

entry.name: SATA_VIA
entry.label: VIA SATA support
entry.help:
This option enables support for VIA Serial ATA.
If unsure, say N.

entry.name: SATA_VITESSE
entry.label: VITESSE VSC-7174 / INTEL 31244 SATA support
entry.help:
This option enables support for Vitesse VSC7174 and Intel 31244 Serial ATA.
If unsure, say N.

entry.name: PATA_ALI
entry.label: ALi PATA support
entry.help:
This option enables support for the ALi ATA interfaces found on the many ALi chipsets.
If unsure, say N.

entry.name: PATA_AMD
entry.label: AMD/NVidia PATA support
entry.help:
This option enables support for the AMD and NVidia PATA interfaces found on the chipsets for Athlon/Athlon64.
If unsure, say N.

entry.name: PATA_ARASAN_CF
entry.label: ARASAN CompactFlash PATA Controller Support
entry.help: Say Y here to support the ARASAN CompactFlash PATA controller

entry.name: PATA_ARTOP
entry.label: ARTOP 6210/6260 PATA support
entry.help:
This option enables support for ARTOP PATA controllers.
If unsure, say N.

entry.name: PATA_ATIIXP
entry.label: ATI PATA support
entry.help:
This option enables support for the ATI ATA interfaces found on the many ATI chipsets.
If unsure, say N.

entry.name: PATA_ATP867X
entry.label: ARTOP/Acard ATP867X PATA support
entry.help:
This option enables support for ARTOP/Acard ATP867X PATA controllers.
If unsure, say N.

entry.name: PATA_BF54X
entry.label: Blackfin 54x ATAPI support
entry.help:
This option enables support for the built-in ATAPI controller on Blackfin 54x family chips.
If unsure, say N.

entry.name: PATA_CMD64X
entry.label: CMD64x PATA support
entry.help:
This option enables support for the CMD64x series chips except for the CMD640.
If unsure, say N.

entry.name: PATA_CS5520
entry.label: CS5510/5520 PATA support
entry.help:
This option enables support for the Cyrix 5510/5520 companion chip used with the MediaGX/Geode processor family.
If unsure, say N.

entry.name: PATA_CS5530
entry.label: CS5530 PATA support
entry.help:
This option enables support for the Cyrix/NatSemi/AMD CS5530 companion chip used with the MediaGX/Geode processor family.
If unsure, say N.

entry.name: PATA_CS5535
entry.label: CS5535 PATA support (Experimental)
entry.help:
This option enables support for the NatSemi/AMD CS5535 companion chip used with the Geode processor family.
If unsure, say N.

entry.name: PATA_CS5536
entry.label: CS5536 PATA support
entry.help:
This option enables support for the AMD CS5536 companion chip used with the Geode LX processor family.
If unsure, say N.

entry.name: PATA_CYPRESS
entry.label: Cypress CY82C693 PATA support (Very Experimental)
entry.help:
This option enables support for the Cypress/Contaq CY82C693 chipset found in some Alpha systems
If unsure, say N.

entry.name: PATA_EFAR
entry.label: EFAR SLC90E66 support
entry.help:
This option enables support for the EFAR SLC90E66 IDE controller found on some older machines.
If unsure, say N.

entry.name: PATA_EP93XX
entry.label: Cirrus Logic EP93xx PATA support
entry.help:
This option enables support for the PATA controller in the Cirrus Logic EP9312 and EP9315 ARM CPU.
If unsure, say N.

entry.name: PATA_HPT366
entry.label: HPT 366/368 PATA support
entry.help:
This option enables support for the HPT 366 and 368 PATA controllers via the new ATA layer.
If unsure, say N.

entry.name: PATA_HPT37X
entry.label: HPT 370/370A/371/372/374/302 PATA support
entry.help:
This option enables support for the majority of the later HPT PATA controllers via the new ATA layer.
If unsure, say N.

entry.name: PATA_HPT3X2N
entry.label: HPT 371N/372N/302N PATA support
entry.help:
This option enables support for the N variant HPT PATA controllers via the new ATA layer.
If unsure, say N.

entry.name: PATA_HPT3X3

entry.help:
This option enables support for the HPT 343/363 PATA controllers via the new ATA layer
If unsure, say N.

entry.name: PATA_HPT3X3_DMA
entry.label: HPT 343/363 DMA support
entry.help: This option enables DMA support for the HPT343/363 controllers. Enable with care as there are still some problems with DMA on this chipset.

entry.name: PATA_ICSIDE
entry.label: Acorn ICS PATA support
entry.help: On Acorn systems, say Y here if you wish to use the ICS PATA interface card. This is not required for ICS partition support. If you are unsure, say N to this.

entry.name: PATA_IMX
entry.label: PATA support for Freescale iMX
entry.help:
This option enables support for the PATA host available on Freescale iMX SoCs.
If unsure, say N.

entry.name: PATA_IT8213
entry.label: IT8213 PATA support (Experimental)
entry.help:
This option enables support for the ITE 821 PATA controllers via the new ATA layer.
If unsure, say N.

entry.name: PATA_IT821X
entry.label: IT8211/2 PATA support
entry.help:
This option enables support for the ITE 8211 and 8212 PATA controllers via the new ATA layer, including RAID mode.
If unsure, say N.

entry.name: PATA_JMICRON
entry.label: JMicron PATA support
entry.help:
Enable support for the JMicron IDE controller, via the new ATA layer.
If unsure, say N.

entry.name: PATA_MACIO
entry.label: Apple PowerMac/PowerBook internal 'MacIO' IDE
entry.help: Most IDE capable PowerMacs have IDE busses driven by a variant of this controller which is part of the Apple chipset used on most PowerMac models. Some models have multiple busses using different chipsets, though generally, MacIO is one of them.

entry.name: PATA_MARVELL
entry.label: Marvell PATA support via legacy mode
entry.help:
This option enables limited support for the Marvell 88SE61xx ATA controllers. If you wish to use only the SATA ports then select the AHCI driver alone. If you wish to the use the PATA port or both SATA and PATA include this driver.
If unsure, say N.

entry.name: PATA_MPC52xx
entry.label: Freescale MPC52xx SoC internal IDE
entry.help:
This option enables support for integrated IDE controller of the Freescale MPC52xx SoC.
If unsure, say N.

entry.name: PATA_NETCELL
entry.label: NETCELL Revolution RAID support
entry.help:
This option enables support for the Netcell Revolution RAID PATA controller.
If unsure, say N.

entry.name: PATA_NINJA32
entry.label: Ninja32/Delkin Cardbus ATA support
entry.help:
This option enables support for the Ninja32, Delkin and possibly other brands of Cardbus ATA adapter
If unsure, say N.

entry.name: PATA_NS87415
entry.label: Nat Semi NS87415 PATA support
entry.help:
This option enables support for the National Semiconductor NS87415 PCI-IDE controller.
If unsure, say N.

entry.name: PATA_OLDPIIX
entry.label: Intel PATA old PIIX support
entry.help:
This option enables support for early PIIX PATA support.
If unsure, say N.

entry.name: PATA_OPTIDMA
entry.label: OPTI FireStar PATA support (Very Experimental)
entry.help:
This option enables DMA/PIO support for the later OPTi controllers found on some old motherboards and in some laptops.
If unsure, say N.

entry.name: PATA_PDC2027X
entry.label: Promise PATA 2027x support
entry.help:
This option enables support for Promise PATA pdc20268 to pdc20277 host adapters.
If unsure, say N.

entry.name: PATA_PDC_OLD
entry.label: Older Promise PATA controller support
entry.help:
This option enables support for the Promise 20246, 20262, 20263, 20265 and 20267 adapters.
If unsure, say N.

entry.name: PATA_RADISYS
entry.label: RADISYS 82600 PATA support (Experimental)
entry.help:
This option enables support for the RADISYS 82600 PATA controllers via the new ATA layer
If unsure, say N.

entry.name: PATA_RDC
entry.label: RDC PATA support
entry.help:
This option enables basic support for the later RDC PATA controllers controllers via the new ATA layer. For the RDC 1010, you need to enable the IT821X driver instead.
If unsure, say N.

entry.name: PATA_SC1200
entry.label: SC1200 PATA support
entry.help:
This option enables support for the NatSemi/AMD SC1200 SoC companion chip used with the Geode processor family.
If unsure, say N.

entry.name: PATA_SCH
entry.label: Intel SCH PATA support
entry.help:
This option enables support for Intel SCH PATA on the Intel SCH (US15W, US15L, UL11L) series host controllers.
If unsure, say N.

entry.name: PATA_SERVERWORKS
entry.label: SERVERWORKS OSB4/CSB5/CSB6/HT1000 PATA support
entry.help:
This option enables support for the Serverworks OSB4/CSB5/CSB6 and HT1000 PATA controllers, via the new ATA layer.
If unsure, say N.

entry.name: PATA_SIL680
entry.label: CMD / Silicon Image 680 PATA support
entry.help:
This option enables support for CMD / Silicon Image 680 PATA.
If unsure, say N.

entry.name: PATA_SIS
entry.label: SiS PATA support
entry.help:
This option enables support for SiS PATA controllers
If unsure, say N.

entry.name: PATA_TOSHIBA
entry.label: Toshiba Piccolo support (Experimental)
entry.help:

entry.name: PATA_WINBOND

entry.help:
This option enables support for SL82C105 PATA devices found in the Netwinder and some other systems

entry.name: PATA_AT32

entry.name: PATA_AT91

entry.name: PATA_CMD640_PCI

entry.name: PATA_ISAPNP

entry.name: PATA_IXP4XX_CF

If unsure, say N.

entry.name: PATA_MPIIX

entry.name: PATA_NS87410

entry.name: PATA_OPTI

entry.name: PATA_PALMLD

This option enables support for Palm LifeDrive's internal ATA port via the new ATA layer.
If unsure, say N.

entry.name: PATA_PCMCIA
entry.label: PCMCIA PATA support
entry.help:
This option enables support for PCMCIA ATA interfaces, including compact flash card adapters via the new ATA layer.
If unsure, say N.

entry.name: PATA_PLATFORM
entry.label: Generic platform device PATA support
entry.help:
This option enables support for generic directly connected ATA devices commonly found on embedded systems.
If unsure, say N.

entry.name: PATA_OF_PLATFORM
entry.label: OpenFirmware platform device PATA support
entry.help:
This option enables support for generic directly connected ATA devices commonly found on embedded systems with OpenFirmware bindings.
If unsure, say N.

entry.name: PATA_QDI
entry.label: QDI VLB PATA support
entry.help: Support for QDI 6500 and 6580 PATA controllers on VESA local bus.

entry.name: PATA_RB532
entry.label: RouterBoard 532 PATA CompactFlash support
entry.help:
This option enables support for the RouterBoard 532 PATA CompactFlash controller.
If unsure, say N.

entry.name: PATA_RZ1000
entry.label: PC Tech RZ1000 PATA support
entry.help:
This option enables basic support for the PC Tech RZ1000/1 PATA controllers via the new ATA layer
If unsure, say N.

entry.name: PATA_SAMSUNG_CF
entry.label: Samsung SoC PATA support
entry.help:
This option enables basic support for Samsung's S3C/S5P board PATA controllers via the new ATA layer
If unsure, say N.

entry.name: PATA_WINBOND_VLB
entry.label: Winbond W83759A VLB PATA support (Experimental)
entry.help: Support for the Winbond W83759A controller on Vesa Local Bus systems.

entry.name: PATA_ACPI
entry.label: ACPI firmware driver for PATA
entry.help: This option enables an ACPI method driver which drives motherboard PATA controller interfaces through the ACPI firmware in the BIOS. This driver can sometimes handle otherwise unsupported hardware.

entry.name: ATA_GENERIC
entry.label: Generic ATA support
entry.help:
This option enables support for generic BIOS configured ATA controllers via the new ATA layer
If unsure, say N.

entry.name: PATA_LEGACY
entry.label: Legacy ISA PATA support (Experimental)
entry.help:
This option enables support for ISA/VLB/PCI bus legacy PATA ports and allows them to be accessed via the new ATA layer.
If unsure, say N.

entry.name: MD
entry.label: Multiple devices driver support (RAID and LVM)
entry.help: Support multiple physical spindles through a single logical device. Required for RAID and logical volume management.

entry.name: BLK_DEV_MD
entry.label: RAID support
entry.help:
This driver lets you combine several hard disk partitions into one logical block device. This can be used to simply append one partition to another one or to combine several redundant hard disks into a RAID1/4/5 device so as to provide protection against hard disk failures. This is called "Software RAID" since the combining of the partitions is done by the kernel. "Hardware RAID" means that the combining is done by a dedicated controller; if you have such a controller, you do not need to say Y here.
More information about Software RAID on Linux is contained in the Software RAID mini-HOWTO, available from <http://www.tldp.org/docs.html#howto>. There you will also learn where to get the supporting user space utilities raidtools.
If unsure, say N.

entry.name: MD_AUTODETECT
entry.label: Autodetect RAID arrays during kernel boot
entry.help:
If you say Y here, then the kernel will try to autodetect raid arrays as part of its boot process.
If you don't use raid and say Y, this autodetection can cause a several-second delay in the boot time due to various synchronisation steps that are part of this step.
If unsure, say Y.

entry.name: MD_LINEAR
entry.label: Linear (append) mode
entry.help:
If you say Y here, then your multiple devices driver will be able to use the so-called linear mode, i.e. it will combine the hard disk partitions by simply appending one to the other.
To compile this as a module, choose M here: the module will be called linear.
If unsure, say Y.

entry.name: MD_RAID0
entry.label: RAID-0 (striping) mode
entry.help:
If you say Y here, then your multiple devices driver will be able to use the so-called raid0 mode, i.e. it will combine the hard disk partitions into one logical device in such a fashion as to fill them up evenly, one chunk here and one chunk there. This will increase the throughput rate if the partitions reside on distinct disks.
Information about Software RAID on Linux is contained in the Software-RAID mini-HOWTO, available from <http://www.tldp.org/docs.html#howto>. There you will also learn where to get the supporting user space utilities raidtools.
To compile this as a module, choose M here: the module will be called raid0.
If unsure, say Y.

entry.name: MD_RAID1
entry.label: RAID-1 (mirroring) mode
entry.help:
A RAID-1 set consists of several disk drives which are exact copies of each other. In the event of a mirror failure, the RAID driver will continue to use the operational mirrors in the set, providing an error free MD (multiple device) to the higher levels of the kernel. In a set with N drives, the available space is the capacity of a single drive, and the set protects against a failure of (N - 1) drives.
Information about Software RAID on Linux is contained in the Software-RAID mini-HOWTO, available from <http://www.tldp.org/docs.html#howto>. There you will also learn where to get the supporting user space utilities raidtools.
If you want to use such a RAID-1 set, say Y. To compile this code as a module, choose M here: the module will be called raid1.
If unsure, say Y.

entry.name: MD_RAID10
entry.label: RAID-10 (mirrored striping) mode
entry.help:
RAID-10 provides a combination of striping (RAID-0) and mirroring (RAID-1) with easier configuration and more flexible layout. Unlike RAID-0, but like RAID-1, RAID-10 requires all devices to be the same size (or at least, only as much as the smallest device will be used). RAID-10 provides a variety of layouts that provide different levels of redundancy and performance.
RAID-10 requires mdadm-1.7.0 or later, available at:
ftp://ftp.kernel.org/pub/linux/utils/raid/mdadm/
If unsure, say Y.

entry.name: MD_RAID456
entry.label: RAID-4/RAID-5/RAID-6 mode
entry.help:
A RAID-5 set of N drives with a capacity of C MB per drive provides the capacity of C * (N - 1) MB, and protects against a failure of a single drive. For a given sector (row) number, (N - 1) drives contain data sectors, and one drive contains the parity protection. For a RAID-4 set, the parity blocks are present on a single drive, while a RAID-5 set distributes the parity across the drives in one of the available parity distribution methods.
A RAID-6 set of N drives with a capacity of C MB per drive provides the capacity of C * (N - 2) MB, and protects against a failure of any two drives. For a given sector (row) number, (N - 2) drives contain data sectors, and two drives contains two independent redundancy syndromes. Like RAID-5, RAID-6 distributes the syndromes across the drives in one of the available parity distribution methods.
Information about Software RAID on Linux is contained in the Software-RAID mini-HOWTO, available from <http://www.tldp.org/docs.html#howto>. There you will also learn where to get the supporting user space utilities raidtools.
If you want to use such a RAID-4/RAID-5/RAID-6 set, say Y. To compile this code as a module, choose M here: the module will be called raid456.
If unsure, say Y.

entry.name: MD_MULTIPATH
entry.label: Multipath I/O support
entry.help:
MD_MULTIPATH provides a simple multi-path personality for use the MD framework. It is not under active development. New projects should consider using DM_MULTIPATH which has more features and more testing.
If unsure, say N.

entry.name: MD_FAULTY
entry.label: Faulty test module for MD
entry.help:
The "faulty" module allows for a block device that occasionally returns read or write errors. It is useful for testing.
In unsure, say N.

entry.name: MD_CLUSTER
entry.label: Cluster Support for MD (EXPERIMENTAL)
entry.help:
Clustering support for MD devices. This enables locking and synchronization across multiple systems on the cluster, so all nodes in the cluster can access the MD devices simultaneously.
This brings the redundancy (and uptime) of RAID levels across the nodes of the cluster.
If unsure, say N.

entry.name: BCACHE
entry.label: Block device as cache
entry.help:
Allows a block device to be used as cache for other devices; uses a btree for indexing and the layout is optimized for SSDs.
See Documentation/bcache.txt for details.

entry.name: BCACHE_DEBUG
entry.label: Bcache debugging
entry.help:
Don't select this option unless you're a developer
Enables extra debugging tools, allows expensive runtime checks to be turned on.

entry.name: BCACHE_CLOSURES_DEBUG
entry.label: Debug closures
entry.help: Keeps all active closures in a linked list and provides a debugfs interface to list them, which makes it possible to see asynchronous operations that get stuck.

entry.name: BLK_DEV_DM
entry.label: Device mapper support
entry.help:
Device-mapper is a low level volume manager. It works by allowing people to specify mappings for ranges of logical sectors. Various mapping types are available, in addition people may write their own modules containing custom mappings if they wish.
Higher level volume managers such as LVM2 use this driver.
To compile this as a module, choose M here: the module will be called dm-mod.
If unsure, say N.

entry.name: DM_MQ_DEFAULT
entry.label: request-based DM: use blk-mq I/O path by default
entry.help:
This option enables the blk-mq based I/O path for request-based DM devices by default. With the option the dm_mod.use_blk_mq module/boot option defaults to Y, without it to N, but it can still be overriden either way.
If unsure say N.

entry.name: DM_DEBUG
entry.label: Device mapper debugging support
entry.help:
Enable this for messages that may help debug device-mapper problems.
If unsure, say N.

entry.name: DM_BUFIO
entry.help: This interface allows you to do buffered I/O on a device and acts as a cache, holding recently-read blocks in memory and performing delayed writes.

entry.name: DM_DEBUG_BLOCK_STACK_TRACING
entry.label: Keep stack trace of persistent data block lock holders
entry.help:
Enable this for messages that may help debug problems with the block manager locking used by thin provisioning and caching.
If unsure, say N.

entry.name: DM_BIO_PRISON
entry.help: Some bio locking schemes used by other device-mapper targets including thin provisioning.

entry.name: DM_PERSISTENT_DATA
entry.help: Library providing immutable on-disk data structure support for device-mapper targets such as the thin provisioning target.

entry.name: DM_CRYPT
entry.label: Crypt target support
entry.help:
This device-mapper target allows you to create a device that transparently encrypts the data on it. You'll need to activate the ciphers you're going to use in the cryptoapi configuration.
For further information on dm-crypt and userspace tools see: <https://gitlab.com/cryptsetup/cryptsetup/wikis/DMCrypt>
To compile this code as a module, choose M here: the module will be called dm-crypt.
If unsure, say N.

entry.name: DM_SNAPSHOT
entry.label: Snapshot target
entry.help: Allow volume managers to take writable snapshots of a device.

entry.name: DM_THIN_PROVISIONING
entry.label: Thin provisioning target
entry.help: Provides thin provisioning and snapshots that share a data store.

entry.name: DM_CACHE
entry.label: Cache target (EXPERIMENTAL)
entry.help: dm-cache attempts to improve performance of a block device by moving frequently used data to a smaller, higher performance device. Different 'policy' plugins can be used to change the algorithms used to select which blocks are promoted, demoted, cleaned etc. It supports writeback and writethrough modes.

entry.name: DM_CACHE_SMQ
entry.label: Stochastic MQ Cache Policy (EXPERIMENTAL)
entry.help: A cache policy that uses a multiqueue ordered by recent hits to select which blocks should be promoted and demoted. This is meant to be a general purpose policy. It prioritises reads over writes. This SMQ policy (vs MQ) offers the promise of less memory utilization, improved performance and increased adaptability in the face of changing workloads.

entry.name: DM_CACHE_CLEANER
entry.label: Cleaner Cache Policy (EXPERIMENTAL)
entry.help: A simple cache policy that writes back all data to the origin. Used when decommissioning a dm-cache.

entry.name: DM_ERA
entry.label: Era target (EXPERIMENTAL)
entry.help: dm-era tracks which parts of a block device are written to over time. Useful for maintaining cache coherency when using vendor snapshots.

entry.name: DM_MIRROR
entry.label: Mirror target
entry.help: Allow volume managers to mirror logical volumes, also needed for live data migration tools such as 'pvmove'.

entry.name: DM_LOG_USERSPACE
entry.label: Mirror userspace logging
entry.help: The userspace logging module provides a mechanism for relaying the dm-dirty-log API to userspace. Log designs which are more suited to userspace implementation (e.g. shared storage logs) or experimental logs can be implemented by leveraging this framework.

entry.name: DM_RAID
entry.label: RAID 1/4/5/6/10 target
entry.help:
A dm target that supports RAID1, RAID10, RAID4, RAID5 and RAID6 mappings
A RAID-5 set of N drives with a capacity of C MB per drive provides the capacity of C * (N - 1) MB, and protects against a failure of a single drive. For a given sector (row) number, (N - 1) drives contain data sectors, and one drive contains the parity protection. For a RAID-4 set, the parity blocks are present on a single drive, while a RAID-5 set distributes the parity across the drives in one of the available parity distribution methods.
A RAID-6 set of N drives with a capacity of C MB per drive provides the capacity of C * (N - 2) MB, and protects against a failure of any two drives. For a given sector (row) number, (N - 2) drives contain data sectors, and two drives contains two independent redundancy syndromes. Like RAID-5, RAID-6 distributes the syndromes across the drives in one of the available parity distribution methods.

entry.name: DM_ZERO
entry.label: Zero target
entry.help: A target that discards writes, and returns all zeroes for reads. Useful in some recovery situations.

entry.name: DM_MULTIPATH
entry.label: Multipath target
entry.help: Allow volume managers to support multipath hardware.

entry.name: DM_MULTIPATH_QL
entry.label: I/O Path Selector based on the number of in-flight I/Os
entry.help:
This path selector is a dynamic load balancer which selects the path with the least number of in-flight I/Os.
If unsure, say N.

entry.name: DM_MULTIPATH_ST
entry.label: I/O Path Selector based on the service time
entry.help:
This path selector is a dynamic load balancer which selects the path expected to complete the incoming I/O in the shortest time.
If unsure, say N.

entry.name: DM_DELAY
entry.label: I/O delaying target
entry.help:
A target that delays reads and/or writes and can send them to different devices. Useful for testing.
If unsure, say N.

entry.name: DM_UEVENT
entry.label: DM uevents
entry.help: Generate udev events for DM events.

entry.name: DM_FLAKEY
entry.label: Flakey target
entry.help: A target that intermittently fails I/O for debugging purposes.

entry.name: DM_VERITY
entry.label: Verity target support
entry.help:
This device-mapper target creates a read-only device that transparently validates the data on one underlying device against a pre-generated tree of cryptographic checksums stored on a second device.
You'll need to activate the digests you're going to use in the cryptoapi configuration.
To compile this code as a module, choose M here: the module will be called dm-verity.
If unsure, say N.

entry.name: DM_VERITY_FEC
entry.label: Verity forward error correction support
entry.help:
Add forward error correction support to dm-verity. This option makes it possible to use pre-generated error correction data to recover from corrupted blocks.
If unsure, say N.

entry.name: DM_SWITCH
entry.label: Switch target support (EXPERIMENTAL)
entry.help:
This device-mapper target creates a device that supports an arbitrary mapping of fixed-size regions of I/O across a fixed set of paths. The path used for any specific region can be switched dynamically by sending the target a message.
To compile this code as a module, choose M here: the module will be called dm-switch.
If unsure, say N.

entry.name: DM_LOG_WRITES
entry.label: Log writes target support
entry.help:
This device-mapper target takes two devices, one device to use normally, one to log all write operations done to the first device. This is for use by file system developers wishing to verify that their fs is writing a consistent file system at all times by allowing them to replay the log in a variety of ways and to check the contents.
To compile this code as a module, choose M here: the module will be called dm-log-writes.
If unsure, say N.

entry.name: TARGET_CORE
entry.label: Generic Target Core Mod (TCM) and ConfigFS Infrastructure
entry.help: Say Y or M here to enable the TCM Storage Engine and ConfigFS enabled control path for target_core_mod. This includes built-in TCM RAMDISK subsystem logic for virtual LUN 0 access

entry.name: TCM_IBLOCK
entry.label: TCM/IBLOCK Subsystem Plugin for Linux/BLOCK
entry.help: Say Y here to enable the TCM/IBLOCK subsystem plugin for non-buffered access to Linux/Block devices using BIO

entry.name: TCM_FILEIO
entry.label: TCM/FILEIO Subsystem Plugin for Linux/VFS
entry.help: Say Y here to enable the TCM/FILEIO subsystem plugin for buffered access to Linux/VFS struct file or struct block_device

entry.name: TCM_PSCSI
entry.label: TCM/pSCSI Subsystem Plugin for Linux/SCSI
entry.help: Say Y here to enable the TCM/pSCSI subsystem plugin for non-buffered passthrough access to Linux/SCSI device

entry.name: TCM_USER2
entry.label: TCM/USER Subsystem Plugin for Linux
entry.help: Say Y here to enable the TCM/USER subsystem plugin for a userspace process to handle requests. This is version 2 of the ABI; version 1 is obsolete.

entry.name: LOOPBACK_TARGET
entry.label: TCM Virtual SAS target and Linux/SCSI LDD fabric loopback module
entry.help: Say Y here to enable the TCM Virtual SAS target and Linux/SCSI LLD fabric loopback module.

entry.name: TCM_FC
entry.label: TCM_FC fabric Plugin
entry.help: Say Y here to enable the TCM FC plugin for accessing FC fabrics in TCM

entry.name: ISCSI_TARGET
entry.label: Linux-iSCSI.org iSCSI Target Mode Stack
entry.help: Say M here to enable the ConfigFS enabled Linux-iSCSI.org iSCSI Target Mode Stack.

entry.name: ISCSI_TARGET_CXGB4
entry.label: Chelsio iSCSI target offload driver
entry.help: To compile this driver as module, choose M here: the module will be called cxgbit.

entry.name: SBP_TARGET
entry.label: FireWire SBP-2 fabric module
entry.help:
Say Y or M here to enable SCSI target functionality over FireWire. This enables you to expose SCSI devices to other nodes on the FireWire bus, for example hard disks. Similar to FireWire Target Disk mode on many Apple computers.
To compile this driver as a module, say M here: The module will be called sbp-target.

entry.name: FUSION
entry.label: Fusion MPT device support
entry.help:
Say Y here to get to see options for Fusion Message Passing Technology (MPT) drivers. This option alone does not add any kernel code.
If you say N, all options in this submenu will be skipped and disabled.

entry.name: FUSION_SPI
entry.label: Fusion MPT ScsiHost drivers for SPI
entry.help:
SCSI HOST support for a parallel SCSI host adapters.
List of supported controllers:
LSI53C1020 LSI53C1020A LSI53C1030 LSI53C1035 ATTO UL4D

entry.name: FUSION_FC
entry.label: Fusion MPT ScsiHost drivers for FC
entry.help:
SCSI HOST support for a Fiber Channel host adapters.
List of supported controllers:
LSIFC909 LSIFC919 LSIFC919X LSIFC929 LSIFC929X LSIFC929XL LSIFC949X LSIFC949E Brocade FC 410/420

entry.name: FUSION_SAS
entry.label: Fusion MPT ScsiHost drivers for SAS
entry.help:
SCSI HOST support for a SAS host adapters.
List of supported controllers:
LSISAS1064 LSISAS1068 LSISAS1064E LSISAS1068E LSISAS1078

entry.name: FUSION_MAX_SGE
entry.label: Maximum number of scatter gather entries (16 - 128)
entry.help: This option allows you to specify the maximum number of scatter- gather entries per I/O. The driver default is 128, which matches SCSI_MAX_PHYS_SEGMENTS. However, it may decreased down to 16. Decreasing this parameter will reduce memory requirements on a per controller instance.

entry.name: FUSION_CTL
entry.label: Fusion MPT misc device (ioctl) driver
entry.help:
The Fusion MPT misc device driver provides specialized control of MPT adapters via system ioctl calls. Use of ioctl calls to the MPT driver requires that you create and use a misc device node ala: mknod /dev/mptctl c 10 240
One use of this ioctl interface is to perform an upgrade (reflash) of the MPT adapter firmware. Refer to readme file(s) distributed with the Fusion MPT linux driver for additional details.
If enabled by saying M to this, a driver named: mptctl will be compiled.
If unsure whether you really want or need this, say N.

entry.name: FUSION_LAN
entry.label: Fusion MPT LAN driver
entry.help:
This module supports LAN IP traffic over Fibre Channel port(s) on Fusion MPT compatible hardware (LSIFC9xx chips). The physical interface used is defined in RFC 2625. Please refer to that document for details.
Installing this driver requires the knowledge to configure and activate a new network interface, "fc0", using standard Linux tools.
If enabled by saying M to this, a driver named: mptlan will be compiled.
If unsure whether you really want or need this, say N.

entry.name: FUSION_LOGGING
entry.label: Fusion MPT logging facility
entry.help:
This turns on a logging facility that can be used to debug a number of Fusion MPT related problems.
The debug level can be programmed on the fly via SysFS (hex values)
echo [level] > /sys/class/scsi_host/host#/debug_level
There are various debug levels that can be found in the source: file:drivers/message/fusion/mptdebug.h

entry.name: FIREWIRE
entry.label: FireWire driver stack
entry.help:
This is the new-generation IEEE 1394 (FireWire) driver stack a.k.a. Juju, a new implementation designed for robustness and simplicity. See http://ieee1394.wiki.kernel.org/index.php/Juju_Migration for information about migration from the older Linux 1394 stack to the new driver stack.
To compile this driver as a module, say M here: the module will be called firewire-core.

entry.name: FIREWIRE_OHCI
entry.label: OHCI-1394 controllers
entry.help:
Enable this driver if you have a FireWire controller based on the OHCI specification. For all practical purposes, this is the only chipset in use, so say Y here.
To compile this driver as a module, say M here: The module will be called firewire-ohci.

entry.name: FIREWIRE_SBP2
entry.label: Storage devices (SBP-2 protocol)
entry.help:
This option enables you to use SBP-2 devices connected to a FireWire bus. SBP-2 devices include storage devices like harddisks and DVD drives, also some other FireWire devices like scanners.
To compile this driver as a module, say M here: The module will be called firewire-sbp2.
You should also enable support for disks, CD-ROMs, etc. in the SCSI configuration section.

entry.name: FIREWIRE_NET
entry.label: IP networking over 1394
entry.help:
This enables IPv4/IPv6 over IEEE 1394, providing IP connectivity with other implementations of RFC 2734/3146 as found on several operating systems. Multicast support is currently limited.
To compile this driver as a module, say M here: The module will be called firewire-net.

entry.name: FIREWIRE_NOSY
entry.label: Nosy - a FireWire traffic sniffer for PCILynx cards
entry.help:
Nosy is an IEEE 1394 packet sniffer that is used for protocol analysis and in development of IEEE 1394 drivers, applications, or firmwares.
This driver lets you use a Texas Instruments PCILynx 1394 to PCI link layer controller TSB12LV21/A/B as a low-budget bus analyzer. PCILynx is a nowadays very rare IEEE 1394 controller which is not OHCI 1394 compliant.
The following cards are known to be based on PCILynx or PCILynx-2: IOI IOI-1394TT (PCI card), Unibrain Fireboard 400 PCI Lynx-2 (PCI card), Newer Technology FireWire 2 Go (CardBus card), Apple Power Mac G3 blue & white and G4 with PCI graphics (onboard controller).
To compile this driver as a module, say M here: The module will be called nosy. Source code of a userspace interface to nosy, called nosy-dump, can be found in tools/firewire/ of the kernel sources.
If unsure, say N.

entry.name: MACINTOSH_DRIVERS
entry.label: Macintosh device drivers
entry.help:
Say Y here to get to see options for devices used with Macintosh computers. This option alone does not add any kernel code.
If you say N, all options in this submenu will be skipped and disabled.

entry.name: ADB
