entry.help:
If you say yes to this option, support will be included for the SiS5595 SMBus (a subset of I2C) interface.
This driver can also be built as a module. If so, the module will be called i2c-sis5595.

entry.name: I2C_SIS630
entry.label: SiS 630/730/964
entry.help:
If you say yes to this option, support will be included for the SiS630, SiS730 and SiS964 SMBus (a subset of I2C) interface.
This driver can also be built as a module. If so, the module will be called i2c-sis630.

entry.name: I2C_SIS96X
entry.label: SiS 96x
entry.help:
If you say yes to this option, support will be included for the SiS 96x SMBus (a subset of I2C) interfaces. Specifically, the following chipsets are supported: 645/961 645DX/961 645DX/962 648/961 650/961 735 745
This driver can also be built as a module. If so, the module will be called i2c-sis96x.

entry.name: I2C_VIA
entry.label: VIA VT82C586B
entry.help:
If you say yes to this option, support will be included for the VIA 82C586B I2C interface
This driver can also be built as a module. If so, the module will be called i2c-via.

entry.name: I2C_VIAPRO
entry.label: VIA VT82C596/82C686/82xx and CX700/VX8xx/VX900
entry.help:
If you say yes to this option, support will be included for the VIA VT82C596 and later SMBus interface. Specifically, the following chipsets are supported: VT82C596A/B VT82C686A/B VT8231 VT8233/A VT8235 VT8237R/A/S VT8251 CX700 VX800/VX820 VX855/VX875 VX900
This driver can also be built as a module. If so, the module will be called i2c-viapro.

entry.name: I2C_SCMI
entry.label: SMBus Control Method Interface
entry.help:
This driver supports the SMBus Control Method Interface. It needs the BIOS to declare ACPI control methods as described in the SMBus Control Method Interface specification.
To compile this driver as a module, choose M here: the module will be called i2c-scmi.

entry.name: I2C_HYDRA
entry.label: CHRP Apple Hydra Mac I/O I2C interface
entry.help:
This supports the use of the I2C interface in the Apple Hydra Mac I/O chip on some CHRP machines (e.g. the LongTrail). Say Y if you have such a machine.
This support is also available as a module. If so, the module will be called i2c-hydra.

entry.name: I2C_POWERMAC
entry.label: Powermac I2C interface
entry.help:
This exposes the various PowerMac i2c interfaces to the linux i2c layer and to userland. It is used by various drivers on the PowerMac platform, and should generally be enabled.
This support is also available as a module. If so, the module will be called i2c-powermac.

entry.name: I2C_AT91
entry.label: Atmel AT91 I2C Two-Wire interface (TWI)
entry.help:
This supports the use of the I2C interface on Atmel AT91 processors.
A serious problem is that there is no documented way to issue repeated START conditions for more than two messages, as needed to support combined I2C messages. Use the i2c-gpio driver unless your system can cope with this limitation.
Caution! at91rm9200, at91sam9261, at91sam9260, at91sam9263 devices don't have clock stretching in transmission mode. For that reason, you can encounter underrun issues causing premature stop sendings if the latency to fill the transmission register is too long. If you are facing this situation, use the i2c-gpio driver.

entry.name: I2C_AU1550
entry.label: Au1550/Au1200/Au1300 SMBus interface
entry.help:
If you say yes to this option, support will be included for the Au1550/Au1200/Au1300 SMBus interface.
This driver can also be built as a module. If so, the module will be called i2c-au1550.

entry.name: I2C_AXXIA
entry.label: Axxia I2C controller
entry.help:
Say yes if you want to support the I2C bus on Axxia platforms.
Please note that this controller is limited to transfers of maximum 255 bytes in length. Any attempt to to a larger transfer will return an error.

entry.name: I2C_BCM2835
entry.label: Broadcom BCM2835 I2C controller
entry.help:
If you say yes to this option, support will be included for the BCM2835 I2C controller.
If you don't know what to do here, say N.
This support is also available as a module. If so, the module will be called i2c-bcm2835.

entry.name: I2C_BCM_IPROC
entry.label: Broadcom iProc I2C controller
entry.help:
If you say yes to this option, support will be included for the Broadcom iProc I2C controller.
If you don't know what to do here, say N.

entry.name: I2C_BCM_KONA
entry.label: BCM Kona I2C adapter
entry.help:
If you say yes to this option, support will be included for the I2C interface on the Broadcom Kona family of processors.
If you do not need KONA I2C interface, say N.

entry.name: I2C_BRCMSTB
entry.label: BRCM Settop I2C controller
entry.help:
If you say yes to this option, support will be included for the I2C interface on the Broadcom Settop SoCs.
If you do not need I2C interface, say N.

entry.name: I2C_BLACKFIN_TWI
entry.label: Blackfin TWI I2C support
entry.help:
This is the I2C bus driver for Blackfin on-chip TWI interface.
This driver can also be built as a module. If so, the module will be called i2c-bfin-twi.

entry.name: I2C_BLACKFIN_TWI_CLK_KHZ
entry.label: Blackfin TWI I2C clock (kHz)
entry.help: The unit of the TWI clock is kHz.

entry.name: I2C_CADENCE
entry.label: Cadence I2C Controller
entry.help: Say yes here to select Cadence I2C Host Controller. This controller is e.g. used by Xilinx Zynq.

entry.name: I2C_CBUS_GPIO
entry.label: CBUS I2C driver
entry.help:
Support for CBUS access using I2C API. Mostly relevant for Nokia Internet Tablets (770, N800 and N810).
This driver can also be built as a module. If so, the module will be called i2c-cbus-gpio.

entry.name: I2C_CPM
entry.label: Freescale CPM1 or CPM2 (MPC8xx/826x)
entry.help:
This supports the use of the I2C interface on Freescale processors with CPM1 or CPM2.
This driver can also be built as a module. If so, the module will be called i2c-cpm.

entry.name: I2C_DAVINCI
entry.label: DaVinci I2C driver
entry.help:
Support for TI DaVinci I2C controller driver.
This driver can also be built as a module. If so, the module will be called i2c-davinci.
Please note that this driver might be needed to bring up other devices such as DaVinci NIC. For details please see http://www.ti.com/davinci

entry.name: I2C_DESIGNWARE_PLATFORM

entry.help:
If you say yes to this option, support will be included for the Synopsys DesignWare I2C adapter. Only master mode is supported.
This driver can also be built as a module. If so, the module will be called i2c-designware-platform.

entry.name: I2C_DESIGNWARE_PCI
entry.label: Synopsys DesignWare PCI
entry.help:
If you say yes to this option, support will be included for the Synopsys DesignWare I2C adapter. Only master mode is supported.
This driver can also be built as a module. If so, the module will be called i2c-designware-pci.

entry.name: I2C_DESIGNWARE_BAYTRAIL
entry.label: Intel Baytrail I2C semaphore support
entry.help: This driver enables managed host access to the PMIC I2C bus on select Intel BayTrail platforms using the X-Powers AXP288 PMIC. It allows the host to request uninterrupted access to the PMIC's I2C bus from the platform firmware controlling it. You should say Y if running on a BayTrail system using the AXP288.

entry.name: I2C_DIGICOLOR
entry.label: Conexant Digicolor I2C driver
entry.help:
Support for Conexant Digicolor SoCs (CX92755) I2C controller driver.
This driver can also be built as a module. If so, the module will be called i2c-digicolor.

entry.name: I2C_EFM32
entry.label: EFM32 I2C controller
entry.help: This driver supports the i2c block found in Energy Micro's EFM32 SoCs.

entry.name: I2C_EG20T
entry.label: Intel EG20T PCH/LAPIS Semicon IOH(ML7213/ML7223/ML7831) I2C
entry.help:
This driver is for PCH(Platform controller Hub) I2C of EG20T which is an IOH(Input/Output Hub) for x86 embedded processor. This driver can access PCH I2C bus device.
This driver also can be used for LAPIS Semiconductor IOH(Input/ Output Hub), ML7213, ML7223 and ML7831. ML7213 IOH is for IVI(In-Vehicle Infotainment) use, ML7223 IOH is for MP(Media Phone) use and ML7831 IOH is for general purpose use. ML7213/ML7223/ML7831 is companion chip for Intel Atom E6xx series. ML7213/ML7223/ML7831 is completely compatible for Intel EG20T PCH.

entry.name: I2C_EMEV2
entry.label: EMMA Mobile series I2C adapter
entry.help: If you say yes to this option, support will be included for the I2C interface on the Renesas Electronics EM/EV family of processors.

entry.name: I2C_EXYNOS5

entry.name: I2C_GPIO

entry.name: I2C_IBM_IIC

The P2WI looks like an SMBus controller (which supports only byte accesses), except that it only supports one slave device. This interface is used to connect to specific PMIC devices (like the AXP221).

entry.name: I2C_XLP9XX

entry.help:
This driver enables support for the on-chip I2C interface of the Broadcom XLP9xx/XLP5xx MIPS and Vulcan ARM64 processors.
This driver can also be built as a module. If so, the module will be called i2c-xlp9xx.

entry.name: I2C_RCAR
entry.label: Renesas R-Car I2C Controller
entry.help:
If you say yes to this option, support will be included for the R-Car I2C controller.
This driver can also be built as a module. If so, the module will be called i2c-rcar.

entry.name: I2C_DIOLAN_U2C
entry.label: Diolan U2C-12 USB adapter
entry.help:
If you say yes to this option, support will be included for Diolan U2C-12, a USB to I2C interface.

entry.name: I2C_DLN2
entry.label: Diolan DLN-2 USB I2C adapter
entry.help:
If you say yes to this option, support will be included for Diolan DLN2, a USB to I2C interface.
This driver can also be built as a module. If so, the module will be called i2c-dln2.

entry.name: I2C_PARPORT
entry.label: Parallel port adapter
entry.help:
This supports parallel port I2C adapters such as the ones made by Philips or Velleman, Analog Devices evaluation boards, and more. Basically any adapter using the parallel port as an I2C bus with no extra chipset is supported by this driver, or could be.
This driver is a replacement for (and was inspired by) an older driver named i2c-philips-par. The new driver supports more devices, and makes it easier to add support for new devices.
An adapter type parameter is now mandatory. Please read the file Documentation/i2c/busses/i2c-parport for details.
Another driver exists, named i2c-parport-light, which doesn't depend on the parport driver. This is meant for embedded systems. Don't say Y here if you intend to say Y or M there.
This support is also available as a module. If so, the module will be called i2c-parport.

entry.name: I2C_PARPORT_LIGHT
entry.label: Parallel port adapter (light)
entry.help:
This supports parallel port I2C adapters such as the ones made by Philips or Velleman, Analog Devices evaluation boards, and more. Basically any adapter using the parallel port as an I2C bus with no extra chipset is supported by this driver, or could be.
This driver is a light version of i2c-parport. It doesn't depend on the parport driver, and uses direct I/O access instead. This might be preferred on embedded systems where wasting memory for the clean but heavy parport handling is not an option. The drawback is a reduced portability and the impossibility to daisy-chain other parallel port devices.
Don't say Y here if you said Y or M to i2c-parport. Saying M to both is possible but both modules should not be loaded at the same time.
This support is also available as a module. If so, the module will be called i2c-parport-light.

entry.name: I2C_ROBOTFUZZ_OSIF
entry.label: RobotFuzz Open Source InterFace USB adapter
entry.help:
If you say yes to this option, support will be included for the RobotFuzz Open Source InterFace USB to I2C interface.
This driver can also be built as a module. If so, the module will be called i2c-osif.

entry.name: I2C_TAOS_EVM

entry.help:
This supports TAOS evaluation modules on serial port. In order to use this driver, you will need the inputattach tool, which is part of the input-utils package.
If unsure, say N.

entry.name: I2C_TINY_USB
entry.label: Tiny-USB adapter

If you say yes to this option, support will be included for the i2c-tiny-usb, a simple do-it-yourself USB to I2C interface. See http://www.harbaum.org/till/i2c_tiny_usb for hardware details.

entry.name: I2C_PCA_ISA

entry.help:
This driver supports ISA boards using the Philips PCA9564/PCA9665 parallel bus to I2C bus controller.
This driver can also be built as a module. If so, the module will be called i2c-pca-isa.

entry.name: I2C_CROS_EC_TUNNEL

entry.name: I2C_XGENE_SLIMPRO

Enable the use of the ACCESS.bus controllers on the Geode SCx200 and SC1100 processors and the CS5535 and CS5536 Geode companion devices.

entry.name: I2C_OPAL

This exposes the PowerNV platform i2c busses to the linux i2c layer, the driver is based on the OPAL interfaces.

entry.name: I2C_STUB

This module may be useful to developers of SMBus client drivers, especially for certain kinds of sensor chips.
If you do build this module, be sure to read the notes and warnings in <file:Documentation/i2c/i2c-stub>.

entry.help: Say Y here if you want the I2C core to produce a bunch of debug messages to the system log. Select this if you are having a problem with I2C support and want to see more of what is going on.

entry.name: I2C_DEBUG_ALGO

entry.help: Say Y here if you want the I2C algorithm drivers to produce a bunch of debug messages to the system log. Select this if you are having a problem with I2C support and want to see more of what is going on.

entry.name: SPI
entry.label: SPI support
entry.help:
The "Serial Peripheral Interface" is a low level synchronous protocol. Chips that support SPI can have data transfer rates up to several tens of Mbit/sec. Chips are addressed with a controller and a chipselect. Most SPI slaves don't support dynamic device discovery; some are even write-only or read-only.
SPI is widely used by microcontrollers to talk with sensors, eeprom and flash memory, codecs and various other controller chips, analog to digital (and d-to-a) converters, and more. MMC and SD cards can be accessed using SPI protocol; and for DataFlash cards used in MMC sockets, SPI must always be used.
SPI is one of a family of similar protocols using a four wire interface (select, clock, data in, data out) including Microwire (half duplex), SSP, SSI, and PSP. This driver framework should work with most such devices and controllers.

entry.name: SPI_DEBUG

entry.help: Say "yes" to enable debug messaging (like dev_dbg and pr_debug), sysfs, and debugfs support in SPI controller and protocol drivers.

entry.name: SPI_MASTER

entry.help: This is the driver for the Altera SPI Controller.

entry.name: SPI_ATH79

entry.help: This enables support for the SPI controller present on the Atheros AR71XX/AR724X/AR913X SoCs.

entry.name: SPI_ATMEL

entry.help: This selects a driver for the Atmel SPI Controller, present on many AT32 (AVR32) and AT91 (ARM) chips.

entry.name: SPI_AU1550
entry.label: Au1550/Au1200/Au1300 SPI Controller
entry.help: If you say yes to this option, support will be included for the PSC SPI controller found on Au1550, Au1200 and Au1300 series.

entry.help: This enables support for the Analog Devices AXI SPI Engine SPI controller. It is part of the SPI Engine framework that is used in some Analog Devices reference designs for FPGAs.

entry.name: SPI_BCM2835
entry.label: BCM2835 SPI controller
entry.help:
This selects a driver for the Broadcom BCM2835 SPI master.
The BCM2835 contains two types of SPI master controller; the "universal SPI master", and the regular SPI controller. This driver is for the regular SPI controller. Slave mode operation is not also not supported.

entry.name: SPI_BCM2835AUX
entry.label: BCM2835 SPI auxiliary controller
entry.help:
This selects a driver for the Broadcom BCM2835 SPI aux master.
The BCM2835 contains two types of SPI master controller; the "universal SPI master", and the regular SPI controller. This driver is for the universal/auxiliary SPI controller.

entry.name: SPI_BFIN5XX
entry.label: SPI controller driver for ADI Blackfin5xx
entry.help: This is the SPI controller master driver for Blackfin 5xx processor.

entry.name: SPI_ADI_V3
entry.label: SPI controller v3 for ADI
entry.help: This is the SPI controller v3 master driver found on Blackfin 60x processor.

entry.name: SPI_BFIN_SPORT
entry.label: SPI bus via Blackfin SPORT
entry.help: Enable support for a SPI bus via the Blackfin SPORT peripheral.

entry.name: SPI_BCM53XX
entry.label: Broadcom BCM53xx SPI controller
entry.help: Enable support for the SPI controller on Broadcom BCM53xx ARM SoCs.

entry.name: SPI_BCM63XX
entry.label: Broadcom BCM63xx SPI controller
entry.help: Enable support for the SPI controller on the Broadcom BCM63xx SoCs.

entry.name: SPI_BCM63XX_HSSPI
entry.label: Broadcom BCM63XX HS SPI controller driver
entry.help: This enables support for the High Speed SPI controller present on newer Broadcom BCM63XX SoCs.

entry.name: SPI_BITBANG
entry.label: Utilities for Bitbanging SPI masters
entry.help:
With a few GPIO pins, your system can bitbang the SPI protocol. Select this to get SPI support through I/O pins (GPIO, parallel port, etc). Or, some systems' SPI master controller drivers use this code to manage the per-word or per-transfer accesses to the hardware shift registers.
This is library code, and is automatically selected by drivers that need it. You only need to select this explicitly to support driver modules that aren't part of this kernel tree.

entry.name: SPI_BUTTERFLY
entry.label: Parallel port adapter for AVR Butterfly (DEVELOPMENT)
entry.help: This uses a custom parallel port cable to connect to an AVR Butterfly <http://www.atmel.com/products/avr/butterfly>, an inexpensive battery powered microcontroller evaluation board. This same cable can be used to flash new firmware.

entry.name: SPI_CADENCE
entry.label: Cadence SPI controller
entry.help: This selects the Cadence SPI controller master driver used by Xilinx Zynq and ZynqMP.

entry.name: SPI_CLPS711X
entry.label: CLPS711X host SPI controller
entry.help: This enables dedicated general purpose SPI/Microwire1-compatible master mode interface (SSI1) for CLPS711X-based CPUs.

entry.name: SPI_COLDFIRE_QSPI
entry.label: Freescale Coldfire QSPI controller
entry.help: This enables support for the Coldfire QSPI controller in master mode.

entry.name: SPI_DAVINCI
entry.label: Texas Instruments DaVinci/DA8x/OMAP-L/AM1x SoC SPI controller
entry.help: SPI master controller for DaVinci/DA8x/OMAP-L/AM1x SPI modules.

entry.name: SPI_DESIGNWARE
entry.label: DesignWare SPI controller core support
entry.help: general driver for SPI controller core from DesignWare

entry.name: SPI_DW_PCI
entry.label: PCI interface driver for DW SPI core

entry.name: SPI_DW_MID_DMA
entry.label: DMA support for DW SPI controller on Intel MID platform

entry.name: SPI_DW_MMIO
entry.label: Memory-mapped io interface driver for DW SPI core

entry.name: SPI_DLN2
entry.label: Diolan DLN-2 USB SPI adapter
entry.help:
If you say yes to this option, support will be included for Diolan DLN2, a USB to SPI interface.
This driver can also be built as a module. If so, the module will be called spi-dln2.

entry.name: SPI_EFM32
entry.label: EFM32 SPI controller
entry.help: Driver for the spi controller found on Energy Micro's EFM32 SoCs.

entry.name: SPI_EP93XX
entry.label: Cirrus Logic EP93xx SPI controller
entry.help: This enables using the Cirrus EP93xx SPI controller in master mode.

entry.name: SPI_FALCON
entry.label: Falcon SPI controller support
entry.help: The external bus unit (EBU) found on the FALC-ON SoC has SPI emulation that is designed for serial flash access. This driver has only been tested with m25p80 type chips. The hardware has no support for other types of SPI peripherals.

entry.name: SPI_GPIO
entry.label: GPIO-based bitbanging SPI Master
entry.help:
This simple GPIO bitbanging SPI master uses the arch-neutral GPIO interface to manage MOSI, MISO, SCK, and chipselect signals. SPI slaves connected to a bus using this driver are configured as usual, except that the spi_board_info.controller_data holds the GPIO number for the chipselect used by this controller driver.
Note that this driver often won't achieve even 1 Mbit/sec speeds, making it unusually slow for SPI. If your platform can inline GPIO operations, you should be able to leverage that for better speed with a custom version of this driver; see the source code.

entry.name: SPI_IMG_SPFI
entry.label: IMG SPFI controller
entry.help: This enables support for the SPFI master controller found on IMG SoCs.

entry.name: SPI_IMX
entry.label: Freescale i.MX SPI controllers
entry.help: This enables using the Freescale i.MX SPI controllers in master mode.

entry.name: SPI_LM70_LLP
entry.label: Parallel port adapter for LM70 eval board (DEVELOPMENT)
entry.help: This driver supports the NS LM70 LLP Evaluation Board, which interfaces to an LM70 temperature sensor using a parallel port.

entry.name: SPI_LP8841_RTC
entry.label: ICP DAS LP-8841 SPI Controller for RTC
entry.help:
This driver provides an SPI master device to drive Maxim DS-1302 real time clock.
Say N here unless you plan to run the kernel on an ICP DAS LP-8x4x industrial computer.

entry.name: SPI_MPC52xx
entry.label: Freescale MPC52xx SPI (non-PSC) controller support
entry.help: This drivers supports the MPC52xx SPI controller in master SPI mode.

entry.name: SPI_MPC52xx_PSC
entry.label: Freescale MPC52xx PSC SPI controller
entry.help: This enables using the Freescale MPC52xx Programmable Serial Controller in master SPI mode.

entry.name: SPI_MPC512x_PSC
entry.label: Freescale MPC512x PSC SPI controller
entry.help: This enables using the Freescale MPC5121 Programmable Serial Controller in SPI master mode.

entry.name: SPI_FSL_SPI
entry.label: Freescale SPI controller and Aeroflex Gaisler GRLIB SPI controller
entry.help: This enables using the Freescale SPI controllers in master mode. MPC83xx platform uses the controller in cpu mode or CPM/QE mode. MPC8569 uses the controller in QE mode, MPC8610 in cpu mode. This also enables using the Aeroflex Gaisler GRLIB SPI controller in master mode.

entry.name: SPI_FSL_DSPI
entry.label: Freescale DSPI controller
entry.help: This enables support for the Freescale DSPI controller in master mode. VF610 platform uses the controller.

entry.name: SPI_FSL_ESPI
entry.label: Freescale eSPI controller
entry.help: This enables using the Freescale eSPI controllers in master mode. From MPC8536, 85xx platform uses the controller, and all P10xx, P20xx, P30xx,P40xx, P50xx uses this controller.

entry.name: SPI_MESON_SPIFC
entry.label: Amlogic Meson SPIFC controller

entry.name: SPI_MT65XX
entry.label: MediaTek SPI controller
entry.help: This selects the MediaTek(R) SPI bus driver. If you want to use MediaTek(R) SPI interface, say Y or M here.If you are not sure, say N. SPI drivers for Mediatek MT65XX and MT81XX series ARM SoCs.

entry.name: SPI_NUC900
entry.label: Nuvoton NUC900 series SPI
entry.help: SPI driver for Nuvoton NUC900 series ARM SoCs

entry.name: SPI_OC_TINY
entry.label: OpenCores tiny SPI
entry.help: This is the driver for OpenCores tiny SPI master controller.

entry.name: SPI_OCTEON
entry.label: Cavium OCTEON SPI controller
entry.help: SPI host driver for the hardware found on some Cavium OCTEON SOCs.

entry.name: SPI_OMAP_UWIRE
entry.label: OMAP1 MicroWire
entry.help: This hooks up to the MicroWire controller on OMAP1 chips.

entry.name: SPI_OMAP24XX
entry.label: McSPI driver for OMAP
entry.help: SPI master controller for OMAP24XX and later Multichannel SPI (McSPI) modules.

entry.name: SPI_TI_QSPI
entry.label: DRA7xxx QSPI controller support
entry.help: QSPI master controller for DRA7xxx used for flash devices. This device supports single, dual and quad read support, while it only supports single write mode.

entry.name: SPI_OMAP_100K
entry.label: OMAP SPI 100K
entry.help: OMAP SPI 100K master controller for omap7xx boards.

entry.name: SPI_ORION
entry.label: Orion SPI master
entry.help: This enables using the SPI master controller on the Orion chips.

entry.name: SPI_PIC32
entry.label: Microchip PIC32 series SPI
entry.help: SPI driver for Microchip PIC32 SPI master controller.

entry.name: SPI_PIC32_SQI
entry.label: Microchip PIC32 Quad SPI driver
entry.help: SPI driver for PIC32 Quad SPI controller.

entry.name: SPI_PL022
entry.label: ARM AMBA PL022 SSP controller
entry.help: This selects the ARM(R) AMBA(R) PrimeCell PL022 SSP controller. If you have an embedded system with an AMBA(R) bus and a PL022 controller, say Y or M here.

entry.name: SPI_PPC4xx
entry.label: PPC4xx SPI Controller
entry.help: This selects a driver for the PPC4xx SPI Controller.

entry.name: SPI_PXA2XX
entry.label: PXA2xx SSP SPI master
entry.help: This enables using a PXA2xx or Sodaville SSP port as a SPI master controller. The driver can be configured to use any SSP port and additional documentation can be found a Documentation/spi/pxa2xx.

entry.name: SPI_ROCKCHIP
entry.label: Rockchip SPI controller driver
entry.help:
This selects a driver for Rockchip SPI controller.
If you say yes to this option, support will be included for RK3066, RK3188 and RK3288 families of SPI controller. Rockchip SPI controller support DMA transport and PIO mode. The main usecase of this controller is to use spi flash as boot device.

entry.name: SPI_RB4XX
entry.label: Mikrotik RB4XX SPI master
entry.help: SPI controller driver for the Mikrotik RB4xx series boards.

entry.name: SPI_RSPI
entry.label: Renesas RSPI/QSPI controller
entry.help: SPI driver for Renesas RSPI and QSPI blocks.

entry.name: SPI_QUP
entry.label: Qualcomm SPI controller with QUP interface
entry.help:
Qualcomm Universal Peripheral (QUP) core is an AHB slave that provides a common data path (an output FIFO and an input FIFO) for serial peripheral interface (SPI) mini-core. SPI in master mode supports up to 50MHz, up to four chip selects, programmable data path from 4 bits to 32 bits and numerous protocol variants.
This driver can also be built as a module. If so, the module will be called spi_qup.

entry.name: SPI_S3C24XX
entry.label: Samsung S3C24XX series SPI
entry.help: SPI driver for Samsung S3C24XX series ARM SoCs

entry.name: SPI_S3C24XX_FIQ
entry.label: S3C24XX driver with FIQ pseudo-DMA
entry.help: Enable FIQ support for the S3C24XX SPI driver to provide pseudo DMA by using the fast-interrupt request framework, This allows the driver to get DMA-like performance when there are either no free DMA channels, or when doing transfers that required both TX and RX data paths.

entry.name: SPI_S3C64XX
entry.label: Samsung S3C64XX series type SPI
entry.help: SPI driver for Samsung S3C64XX and newer SoCs.

entry.name: SPI_SC18IS602
entry.label: NXP SC18IS602/602B/603 I2C to SPI bridge
entry.help: SPI driver for NXP SC18IS602/602B/603 I2C to SPI bridge.

entry.name: SPI_SH_MSIOF
entry.label: SuperH MSIOF SPI controller
entry.help: SPI driver for SuperH and SH Mobile MSIOF blocks.

entry.name: SPI_SH
entry.label: SuperH SPI controller
entry.help: SPI driver for SuperH SPI blocks.

entry.name: SPI_SH_SCI
entry.label: SuperH SCI SPI controller
entry.help: SPI driver for SuperH SCI blocks.

entry.name: SPI_SH_HSPI
entry.label: SuperH HSPI controller
entry.help: SPI driver for SuperH HSPI blocks.

entry.name: SPI_SIRF
entry.label: CSR SiRFprimaII SPI controller
entry.help: SPI driver for CSR SiRFprimaII SoCs

entry.name: SPI_ST_SSC4
entry.label: STMicroelectronics SPI SSC-based driver
entry.help: STMicroelectronics SoCs support for SPI. If you say yes to this option, support will be included for the SSC driven SPI.

entry.name: SPI_SUN4I

entry.help: SPI driver for Allwinner sun4i, sun5i and sun7i SoCs

entry.name: SPI_SUN6I

entry.help: This enables using the SPI controller on the Allwinner A31 SoCs.

entry.name: SPI_MXS
entry.label: Freescale MXS SPI controller
entry.help: SPI driver for Freescale MXS devices.

entry.name: SPI_TEGRA114
entry.label: NVIDIA Tegra114 SPI Controller
entry.help: SPI driver for NVIDIA Tegra114 SPI Controller interface. This controller is different than the older SoCs SPI controller and also register interface get changed with this controller.

entry.name: SPI_TEGRA20_SFLASH

entry.help: SPI driver for Nvidia Tegra20 Serial flash Controller interface. The main usecase of this controller is to use spi flash as boot device.

entry.name: SPI_TEGRA20_SLINK
entry.label: Nvidia Tegra20/Tegra30 SLINK Controller
entry.help: SPI driver for Nvidia Tegra20/Tegra30 SLINK Controller interface.

entry.name: SPI_TOPCLIFF_PCH
entry.label: Intel EG20T PCH/LAPIS Semicon IOH(ML7213/ML7223/ML7831) SPI
entry.help:
SPI driver for the Topcliff PCH (Platform Controller Hub) SPI bus used in some x86 embedded processors.
This driver also supports the ML7213/ML7223/ML7831, a companion chip for the Atom E6xx series and compatible with the Intel EG20T PCH.

entry.name: SPI_TXX9
entry.label: Toshiba TXx9 SPI controller
entry.help: SPI driver for Toshiba TXx9 MIPS SoCs

entry.name: SPI_XCOMM
entry.label: Analog Devices AD-FMCOMMS1-EBZ SPI-I2C-bridge driver
entry.help: Support for the SPI-I2C bridge found on the Analog Devices AD-FMCOMMS1-EBZ board.

entry.name: SPI_XILINX

entry.help:
This exposes the SPI controller IP from the Xilinx EDK.
See the "OPB Serial Peripheral Interface (SPI) (v1.00e)" Product Specification document (DS464) for hardware details.
Or for the DS570, see "XPS Serial Peripheral Interface (SPI) (v2.00b)"

entry.name: SPI_XLP
entry.label: Netlogic XLP SPI controller driver
entry.help:
Enable support for the SPI controller on the Netlogic XLP SoCs. Currently supported XLP variants are XLP8XX, XLP3XX, XLP2XX, XLP9XX and XLP5XX.
If you have a Netlogic XLP platform say Y here. If unsure, say N.

entry.name: SPI_XTENSA_XTFPGA
entry.label: Xtensa SPI controller for xtfpga
entry.help:
SPI driver for xtfpga SPI master controller.
This simple SPI master controller is built into xtfpga bitstreams and is used to control daughterboard audio codec. It always transfers 16 bit words in SPI mode 0, automatically asserting CS on transfer start and deasserting on end.

entry.name: SPI_ZYNQMP_GQSPI

entry.help: Enables Xilinx GQSPI controller driver for Zynq UltraScale+ MPSoC.

entry.name: SPI_SPIDEV
entry.label: User mode SPI device driver support
entry.help:
This supports user mode SPI protocol drivers.
Note that this application programming interface is EXPERIMENTAL and hence SUBJECT TO CHANGE WITHOUT NOTICE while it stabilizes.

entry.name: SPI_LOOPBACK_TEST
entry.label: spi loopback test framework support
entry.help:
This enables the SPI loopback testing framework driver
primarily used for development of spi_master drivers and to detect regressions

entry.name: SPI_TLE62X0

entry.help: SPI driver for Infineon TLE62X0 series line driver chips, such as the TLE6220, TLE6230 and TLE6240. This provides a sysfs interface, with each line presented as a kind of GPIO exposing both switch control and diagnostic feedback.

entry.name: SPMI
entry.label: SPMI support
entry.help: SPMI (System Power Management Interface) is a two-wire serial interface between baseband and application processors and Power Management Integrated Circuits (PMIC).

entry.name: SPMI_MSM_PMIC_ARB
entry.label: Qualcomm MSM SPMI Controller (PMIC Arbiter)
entry.help:
If you say yes to this option, support will be included for the built-in SPMI PMIC Arbiter interface on Qualcomm MSM family processors.
This is required for communicating with Qualcomm PMICs and other devices that have the SPMI interface.

entry.name: HSI
entry.label: HSI support
entry.help: The "High speed synchronous Serial Interface" is synchronous serial interface used mainly to connect application engines and cellular modems.

entry.name: OMAP_SSI
entry.label: OMAP SSI hardware driver
entry.help:
SSI is a legacy version of HSI. It is usually used to connect an application engine with a cellular modem. If you say Y here, you will enable the OMAP SSI hardware driver.
If unsure, say N.

entry.name: NOKIA_MODEM
entry.label: Nokia Modem
entry.help:
Say Y here if you want to add support for the modem on Nokia N900 (Nokia RX-51) hardware.
If unsure, say N.

entry.name: CMT_SPEECH
entry.label: CMT speech
entry.help:
If you say Y here, you will enable the CMT speech protocol used by Nokia modems. If you say M the protocol will be available as module named cmt_speech.
If unsure, say N.

entry.name: SSI_PROTOCOL
entry.label: SSI protocol
entry.help:
If you say Y here, you will enable the SSI protocol aka McSAAB.
If unsure, say N.

entry.name: HSI_CHAR
entry.label: HSI/SSI character driver
entry.help: If you say Y here, you will enable the HSI/SSI character driver. This driver provides a simple character device interface for serial communication with the cellular modem over HSI/SSI bus.

entry.name: PPS
entry.label: PPS support
entry.help:
PPS (Pulse Per Second) is a special pulse provided by some GPS antennae. Userland can use it to get a high-precision time reference.
Some antennae's PPS signals are connected with the CD (Carrier Detect) pin of the serial line they use to communicate with the host. In this case use the SERIAL_LINE client support.
Some antennae's PPS signals are connected with some special host inputs so you have to enable the corresponding client support.
To compile this driver as a module, choose M here: the module will be called pps_core.ko.

entry.name: PPS_DEBUG
entry.label: PPS debugging messages
entry.help: Say Y here if you want the PPS support to produce a bunch of debug messages to the system log. Select this if you are having a problem with PPS support and want to see more of what is going on.

entry.name: NTP_PPS
entry.label: PPS kernel consumer support
entry.help:
This option adds support for direct in-kernel time synchronization using an external PPS signal.
It doesn't work on tickless systems at the moment.

entry.name: PPS_CLIENT_KTIMER
entry.label: Kernel timer client (Testing client, use for debug)
entry.help:
If you say yes here you get support for a PPS debugging client which uses a kernel timer to generate the PPS signal.
This driver can also be built as a module. If so, the module will be called pps-ktimer.

entry.name: PPS_CLIENT_LDISC
entry.label: PPS line discipline
entry.help: If you say yes here you get support for a PPS source connected with the CD (Carrier Detect) pin of your serial port.

entry.name: PPS_CLIENT_PARPORT
entry.label: Parallel port PPS client
entry.help: If you say yes here you get support for a PPS source connected with the interrupt pin of your parallel port.

entry.name: PPS_CLIENT_GPIO
entry.label: PPS client using GPIO
entry.help: If you say yes here you get support for a PPS source using GPIO. To be useful you must also register a platform device specifying the GPIO pin and other options, usually in your board setup.

entry.name: PPS_GENERATOR_PARPORT
entry.label: Parallel port PPS signal generator
entry.help: If you say yes here you get support for a PPS signal generator which utilizes STROBE pin of a parallel port to send PPS signals. It uses parport abstraction layer and hrtimers to precisely control the signal.

entry.name: PTP_1588_CLOCK
entry.label: PTP clock support
entry.help:
The IEEE 1588 standard defines a method to precisely synchronize distributed clocks over Ethernet networks. The standard defines a Precision Time Protocol (PTP), which can be used to achieve synchronization within a few dozen microseconds. In addition, with the help of special hardware time stamping units, it can be possible to achieve synchronization to within a few hundred nanoseconds.
This driver adds support for PTP clocks as character devices. If you want to use a PTP clock, then you should also enable at least one clock driver as well.
To compile this driver as a module, choose M here: the module will be called ptp.

entry.name: PTP_1588_CLOCK_GIANFAR
entry.label: Freescale eTSEC as PTP clock
entry.help:
This driver adds support for using the eTSEC as a PTP clock. This clock is only useful if your PTP programs are getting hardware time stamps on the PTP Ethernet packets using the SO_TIMESTAMPING API.
To compile this driver as a module, choose M here: the module will be called gianfar_ptp.

entry.name: PTP_1588_CLOCK_IXP46X
entry.label: Intel IXP46x as PTP clock
entry.help:
This driver adds support for using the IXP46X as a PTP clock. This clock is only useful if your PTP programs are getting hardware time stamps on the PTP Ethernet packets using the SO_TIMESTAMPING API.
To compile this driver as a module, choose M here: the module will be called ptp_ixp46x.

entry.name: DP83640_PHY
entry.label: Driver for the National Semiconductor DP83640 PHYTER
entry.help:
Supports the DP83640 PHYTER with IEEE 1588 features.
This driver adds support for using the DP83640 as a PTP clock. This clock is only useful if your PTP programs are getting hardware time stamps on the PTP Ethernet packets using the SO_TIMESTAMPING API.
In order for this to work, your MAC driver must also implement the skb_tx_timestamp() function.

entry.name: PTP_1588_CLOCK_PCH
entry.label: Intel PCH EG20T as PTP clock
entry.help:
This driver adds support for using the PCH EG20T as a PTP clock. The hardware supports time stamping of PTP packets when using the end-to-end delay (E2E) mechansim. The peer delay mechansim (P2P) is not supported.
This clock is only useful if your PTP programs are getting hardware time stamps on the PTP Ethernet packets using the SO_TIMESTAMPING API.
To compile this driver as a module, choose M here: the module will be called ptp_pch.

entry.name: PINCTRL_IPROC_GPIO
entry.label: Broadcom iProc GPIO (with PINCONF) driver
entry.help:
Say yes here to enable the Broadcom iProc GPIO driver.
The Broadcom iProc based SoCs- Cygnus, NS2, NSP and Stingray, use same GPIO Controller IP hence this driver could be used for all.
The Broadcom Cygnus SoC has 3 GPIO controllers including the ASIU GPIO controller (ASIU), the chipCommonG GPIO controller (CCM), and the always-ON GPIO controller (CRMU/AON). All 3 GPIO controllers are supported by this driver.
The Broadcom NSP has two GPIO controllers including the ChipcommonA GPIO, the ChipcommonB GPIO. Later controller is supported by this driver.
The Broadcom NS2 has two GPIO controller including the CRMU GPIO, the ChipcommonG GPIO. Both controllers are supported by this driver.
The Broadcom Stingray GPIO controllers are supported by this driver.
All above SoCs GPIO controllers support basic PINCONF functions such as bias pull up, pull down, and drive strength configurations, when these pins are muxed to GPIO.
It provides the framework where pins from the individual GPIO can be individually muxed to GPIO function, through interaction with the SoCs IOMUX controller. This features could be used only on SoCs which support individual pin muxing.

entry.name: PINCTRL_CYGNUS_MUX
entry.label: Broadcom Cygnus IOMUX driver
entry.help:
Say yes here to enable the Broadcom Cygnus IOMUX driver.
The Broadcom Cygnus IOMUX driver supports group based IOMUX configuration, with the exception that certain individual pins can be overrided to GPIO function

entry.name: PINCTRL_NSP_GPIO
entry.label: Broadcom NSP GPIO (with PINCONF) driver
entry.help:
Say yes here to enable the Broadcom NSP GPIO driver.
The Broadcom Northstar Plus SoC ChipcommonA GPIO controller is supported by this driver.
The ChipcommonA GPIO controller support basic PINCONF functions such as bias pull up, pull down, and drive strength configurations, when these pins are muxed to GPIO.

entry.name: PINCTRL_NS2_MUX

entry.name: PINCTRL_NSP_MUX

entry.help:
Say yes here to enable the Broadcom NSP SOC IOMUX driver.
The Broadcom Northstar Plus IOMUX driver supports pin based IOMUX configuration, with certain individual pins can be overridden to GPIO function.

entry.name: ARCH_HAVE_CUSTOM_GPIO_H
entry.help: Selecting this config option from the architecture Kconfig allows the architecture to provide a custom asm/gpio.h implementation overriding the default implementations. New uses of this are strongly discouraged.

entry.name: ARCH_WANT_OPTIONAL_GPIOLIB
entry.help: Select this config option from the architecture Kconfig, if it is possible to use gpiolib on the architecture, but let the user decide whether to actually build it or not. Select this instead of ARCH_REQUIRE_GPIOLIB, if your architecture does not depend on GPIOs being available, but rather let the user decide whether he needs it or not.

entry.name: ARCH_REQUIRE_GPIOLIB
entry.help: Platforms select gpiolib if they use this infrastructure for all their GPIOs, usually starting with ones integrated into SOC processors. Selecting this from the architecture code will cause the gpiolib code to always get built in.

entry.name: GPIOLIB
entry.label: GPIO Support
entry.help:
This enables GPIO support through the generic GPIO library. You only need to enable this, if you also want to enable one or more of the GPIO drivers below.
If unsure, say N.

entry.name: DEBUG_GPIO
entry.label: Debug GPIO calls
entry.help: Say Y here to add some extra checks and diagnostics to GPIO calls. These checks help ensure that GPIOs have been properly initialized before they are used, and that sleeping calls are not made from non-sleeping contexts. They can make bitbanged serial protocols slower. The diagnostics help catch the type of setup errors that are most common when setting up new platforms or boards.

entry.name: GPIO_SYSFS
entry.label: /sys/class/gpio/... (sysfs interface)
entry.help:
Say Y here to add a sysfs interface for GPIOs.
This is mostly useful to work around omissions in a system's kernel support. Those are common in custom and semicustom hardware assembled using standard kernels with a minimum of custom patches. In those cases, userspace code may import a given GPIO from the kernel, if no kernel driver requested it.
Kernel drivers may also request that a particular GPIO be exported to userspace; this can be useful when debugging.

entry.name: GPIO_74XX_MMIO
entry.label: GPIO driver for 74xx-ICs with MMIO access
entry.help: Say yes here to support GPIO functionality for 74xx-compatible ICs with MMIO access. Compatible models include: 1 bit: 741G125 (Input), 741G74 (Output) 2 bits: 742G125 (Input), 7474 (Output) 4 bits: 74125 (Input), 74175 (Output) 6 bits: 74365 (Input), 74174 (Output) 8 bits: 74244 (Input), 74273 (Output) 16 bits: 741624 (Input), 7416374 (Output)

entry.name: GPIO_F7188X

entry.name: GPIO_IT87
entry.label: IT87xx GPIO support
entry.help:
Say yes here to support GPIO functionality of IT87xx Super I/O chips.
This driver is tested with ITE IT8728 and IT8732 Super I/O chips, and supports the IT8761E, IT8620E and IT8628E Super I/O chip as well.
To compile this driver as a module, choose M here: the module will be called gpio_it87

entry.name: GPIO_SCH
entry.label: Intel SCH/TunnelCreek/Centerton/Quark X1000 GPIO
entry.help:
Say yes here to support GPIO interface on Intel Poulsbo SCH, Intel Tunnel Creek processor, Intel Centerton processor or Intel Quark X1000 SoC.
The Intel SCH contains a total of 14 GPIO pins. Ten GPIOs are powered by the core power rail and are turned off during sleep modes (S3 and higher). The remaining four GPIOs are powered by the Intel SCH suspend power supply. These GPIOs remain active during S3. The suspend powered GPIOs can be used to wake the system from the Suspend-to-RAM state.
The Intel Tunnel Creek processor has 5 GPIOs powered by the core power rail and 9 from suspend power supply.
The Intel Centerton processor has a total of 30 GPIO pins. Twenty-one are powered by the core power rail and 9 from the suspend power supply.
The Intel Quark X1000 SoC has 2 GPIOs powered by the core power well and 6 from the suspend power well.

entry.name: GPIO_SCH311X
entry.label: SMSC SCH311x SuperI/O GPIO

Driver to enable the GPIOs found on SMSC SMSC SCH3112, SCH3114 and SCH3116 "Super I/O" chipsets.
To compile this driver as a module, choose M here: the module will be called gpio-sch311x.

entry.name: GPIO_TS5500
entry.label: TS-5500 DIO blocks and compatibles
entry.help: This driver supports Digital I/O exposed by pin blocks found on some Technologic Systems platforms. It includes, but is not limited to, 3 blocks of the TS-5500: DIO1, DIO2 and the LCD port, and the TS-5600 LCD port.

entry.name: GPIO_WS16C48
entry.label: WinSystems WS16C48 GPIO support
entry.help: Enables GPIO support for the WinSystems WS16C48. The base port addresses for the devices may be configured via the base module parameter. The interrupt line numbers for the devices may be configured via the irq module parameter.

entry.name: GPIO_ADP5588
entry.label: ADP5588 I2C GPIO expander

entry.name: GPIO_ADP5588_IRQ
entry.label: Interrupt controller support for ADP5588
entry.help: Say yes here to enable the adp5588 to be used as an interrupt controller. It requires the driver to be built in the kernel.

entry.name: GPIO_ADNP
entry.label: Avionic Design N-bit GPIO expander
entry.help: This option enables support for N GPIOs found on Avionic Design I2C GPIO expanders. The register space will be extended by powers of two, so the controller will need to accommodate for that. For example: if a controller provides 48 pins, 6 registers will be enough to represent all pins, but the driver will assume a register layout for 64 pins (8 registers).

entry.name: GPIO_MAX7300
entry.label: Maxim MAX7300 GPIO expander
entry.help: GPIO driver for Maxim MAX7300 I2C-based GPIO expander.

entry.name: GPIO_MAX732X
entry.label: MAX7319, MAX7320-7327 I2C Port Expanders
entry.help:
Say yes here to support the MAX7319, MAX7320-7327 series of I2C Port Expanders. Each IO port on these chips has a fixed role of Input (designated by 'I'), Push-Pull Output ('O'), or Open-Drain Input and Output (designed by 'P'). The combinations are listed below:
8 bits: max7319 (8I), max7320 (8O), max7321 (8P), max7322 (4I4O), max7323 (4P4O)
16 bits: max7324 (8I8O), max7325 (8P8O), max7326 (4I12O), max7327 (4P12O)
Board setup code must specify the model to use, and the start number for these GPIOs.

entry.name: GPIO_MAX732X_IRQ
entry.label: Interrupt controller support for MAX732x
entry.help: Say yes here to enable the max732x to be used as an interrupt controller. It requires the driver to be built in the kernel.

entry.name: GPIO_MC9S08DZ60
entry.label: MX35 3DS BOARD MC9S08DZ60 GPIO functions
entry.help: Select this to enable the MC9S08DZ60 GPIO driver

entry.name: GPIO_PCA953X
entry.label: PCA95[357]x, PCA9698, TCA64xx, and MAX7310 I/O ports
entry.help:
Say yes here to provide access to several register-oriented SMBus I/O expanders, made mostly by NXP or TI. Compatible models include:
4 bits: pca9536, pca9537
8 bits: max7310, max7315, pca6107, pca9534, pca9538, pca9554, pca9556, pca9557, pca9574, tca6408, xra1202
16 bits: max7312, max7313, pca9535, pca9539, pca9555, pca9575, tca6416
24 bits: tca6424
40 bits: pca9505, pca9698

entry.name: GPIO_PCA953X_IRQ
entry.label: Interrupt controller support for PCA953x
entry.help: Say yes here to enable the pca953x to be used as an interrupt controller. It requires the driver to be built in the kernel.

entry.name: GPIO_PCF857X
entry.label: PCF857x, PCA{85,96}7x, and MAX732[89] I2C GPIO expanders
entry.help:
Say yes here to provide access to most "quasi-bidirectional" I2C GPIO expanders used for additional digital outputs or inputs. Most of these parts are from NXP, though TI is a second source for some of them. Compatible models include:
8 bits: pcf8574, pcf8574a, pca8574, pca8574a, pca9670, pca9672, pca9674, pca9674a, max7328, max7329
16 bits: pcf8575, pcf8575c, pca8575, pca9671, pca9673, pca9675
Your board setup code will need to declare the expanders in use, and assign numbers to the GPIOs they expose. Those GPIOs can then be used from drivers and other kernel code, just like other GPIOs, but only accessible from task contexts.
This driver provides an in-kernel interface to those GPIOs using platform-neutral GPIO calls.

entry.name: GPIO_SX150X

Say yes here to provide support for Semtech SX150-series I2C GPIO expanders. Compatible models include:

entry.name: GPIO_AMD8111
entry.label: AMD 8111 GPIO driver

The AMD 8111 south bridge contains 32 GPIO pins which can be used.
Note, that usually system firmware/ACPI handles GPIO pins on their own and users might easily break their systems with uncarefull usage of this driver!
If unsure, say N

entry.name: GPIO_BT8XX
entry.label: BT8XX GPIO abuser
entry.help:
The BT8xx frame grabber chip has 24 GPIO pins that can be abused as a cheap PCI GPIO card.
This chip can be found on Miro, Hauppauge and STB TV-cards.
The card needs to be physically altered for using it as a GPIO card. For more information on how to build a GPIO card from a BT8xx TV card, see the documentation file at Documentation/bt8xxgpio.txt
If unsure, say N.

entry.name: GPIO_INTEL_MID

entry.help: Say Y here to support Intel MID GPIO.

entry.name: GPIO_MERRIFIELD
entry.label: Intel Merrifield GPIO support
entry.help: Say Y here to support Intel Merrifield GPIO.

entry.name: GPIO_ML_IOH
entry.label: OKI SEMICONDUCTOR ML7213 IOH GPIO support
entry.help: ML7213 is companion chip for Intel Atom E6xx series. This driver can be used for OKI SEMICONDUCTOR ML7213 IOH(Input/Output Hub) which is for IVI(In-Vehicle Infotainment) use. This driver can access the IOH's GPIO device.

entry.name: GPIO_PCH
entry.label: Intel EG20T PCH/LAPIS Semiconductor IOH(ML7223/ML7831) GPIO
entry.help:
This driver is for PCH(Platform controller Hub) GPIO of Intel Topcliff which is an IOH(Input/Output Hub) for x86 embedded processor. This driver can access PCH GPIO device.
This driver also can be used for LAPIS Semiconductor IOH(Input/ Output Hub), ML7223 and ML7831. ML7223 IOH is for MP(Media Phone) use. ML7831 IOH is for general purpose use. ML7223/ML7831 is companion chip for Intel Atom E6xx series. ML7223/ML7831 is completely compatible for Intel EG20T PCH.

entry.name: GPIO_RDC321X

entry.name: GPIO_SODAVILLE

entry.help: Say Y here to support Intel Sodaville GPIO.

entry.name: GPIO_MAX7301

entry.help: GPIO driver for Maxim MAX7301 SPI-based GPIO expander.

entry.name: GPIO_MC33880

entry.name: GPIO_PISOSR

entry.name: GPIO_MCP23S08

entry.name: GPIO_VIPERBOARD
entry.label: Viperboard GPIO a & b support
entry.help: Say yes here to access the GPIO signals of Nano River Technologies Viperboard. There are two GPIO chips on the board: gpioa and gpiob. See viperboard API specification and Nano River Tech's viperboard.h for detailed meaning of the module parameters.

entry.name: W1
entry.label: Dallas's 1-wire support
entry.help:
Dallas' 1-wire bus is useful to connect slow 1-pin devices such as iButtons and thermal sensors.
If you want W1 support, you should say Y here.
This W1 support can also be built as a module. If so, the module will be called wire.

entry.name: W1_CON
entry.label: Userspace communication over connector
entry.help: This allows to communicate with userspace using connector. For more information see <file:Documentation/connector/connector.txt>. There are three types of messages between w1 core and userspace: 1. Events. They are generated each time new master or slave device found either due to automatic or requested search. 2. Userspace commands. Includes read/write and search/alarm search commands. 3. Replies to userspace commands.

entry.name: W1_MASTER_MATROX
entry.label: Matrox G400 transport layer for 1-wire
entry.help:
Say Y here if you want to communicate with your 1-wire devices using Matrox's G400 GPIO pins.
This support is also available as a module. If so, the module will be called matrox_w1.

entry.name: W1_MASTER_DS2490
entry.label: DS2490 USB <-> W1 transport layer for 1-wire
entry.help:
Say Y here if you want to have a driver for DS2490 based USB <-> W1 bridges, for example DS9490*.
This support is also available as a module. If so, the module will be called ds2490.

entry.name: W1_MASTER_DS2482
entry.label: Maxim DS2482 I2C to 1-Wire bridge
entry.help:
If you say yes here you get support for the Maxim DS2482 I2C to 1-Wire bridge.
This driver can also be built as a module. If so, the module will be called ds2482.

entry.name: W1_MASTER_MXC
entry.label: Freescale MXC 1-wire busmaster
entry.help: Say Y here to enable MXC 1-wire host

entry.name: W1_MASTER_DS1WM
entry.label: Maxim DS1WM 1-wire busmaster
entry.help: Say Y here to enable the DS1WM 1-wire driver, such as that in HP iPAQ devices like h5xxx, h2200, and ASIC3-based like hx4700.

entry.name: W1_MASTER_GPIO
entry.label: GPIO 1-wire busmaster
entry.help:
Say Y here if you want to communicate with your 1-wire devices using GPIO pins. This driver uses the GPIO API to control the wire.
This support is also available as a module. If so, the module will be called w1-gpio.

entry.name: HDQ_MASTER_OMAP
entry.label: OMAP HDQ driver
entry.help: Say Y here if you want support for the 1-wire or HDQ Interface on an OMAP processor.

entry.name: W1_SLAVE_THERM
entry.label: Thermal family implementation
entry.help: Say Y here if you want to connect 1-wire thermal sensors to your wire.

entry.name: W1_SLAVE_SMEM
entry.label: Simple 64bit memory family implementation
entry.help: Say Y here if you want to connect 1-wire simple 64bit memory rom(ds2401/ds2411/ds1990*) to your wire.

entry.name: W1_SLAVE_DS2408
entry.label: 8-Channel Addressable Switch (IO Expander) 0x29 family support (DS2408)
entry.help: Say Y here if you want to use a 1-wire DS2408 8-Channel Addressable Switch device support

entry.name: W1_SLAVE_DS2408_READBACK
entry.label: Read-back values written to DS2408's output register
entry.help:
Enabling this will cause the driver to read back the values written to the chip's output register in order to detect errors.
This is slower but useful when debugging chips and/or busses.

entry.name: W1_SLAVE_DS2413
entry.label: Dual Channel Addressable Switch 0x3a family support (DS2413)
entry.help: Say Y here if you want to use a 1-wire DS2413 Dual Channel Addressable Switch device support

entry.name: W1_SLAVE_DS2406
entry.label: Dual Channel Addressable Switch 0x12 family support (DS2406)
entry.help: Say Y or M here if you want to use a 1-wire DS2406 Dual Channel Addressable Switch. EPROM read/write support for these devices is not implemented.

entry.name: W1_SLAVE_DS2423
entry.label: Counter 1-wire device (DS2423)
entry.help:
If you enable this you can read the counter values available in the DS2423 chipset from the w1_slave file under the sys file system.
Say Y here if you want to use a 1-wire counter family device (DS2423).

entry.name: W1_SLAVE_DS2433_CRC

entry.name: W1_SLAVE_DS2760

If you are unsure, say N.

entry.name: W1_SLAVE_DS2780

entry.name: W1_SLAVE_DS2781

entry.name: POWER_SUPPLY

entry.name: POWER_SUPPLY_DEBUG

entry.name: PDA_POWER

entry.help: Say Y here to enable generic power driver for PDAs and phones with one or two external power supplies (AC/USB) connected to main and backup batteries, and optional builtin charger.

entry.name: APM_POWER

entry.help: Say Y here to enable support APM status emulation using battery class devices.

entry.name: GENERIC_ADC_BATTERY

entry.name: MAX8925_POWER

entry.name: WM8350_POWER

entry.help: Say Y here to enable support for batteries with BQ27xxx chips connected over an I2C bus.

entry.name: BATTERY_DA9030

entry.help: Say Y here to enable support for batteries charger integrated into DA9030 PMIC.

entry.name: BATTERY_DA9052
entry.label: Dialog DA9052 Battery
entry.help: Say Y here to enable support for batteries charger integrated into DA9052 PMIC.

entry.name: CHARGER_DA9150

entry.help:
Say Y here to enable support for charger unit of the DA9150 Integrated Charger & Fuel-Gauge IC.

entry.name: BATTERY_DA9150

entry.help:
Say Y here to enable support for the Fuel-Gauge unit of the DA9150 Integrated Charger & Fuel-Gauge IC
This driver can also be built as a module. If so, the module will be called da9150-fg.

entry.name: AXP288_CHARGER
entry.label: X-Powers AXP288 Charger

entry.name: AXP288_FUEL_GAUGE
entry.label: X-Powers AXP288 Fuel Gauge
entry.help: Say yes here to have support for X-Power power management IC (PMIC) Fuel Gauge. The device provides battery statistics and status monitoring as well as alerts for battery over/under voltage and over/under temperature.

entry.name: BATTERY_MAX17040
entry.label: Maxim MAX17040 Fuel Gauge
entry.help: MAX17040 is fuel-gauge systems for lithium-ion (Li+) batteries in handheld and portable equipment. The MAX17040 is configured to operate with a single lithium cell

entry.name: BATTERY_MAX17042
entry.label: Maxim MAX17042/17047/17050/8997/8966 Fuel Gauge
entry.help: MAX17042 is fuel-gauge systems for lithium-ion (Li+) batteries in handheld and portable equipment. The MAX17042 is configured to operate with a single lithium cell. MAX8997 and MAX8966 are multi-function devices that include fuel gauages that are compatible with MAX17042. This driver also supports max17047/50 chips which are improved version of max17042.

entry.name: BATTERY_Z2

entry.help: Say Y to include support for the battery on the Zipit Z2.

entry.name: BATTERY_S3C_ADC
entry.label: Battery driver for Samsung ADC based monitoring
entry.help: Say Y here to enable support for iPAQ h1930/h1940/rx1950 battery

entry.name: BATTERY_TWL4030_MADC

entry.help: Say Y here to enable this dumb driver for batteries managed through the TWL4030 MADC.

entry.name: CHARGER_88PM860X

entry.help: Say Y here to enable charger for Marvell 88PM860x chip.

entry.name: CHARGER_PCF50633

entry.name: BATTERY_INTEL_MID

entry.help: Say Y here to enable the battery driver on Intel MID platforms.

entry.name: BATTERY_RX51

entry.name: CHARGER_ISP1704

entry.help: Say Y to enable support for USB Charger Detection with ISP1707/ISP1704 USB transceivers.

entry.name: CHARGER_MAX8903
entry.label: MAX8903 Battery DC-DC Charger for USB and Adapter Power
entry.help: Say Y to enable support for the MAX8903 DC-DC charger and sysfs. The driver supports controlling charger-enable and current-limit pins based on the status of charger connections with interrupt handlers.

entry.name: CHARGER_TWL4030
entry.label: OMAP TWL4030 BCI charger driver
entry.help: Say Y here to enable support for TWL4030 Battery Charge Interface.

entry.name: CHARGER_LP8727

This driver can be build as a module. If so, the module will be called gpio-charger.

entry.name: CHARGER_MANAGER
entry.label: Battery charger manager for multiple chargers
entry.help: Say Y to enable charger-manager support, which allows multiple chargers attached to a battery and multiple batteries attached to a system. The charger-manager also can monitor charging status in runtime and in suspend-to-RAM by waking up the system periodically with help of suspend_again support.

entry.name: CHARGER_MAX14577

entry.help: Say Y to enable support for the battery charger control sysfs and platform data of MAX14577/77836 MUICs.

entry.name: CHARGER_MAX77693

entry.help: Say Y to enable support for the Maxim MAX77693 battery charger.

entry.name: CHARGER_MAX8997

entry.help: Say Y to enable support for the battery charger control sysfs and platform data of MAX8997/LP3974 PMICs.

entry.name: CHARGER_MAX8998
entry.label: Maxim MAX8998/LP3974 PMIC battery charger driver
entry.help: Say Y to enable support for the battery charger control sysfs and platform data of MAX8998/LP3974 PMICs.

entry.name: CHARGER_QCOM_SMBB
entry.label: Qualcomm Switch-Mode Battery Charger and Boost
entry.help: Say Y to include support for the Switch-Mode Battery Charger and Boost (SMBB) hardware found in Qualcomm PM8941 PMICs. The charger is an integrated, single-cell lithium-ion battery charger. DT configuration is required for loading, see the devicetree documentation for more detail. The base name for this driver is 'pm8941_charger'.

entry.help: Say Y here to enable support for battery charging with TPS65090 PMIC chips.

entry.name: CHARGER_TPS65217

entry.help: Say Y here to enable support for battery charging with TPS65217 PMIC chips.

entry.name: BATTERY_GAUGE_LTC2941
entry.label: LTC2941/LTC2943 Battery Gauge Driver
entry.help: Say Y here to include support for LTC2941 and LTC2943 Battery Gauge IC. The driver reports the charge count continuously, and measures the voltage and temperature every 10 seconds.

entry.name: AB8500_BM
entry.label: AB8500 Battery Management Driver
entry.help: Say Y to include support for AB8500 battery management.

entry.name: BATTERY_GOLDFISH

entry.help: Say Y to enable support for the battery and AC power in the Goldfish emulator.

entry.name: BATTERY_RT5033

entry.help: This adds support for battery fuel gauge in Richtek RT5033 PMIC. The fuelgauge calculates and determines the battery state of charge according to battery open circuit voltage.

entry.name: CHARGER_RT9455

entry.help: Say Y to enable support for Richtek RT9455 battery charger.

entry.name: AXP20X_POWER

entry.help: This driver provides support for the power supply features of AXP20x PMIC.

entry.name: POWER_RESET
entry.label: Board level reset or power off
entry.help:
Provides a number of drivers which either reset a complete board or shut it down, by manipulating the main power supply on the board.
Say Y here to enable board reset and power off

entry.name: POWER_RESET_AS3722

entry.help: This driver supports turning off board via a ams AS3722 power-off.

entry.name: POWER_RESET_AT91_POWEROFF

entry.name: POWER_RESET_AXXIA

entry.help:

Say Y here if you have a Broadcom Kona-based board and you wish to have restart support.

entry.name: POWER_RESET_BRCMSTB
entry.label: Broadcom STB reset driver
entry.help:
This driver provides restart support for Broadcom STB boards.
Say Y here if you have a Broadcom STB board and you wish to have restart support.

entry.name: POWER_RESET_GPIO
entry.label: GPIO power-off driver
entry.help: This driver supports turning off your board via a GPIO line. If your board needs a GPIO high/low to power down, say Y and create a binding in your devicetree.

entry.name: POWER_RESET_GPIO_RESTART
entry.label: GPIO restart driver
entry.help: This driver supports restarting your board via a GPIO line. If your board needs a GPIO high/low to restart, say Y and create a binding in your devicetree.

entry.name: POWER_RESET_HISI
entry.label: Hisilicon power-off driver
entry.help: Reboot support for Hisilicon boards.

entry.name: POWER_RESET_IMX
entry.label: IMX6 power-off driver
entry.help: This driver support power off external PMIC by PMIC_ON_REQ on i.mx6 boards.If you want to use other pin to control external power,please say N here or disable in dts to make sure pm_power_off never be overwrote wrongly by this driver.

entry.name: POWER_RESET_MSM
entry.label: Qualcomm MSM power-off driver
entry.help: Power off and restart support for Qualcomm boards.

entry.name: POWER_RESET_LTC2952
entry.label: LTC2952 PowerPath power-off driver
entry.help: This driver supports an external powerdown trigger and board power down via the LTC2952. Bindings are made in the device tree.

entry.name: POWER_RESET_QNAP

entry.help:
This driver supports turning off QNAP NAS devices by sending commands to the microcontroller which controls the main power.
Say Y if you have a QNAP NAS.

entry.name: POWER_RESET_RESTART
entry.label: Restart power-off driver
entry.help: Some boards don't actually have the ability to power off. Instead they restart, and u-boot holds the SoC until the user presses a key. u-boot then boots into Linux.

entry.name: POWER_RESET_VERSATILE

entry.help: Power off and restart support for ARM Versatile family of reference boards.

entry.help: Power off and reset support for the ARM Ltd. Versatile Express boards.

entry.name: POWER_RESET_XGENE
entry.label: APM SoC X-Gene reset driver
entry.help: Reboot support for the APM SoC X-Gene Eval boards.

entry.name: POWER_RESET_KEYSTONE
entry.label: Keystone reset driver
entry.help: Reboot support for the KEYSTONE SoCs.

entry.name: POWER_RESET_SYSCON
entry.label: Generic SYSCON regmap reset driver
entry.help: Reboot support for generic SYSCON mapped register reset.

entry.name: POWER_RESET_SYSCON_POWEROFF
entry.label: Generic SYSCON regmap poweroff driver
entry.help: Poweroff support for generic SYSCON mapped register poweroff.

entry.name: POWER_RESET_RMOBILE

entry.name: POWER_RESET_ZX
entry.label: ZTE SoCs reset driver
entry.help: Reboot support for ZTE SoCs.

entry.name: SYSCON_REBOOT_MODE
entry.label: Generic SYSCON regmap reboot mode driver
entry.help: Say y here will enable reboot mode driver. This will get reboot mode arguments and store it in SYSCON mapped register, then the bootloader can read it to take different action according to the mode.

entry.name: POWER_AVS
entry.label: Adaptive Voltage Scaling class support
entry.help:
AVS is a power management technique which finely controls the operating voltage of a device in order to optimize (i.e. reduce) its power consumption. At a given operating point the voltage is adapted depending on static factors (chip manufacturing process) and dynamic factors (temperature depending performance). AVS is also called SmartReflex on OMAP devices.
Say Y here to enable Adaptive Voltage Scaling class support.

entry.name: ROCKCHIP_IODOMAIN
entry.label: Rockchip IO domain support
entry.help: Say y here to enable support io domains on Rockchip SoCs. It is necessary for the io domain setting of the SoC to match the voltage supplied by the regulators.

entry.name: HWMON
entry.label: Hardware Monitoring support
entry.help:
Hardware monitoring devices let you monitor the hardware health of a system. Most modern motherboards include such a device. It can include temperature sensors, voltage sensors, fan speed sensors and various additional features such as the ability to control the speed of the fans. If you want this support you should say Y here and also to the specific driver(s) for your sensors chip(s) below.
To find out which specific driver(s) you need, use the sensors-detect script from the lm_sensors package. Read <file:Documentation/hwmon/userspace-tools> for details.
This support can also be built as a module. If so, the module will be called hwmon.

entry.name: HWMON_DEBUG_CHIP
entry.label: Hardware Monitoring Chip debugging messages
entry.help: Say Y here if you want the I2C chip drivers to produce a bunch of debug messages to the system log. Select this if you are having a problem with I2C support and want to see more of what is going on.

entry.name: SENSORS_AB8500
entry.label: AB8500 thermal monitoring
entry.help:
If you say yes here you get support for the thermal sensor part of the AB8500 chip. The driver includes thermal management for AB8500 die and two GPADC channels. The GPADC channel are preferably used to access sensors outside the AB8500 chip.
This driver can also be built as a module. If so, the module will be called abx500-temp.

entry.name: SENSORS_ABITUGURU
entry.label: Abit uGuru (rev 1 & 2)
entry.help:
If you say yes here you get support for the sensor part of the first and second revision of the Abit uGuru chip. The voltage and frequency control parts of the Abit uGuru are not supported. The Abit uGuru chip can be found on Abit uGuru featuring motherboards (most modern Abit motherboards from before end 2005). For more info and a list of which motherboards have which revision see Documentation/hwmon/abituguru
This driver can also be built as a module. If so, the module will be called abituguru.

entry.name: SENSORS_ABITUGURU3
entry.label: Abit uGuru (rev 3)
entry.help:
If you say yes here you get support for the sensor part of the third revision of the Abit uGuru chip. Only reading the sensors and their settings is supported. The third revision of the Abit uGuru chip can be found on recent Abit motherboards (since end 2005). For more info and a list of which motherboards have which revision see Documentation/hwmon/abituguru3
This driver can also be built as a module. If so, the module will be called abituguru3.

entry.name: SENSORS_AD7314
entry.label: Analog Devices AD7314 and compatibles
entry.help:
If you say yes here you get support for the Analog Devices AD7314, ADT7301 and ADT7302 temperature sensors.
This driver can also be built as a module. If so, the module will be called ad7314.

entry.name: SENSORS_AD7414
entry.label: Analog Devices AD7414
entry.help:
If you say yes here you get support for the Analog Devices AD7414 temperature monitoring chip.
This driver can also be built as a module. If so, the module will be called ad7414.

entry.name: SENSORS_AD7418
entry.label: Analog Devices AD7416, AD7417 and AD7418
entry.help:
If you say yes here you get support for the Analog Devices AD7416, AD7417 and AD7418 temperature monitoring chips.
This driver can also be built as a module. If so, the module will be called ad7418.

entry.name: SENSORS_ADM1021

entry.help:
If you say yes here you get support for Analog Devices ADM1021 and ADM1023 sensor chips and clones: Maxim MAX1617 and MAX1617A, Genesys Logic GL523SM, National Semiconductor LM84 and TI THMC10.
This driver can also be built as a module. If so, the module will be called adm1021.

entry.name: SENSORS_ADM1025
entry.label: Analog Devices ADM1025 and compatibles
entry.help:
If you say yes here you get support for Analog Devices ADM1025 and Philips NE1619 sensor chips.
This driver can also be built as a module. If so, the module will be called adm1025.

entry.name: SENSORS_ADM1026
entry.label: Analog Devices ADM1026 and compatibles
entry.help:
If you say yes here you get support for Analog Devices ADM1026 sensor chip.
This driver can also be built as a module. If so, the module will be called adm1026.

entry.name: SENSORS_ADM1029
entry.label: Analog Devices ADM1029
entry.help:
If you say yes here you get support for Analog Devices ADM1029 sensor chip. Very rare chip, please let us know you use it.
This driver can also be built as a module. If so, the module will be called adm1029.

entry.name: SENSORS_ADM1031
entry.label: Analog Devices ADM1031 and compatibles
entry.help:
If you say yes here you get support for Analog Devices ADM1031 and ADM1030 sensor chips.
This driver can also be built as a module. If so, the module will be called adm1031.

entry.name: SENSORS_ADM9240
entry.label: Analog Devices ADM9240 and compatibles
entry.help:
If you say yes here you get support for Analog Devices ADM9240, Dallas DS1780, National Semiconductor LM81 sensor chips.
This driver can also be built as a module. If so, the module will be called adm9240.

entry.name: SENSORS_ADT7X10
entry.help:
This module contains common code shared by the ADT7310/ADT7320 and ADT7410/ADT7420 temperature monitoring chip drivers.
If build as a module, the module will be called adt7x10.

entry.name: SENSORS_ADT7310
entry.label: Analog Devices ADT7310/ADT7320
entry.help:
If you say yes here you get support for the Analog Devices ADT7310 and ADT7320 temperature monitoring chips.
This driver can also be built as a module. If so, the module will be called adt7310.

entry.name: SENSORS_ADT7410
entry.label: Analog Devices ADT7410/ADT7420
entry.help:
If you say yes here you get support for the Analog Devices ADT7410 and ADT7420 temperature monitoring chips.
This driver can also be built as a module. If so, the module will be called adt7410.

entry.name: SENSORS_ADT7411

entry.name: SENSORS_APPLESMC
entry.label: Apple SMC (Motion sensor, light sensor, keyboard backlight)
entry.help:
This driver provides support for the Apple System Management Controller, which provides an accelerometer (Apple Sudden Motion Sensor), light sensors, temperature sensors, keyboard backlight control and fan control.
Only Intel-based Apple's computers are supported (MacBook Pro, MacBook, MacMini).
Data from the different sensors, keyboard backlight control and fan control are accessible via sysfs.
This driver also provides an absolute input class device, allowing the laptop to act as a pinball machine-esque joystick.
Say Y here if you have an applicable laptop and want to experience the awesome power of applesmc.

entry.name: SENSORS_LM75
entry.label: National Semiconductor LM75 and compatibles
entry.help:
If you say yes here you get support for one common type of temperature sensor chip, with models including:
- Analog Devices ADT75 - Dallas Semiconductor DS75, DS1775 and DS7505 - Global Mixed-mode Technology (GMT) G751 - Maxim MAX6625 and MAX6626 - Microchip MCP980x - National Semiconductor LM75, LM75A - NXP's LM75A - ST Microelectronics STDS75 - TelCom (now Microchip) TCN75 - Texas Instruments TMP100, TMP101, TMP105, TMP112, TMP75, TMP175, TMP275
This driver supports driver model based binding through board specific I2C device tables.
It also supports the "legacy" style of driver binding. To use that with some chips which don't replicate LM75 quirks exactly, you may need the "force" module parameter.
This driver can also be built as a module. If so, the module will be called lm75.

entry.name: SENSORS_PC87427
entry.label: National Semiconductor PC87427
entry.help:
If you say yes here you get access to the hardware monitoring functions of the National Semiconductor PC87427 Super-I/O chip. The chip has two distinct logical devices, one for fan speed monitoring and control, and one for voltage and temperature monitoring. Fan speed monitoring and control are supported, as well as temperature monitoring. Voltages aren't supported yet.
This driver can also be built as a module. If so, the module will be called pc87427.

Currently, this driver supports NCP15WB473, NCP18WB473, NCP21WB473, NCP03WB473, NCP15WL333, NCP03WF104 and NCP15XH103 from Murata and B57330V2103 from EPCOS.

entry.name: SENSORS_SMSC47M1

entry.help:

The temperature and voltage sensor features of the LPC47M15x, LPC47M192, LPC47M292 and LPC47M997 are supported by another driver, select also "SMSC LPC47M192 and compatibles" below for those.
This driver can also be built as a module. If so, the module will be called smsc47m1.

entry.name: SENSORS_SMSC47M192
entry.label: SMSC LPC47M192 and compatibles
entry.help:
If you say yes here you get support for the temperature and voltage sensors of the SMSC LPC47M192, LPC47M15x, LPC47M292 and LPC47M997 chips.
The fan monitoring and control capabilities of these chips are supported by another driver, select "SMSC LPC47M10x and compatibles" above. You need both drivers if you want fan control and voltage/temperature sensor support.
This driver can also be built as a module. If so, the module will be called smsc47m192.

This driver can also be built as a module. If so, the module will be called sch5627.

entry.name: SENSORS_SCH5636
entry.label: SMSC SCH5636
entry.help:
SMSC SCH5636 Super I/O chips include an embedded microcontroller for hardware monitoring solutions, allowing motherboard manufacturers to create their own custom hwmon solution based upon the SCH5636.
Currently this driver only supports the Fujitsu Theseus SCH5636 based hwmon solution. Say yes here if you want support for the Fujitsu Theseus' hardware monitoring features including support for the integrated watchdog.
This driver can also be built as a module. If so, the module will be called sch5636.

Other supported chips are SMM465, SMM665C, SMM764, and SMM766. Support for those chips is untested.
This driver can also be built as a module. If so, the module will be called smm665.

entry.name: SENSORS_W83795

entry.name: SENSORS_W83795_FANCTRL
entry.label: Include automatic fan control support (DANGEROUS)
entry.help:
If you say yes here, support for automatic fan speed control will be included in the driver.
This part of the code wasn't carefully reviewed and tested yet, so enabling this option is strongly discouraged on production servers. Only developers and testers should enable it for the time being.
Please also note that this option will create sysfs attribute files which may change in the future, so you shouldn't rely on them being stable.

entry.name: SENSORS_W83L785TS

entry.name: SENSORS_W83L786NG

entry.help:

entry.name: SENSORS_W83627HF
entry.label: Winbond W83627HF, W83627THF, W83637HF, W83687THF, W83697HF

entry.name: SENSORS_W83627EHF

entry.help:
If you say yes here you get support for the hardware monitoring functionality of the Winbond W83627EHF Super-I/O chip.
This driver also supports the W83627EHG, which is the lead-free version of the W83627EHF, and the W83627DHG, which is a similar chip suited for specific Intel processors that use PECI such as the Core 2 Duo. And also the W83627UHG, which is a stripped down version of the W83627DHG (as far as hardware monitoring goes.)
This driver also supports Nuvoton W83667HG, W83667HG-B, NCT6775F (also known as W83667HG-I), and NCT6776F.
This driver can also be built as a module. If so, the module will be called w83627ehf.

entry.name: SENSORS_WM831X

entry.name: SENSORS_WM8350

entry.help:

entry.name: SENSORS_ULTRA45
