entry.name: VIDEO_IVTV
entry.label: Conexant cx23416/cx23415 MPEG encoder/decoder support
entry.help:
This is a video4linux driver for Conexant cx23416 or cx23415 based PCI personal video recorder devices.
This is used in devices such as the Hauppauge PVR-150/250/350/500 cards. There is a driver homepage at <http://www.ivtvdriver.org>.
To compile this driver as a module, choose M here: the module will be called ivtv.

entry.name: VIDEO_IVTV_ALSA
entry.label: Conexant cx23415/cx23416 ALSA interface for PCM audio capture
entry.help:
This driver provides an ALSA interface as another method for user applications to obtain PCM audio data from Conexant cx23415/cx23416 based PCI TV cards supported by the ivtv driver.
The ALSA interface has much wider use in user applications performing PCM audio capture, than the V4L2 "/dev/video24" PCM audio interface provided by the main ivtv driver.
To compile this driver as a module, choose M here: the module will be called ivtv-alsa.

entry.name: VIDEO_FB_IVTV
entry.label: Conexant cx23415 framebuffer support
entry.help:
This is a framebuffer driver for the Conexant cx23415 MPEG encoder/decoder.
This is used in the Hauppauge PVR-350 card. There is a driver homepage at <http://www.ivtvdriver.org>.
In order to use this module, you will need to boot with PAT disabled on x86 systems, using the nopat kernel parameter.
To compile this driver as a module, choose M here: the module will be called ivtvfb.

entry.name: VIDEO_HEXIUM_GEMINI
entry.label: Hexium Gemini frame grabber
entry.help:
This is a video4linux driver for the Hexium Gemini frame grabber card by Hexium. Please note that the Gemini Dual card is *not* fully supported.
To compile this driver as a module, choose M here: the module will be called hexium_gemini.

entry.name: VIDEO_HEXIUM_ORION
entry.label: Hexium HV-PCI6 and Orion frame grabber
entry.help:
This is a video4linux driver for the Hexium HV-PCI6 and Orion frame grabber cards by Hexium.
To compile this driver as a module, choose M here: the module will be called hexium_orion.

entry.name: VIDEO_MXB
entry.label: Siemens-Nixdorf 'Multimedia eXtension Board'
entry.help:
This is a video4linux driver for the 'Multimedia eXtension Board' TV card by Siemens-Nixdorf.
To compile this driver as a module, choose M here: the module will be called mxb.

entry.name: VIDEO_DT3155
entry.label: DT3155 frame grabber
entry.help:
Enables dt3155 device driver for the DataTranslation DT3155 frame grabber. Say Y here if you have this hardware. In doubt, say N.
To compile this driver as a module, choose M here: the module will be called dt3155.

entry.name: VIDEO_CX18
entry.label: Conexant cx23418 MPEG encoder support
entry.help:
This is a video4linux driver for Conexant cx23418 based PCI combo video recorder devices.
This is used in devices such as the Hauppauge HVR-1600 cards.
To compile this driver as a module, choose M here: the module will be called cx18.

entry.name: VIDEO_CX18_ALSA
entry.label: Conexant 23418 DMA audio support
entry.help:
This is a video4linux driver for direct (DMA) audio on Conexant 23418 based TV cards using ALSA.
To compile this driver as a module, choose M here: the module will be called cx18-alsa.

entry.name: VIDEO_CX23885
entry.label: Conexant cx23885 (2388x successor) support
entry.help:
This is a video4linux driver for Conexant 23885 based TV cards.
To compile this driver as a module, choose M here: the module will be called cx23885

entry.name: MEDIA_ALTERA_CI
entry.label: Altera FPGA based CI module
entry.help:
An Altera FPGA CI module for NetUP Dual DVB-T/C RF CI card.
To compile this driver as a module, choose M here: the module will be called altera-ci

entry.name: VIDEO_CX25821
entry.label: Conexant cx25821 support
entry.help:
This is a video4linux driver for Conexant 25821 based TV cards.
To compile this driver as a module, choose M here: the module will be called cx25821

entry.name: VIDEO_CX25821_ALSA
entry.label: Conexant 25821 DMA audio support
entry.help:
This is a video4linux driver for direct (DMA) audio on Conexant 25821 based capture cards using ALSA.
It only works with boards with function 01 enabled. To check if your board supports, use lspci -n. If supported, you should see 14f1:8801 or 14f1:8811 PCI device.
To compile this driver as a module, choose M here: the module will be called cx25821-alsa.

entry.name: VIDEO_CX88
entry.label: Conexant 2388x (bt878 successor) support
entry.help:
This is a video4linux driver for Conexant 2388x based TV cards.
To compile this driver as a module, choose M here: the module will be called cx8800

entry.name: VIDEO_CX88_ALSA
entry.label: Conexant 2388x DMA audio support
entry.help:
This is a video4linux driver for direct (DMA) audio on Conexant 2388x based TV cards using ALSA.
It only works with boards with function 01 enabled. To check if your board supports, use lspci -n. If supported, you should see 14f1:8801 or 14f1:8811 PCI device.
To compile this driver as a module, choose M here: the module will be called cx88-alsa.

entry.name: VIDEO_CX88_BLACKBIRD
entry.label: Blackbird MPEG encoder support (cx2388x + cx23416)
entry.help:
This adds support for MPEG encoder cards based on the Blackbird reference design, using the Conexant 2388x and 23416 chips.
To compile this driver as a module, choose M here: the module will be called cx88-blackbird.

entry.name: VIDEO_CX88_DVB
entry.label: DVB/ATSC Support for cx2388x based TV cards
entry.help:
This adds support for DVB/ATSC cards based on the Conexant 2388x chip.
To compile this driver as a module, choose M here: the module will be called cx88-dvb.

entry.name: VIDEO_CX88_ENABLE_VP3054
entry.label: VP-3054 Secondary I2C Bus Support
entry.help: This adds DVB-T support for cards based on the Conexant 2388x chip and the MT352 demodulator, which also require support for the VP-3054 Secondary I2C bus, such at DNTV Live! DVB-T Pro.

entry.name: VIDEO_BT848
entry.label: BT848 Video For Linux
entry.help:
Support for BT848 based frame grabber/overlay boards. This includes the Miro, Hauppauge and STB boards. Please read the material in <file:Documentation/video4linux/bttv/> for more information.
To compile this driver as a module, choose M here: the module will be called bttv.

entry.name: DVB_BT8XX
entry.label: DVB/ATSC Support for bt878 based TV cards
entry.help:
Support for PCI cards based on the Bt8xx PCI bridge. Examples are the Nebula cards, the Pinnacle PCTV cards, the Twinhan DST cards, the pcHDTV HD2000 cards, the DViCO FusionHDTV Lite cards, and some AVerMedia cards.
Since these cards have no MPEG decoder onboard, they transmit only compressed MPEG data over the PCI bus, so you need an external software decoder to watch TV on your computer.
Say Y if you own such a device and want to use it.

entry.name: VIDEO_SAA7134
entry.label: Philips SAA7134 support
entry.help:
This is a video4linux driver for Philips SAA713x based TV cards.
To compile this driver as a module, choose M here: the module will be called saa7134.

entry.name: VIDEO_SAA7134_ALSA
entry.label: Philips SAA7134 DMA audio support
entry.help:
This is a video4linux driver for direct (DMA) audio in Philips SAA713x based TV cards using ALSA
To compile this driver as a module, choose M here: the module will be called saa7134-alsa.

entry.name: VIDEO_SAA7134_RC
entry.label: Philips SAA7134 Remote Controller support
entry.help: Enables Remote Controller support on saa7134 driver.

entry.name: VIDEO_SAA7134_DVB
entry.label: DVB/ATSC Support for saa7134 based TV cards
entry.help:
This adds support for DVB cards based on the Philips saa7134 chip.
To compile this driver as a module, choose M here: the module will be called saa7134-dvb.

entry.name: VIDEO_SAA7134_GO7007
entry.label: go7007 support for saa7134 based TV cards
entry.help: Enables saa7134 driver support for boards with go7007 MPEG encoder (WIS Voyager or compatible).

entry.name: VIDEO_SAA7164
entry.label: NXP SAA7164 support
entry.help:
This is a video4linux driver for NXP SAA7164 based TV cards.
To compile this driver as a module, choose M here: the module will be called saa7164

entry.name: VIDEO_COBALT
entry.label: Cisco Cobalt support
entry.help:
This is a video4linux driver for the Cisco PCIe Cobalt card.
This board is sadly not available outside of Cisco, but it is very useful as an example of a real driver that uses all the latest frameworks and APIs.
To compile this driver as a module, choose M here: the module will be called cobalt.

entry.name: DVB_AV7110
entry.label: AV7110 cards
entry.help:
Support for SAA7146 and AV7110 based DVB cards as produced by Fujitsu-Siemens, Technotrend, Hauppauge and others.
This driver only supports the fullfeatured cards with onboard MPEG2 decoder.
This driver needs an external firmware. Please use the script "<kerneldir>/Documentation/dvb/get_dvb_firmware av7110" to download/extract it, and then copy it to /usr/lib/hotplug/firmware or /lib/firmware (depending on configuration of firmware hotplug).
Alternatively, you can download the file and use the kernel's EXTRA_FIRMWARE configuration option to build it into your kernel image by adding the filename to the EXTRA_FIRMWARE configuration option string.
Say Y if you own such a card and want to use it.

entry.name: DVB_AV7110_OSD
entry.label: AV7110 OSD support
entry.help:
The AV7110 firmware provides some code to generate an OnScreenDisplay on the video output. This is kind of nonstandard and not guaranteed to be maintained.
Anyway, some popular DVB software like VDR uses this OSD to render its menus, so say Y if you want to use this software.
All other people say N.

entry.name: DVB_BUDGET_CORE
entry.label: SAA7146 DVB cards (aka Budget, Nova-PCI)
entry.help: Support for simple SAA7146 based DVB cards (so called Budget- or Nova-PCI cards) without onboard MPEG2 decoder.

entry.name: DVB_BUDGET
entry.label: Budget cards
entry.help:
Support for simple SAA7146 based DVB cards (so called Budget- or Nova-PCI cards) without onboard MPEG2 decoder, and without analog inputs or an onboard Common Interface connector.
Say Y if you own such a card and want to use it.
To compile this driver as a module, choose M here: the module will be called budget.

entry.name: DVB_BUDGET_CI
entry.label: Budget cards with onboard CI connector
entry.help:
Support for simple SAA7146 based DVB cards (so called Budget- or Nova-PCI cards) without onboard MPEG2 decoder, but with onboard Common Interface connector.
Note: The Common Interface is not yet supported by this driver due to lack of information from the vendor.
Say Y if you own such a card and want to use it.
To compile this driver as a module, choose M here: the module will be called budget-ci.

entry.name: DVB_BUDGET_AV
entry.label: Budget cards with analog video inputs
entry.help:
Support for simple SAA7146 based DVB cards (so called Budget- or Nova-PCI cards) without onboard MPEG2 decoder, but with one or more analog video inputs.
Say Y if you own such a card and want to use it.
To compile this driver as a module, choose M here: the module will be called budget-av.

entry.name: DVB_BUDGET_PATCH
entry.label: AV7110 cards with Budget Patch
entry.help:
Support for Budget Patch (full TS) modification on SAA7146+AV7110 based cards (DVB-S cards). This driver doesn't use onboard MPEG2 decoder. The card is driven in Budget-only mode. Card is required to have loaded firmware to tune properly. Firmware can be loaded by insertion and removal of standard AV7110 driver prior to loading this driver.
Say Y if you own such a card and want to use it.
To compile this driver as a module, choose M here: the module will be called budget-patch.

entry.name: DVB_B2C2_FLEXCOP_PCI
entry.label: Technisat/B2C2 Air/Sky/Cable2PC PCI
entry.help:
Support for the Air/Sky/CableStar2 PCI card (DVB/ATSC) by Technisat/B2C2.
Say Y if you own such a device and want to use it.

entry.name: DVB_B2C2_FLEXCOP_PCI_DEBUG
entry.label: Enable debug for the B2C2 FlexCop drivers
entry.help: Say Y if you want to enable the module option to control debug messages of all B2C2 FlexCop drivers.

entry.name: DVB_PLUTO2
entry.label: Pluto2 cards
entry.help:
Support for PCI cards based on the Pluto2 FPGA like the Satelco Easywatch Mobile Terrestrial DVB-T Receiver.
Since these cards have no MPEG decoder onboard, they transmit only compressed MPEG data over the PCI bus, so you need an external software decoder to watch TV on your computer.
Say Y or M if you own such a device and want to use it.

entry.name: DVB_DM1105
entry.label: SDMC DM1105 based PCI cards
entry.help:
Support for cards based on the SDMC DM1105 PCI chip like DvbWorld 2002
Since these cards have no MPEG decoder onboard, they transmit only compressed MPEG data over the PCI bus, so you need an external software decoder to watch TV on your computer.
Say Y or M if you own such a device and want to use it.

entry.name: DVB_PT1
entry.label: PT1 cards
entry.help:
Support for Earthsoft PT1 PCI cards.
Since these cards have no MPEG decoder onboard, they transmit only compressed MPEG data over the PCI bus, so you need an external software decoder to watch TV on your computer.
Say Y or M if you own such a device and want to use it.

entry.name: DVB_PT3
entry.label: Earthsoft PT3 cards
entry.help:
Support for Earthsoft PT3 PCIe cards.
Say Y or M if you own such a device and want to use it.

entry.name: MANTIS_CORE
entry.label: Mantis/Hopper PCI bridge based devices
entry.help:
Support for PCI cards based on the Mantis and Hopper PCi bridge.
Say Y if you own such a device and want to use it.

entry.name: DVB_MANTIS
entry.label: MANTIS based cards
entry.help:
Support for PCI cards based on the Mantis PCI bridge. Say Y when you have a Mantis based DVB card and want to use it.
If unsure say N.

entry.name: DVB_HOPPER
entry.label: HOPPER based cards
entry.help:
Support for PCI cards based on the Hopper PCI bridge. Say Y when you have a Hopper based DVB card and want to use it.
If unsure say N

entry.name: DVB_NGENE
entry.label: Micronas nGene support
entry.help: Support for Micronas PCI express cards with nGene bridge.

entry.name: DVB_DDBRIDGE
entry.label: Digital Devices bridge support
entry.help:
Support for cards with the Digital Devices PCI express bridge: - Octopus PCIe Bridge - Octopus mini PCIe Bridge - Octopus LE - DuoFlex S2 Octopus - DuoFlex CT Octopus - cineS2(v6)
Say Y if you own such a card and want to use it.

entry.name: DVB_SMIPCIE
entry.label: SMI PCIe DVBSky cards
entry.help:
Support for cards with SMI PCIe bridge: - DVBSky S950 V3 - DVBSky S952 V3 - DVBSky T9580 V3
Say Y or M if you own such a device and want to use it. If unsure say N.

entry.name: DVB_NETUP_UNIDVB
entry.label: NetUP Universal DVB card support
entry.help: Say Y when you want to support NetUP Dual Universal DVB card Card can receive two independent streams in following standards: DVB-S/S2, T/T2, C/C2 Two CI slots available for CAM modules.

entry.name: V4L_PLATFORM_DRIVERS
entry.label: V4L platform devices
entry.help: Say Y here to enable support for platform-specific V4L drivers.

entry.name: VIDEO_CAFE_CCIC
entry.label: Marvell 88ALP01 (Cafe) CMOS Camera Controller support
entry.help: This is a video4linux2 driver for the Marvell 88ALP01 integrated CMOS camera controller. This is the controller found on first- generation OLPC systems.

entry.name: VIDEO_MMP_CAMERA
entry.label: Marvell Armada 610 integrated camera controller support
entry.help: This is a Video4Linux2 driver for the integrated camera controller found on Marvell Armada 610 application processors (and likely beyond). This is the controller found in OLPC XO 1.75 systems.

entry.name: VIDEO_VIA_CAMERA
entry.label: VIAFB camera controller support
entry.help: Driver support for the integrated camera controller in VIA Chrome9 chipsets. Currently only tested on OLPC xo-1.5 systems with ov7670 sensors.

entry.name: VIDEO_DAVINCI_VPIF_DISPLAY
entry.label: TI DaVinci VPIF V4L2-Display driver
entry.help:
Enables Davinci VPIF module used for display devices. This module is used for display on TI DM6467/DA850/OMAPL138 SoCs.
To compile this driver as a module, choose M here. There will be two modules called vpif.ko and vpif_display.ko

entry.name: VIDEO_DAVINCI_VPIF_CAPTURE
entry.label: TI DaVinci VPIF video capture driver
entry.help:
Enables Davinci VPIF module used for capture devices. This module is used for capture on TI DM6467/DA850/OMAPL138 SoCs.
To compile this driver as a module, choose M here. There will be two modules called vpif.ko and vpif_capture.ko

entry.name: VIDEO_DM6446_CCDC
entry.label: TI DM6446 CCDC video capture driver
entry.help:
Enables DaVinci CCD hw module. DaVinci CCDC hw interfaces with decoder modules such as TVP5146 over BT656 or sensor module such as MT9T001 over a raw interface. This module configures the interface and CCDC/ISIF to do video frame capture from slave decoders.
To compile this driver as a module, choose M here. There will be three modules called vpfe_capture.ko, vpss.ko and dm644x_ccdc.ko

entry.name: VIDEO_DM355_CCDC
entry.label: TI DM355 CCDC video capture driver
entry.help:
Enables DM355 CCD hw module. DM355 CCDC hw interfaces with decoder modules such as TVP5146 over BT656 or sensor module such as MT9T001 over a raw interface. This module configures the interface and CCDC/ISIF to do video frame capture from a slave decoders
To compile this driver as a module, choose M here. There will be three modules called vpfe_capture.ko, vpss.ko and dm355_ccdc.ko

entry.name: VIDEO_DM365_ISIF
entry.label: TI DM365 ISIF video capture driver
entry.help:
Enables ISIF hw module. This is the hardware module for configuring ISIF in VPFE to capture Raw Bayer RGB data from a image sensor or YUV data from a YUV source.
To compile this driver as a module, choose M here. There will be three modules called vpfe_capture.ko, vpss.ko and isif.ko

entry.name: VIDEO_DAVINCI_VPBE_DISPLAY
entry.label: TI DaVinci VPBE V4L2-Display driver
entry.help:
Enables Davinci VPBE module used for display devices. This module is used for display on TI DM644x/DM365/DM355 based display devices.
To compile this driver as a module, choose M here. There will be five modules created called vpss.ko, vpbe.ko, vpbe_osd.ko, vpbe_venc.ko and vpbe_display.ko

entry.name: VIDEO_OMAP2_VOUT
entry.label: OMAP2/OMAP3 V4L2-Display driver
entry.help: V4L2 Display driver support for OMAP2/3 based boards.

entry.name: VIDEO_BLACKFIN_CAPTURE
entry.label: Blackfin Video Capture Driver
entry.help:
V4L2 bridge driver for Blackfin video capture device. Choose PPI or EPPI as its interface.
To compile this driver as a module, choose M here: the module will be called bfin_capture.

entry.name: VIDEO_SH_VOU
entry.label: SuperH VOU video output driver
entry.help: Support for the Video Output Unit (VOU) on SuperH SoCs.

entry.name: VIDEO_VIU
entry.label: Freescale VIU Video Driver
entry.help:
Support for Freescale VIU video driver. This device captures video data, or overlays video on DIU frame buffer.
Say Y here if you want to enable VIU device on MPC5121e Rev2+. In doubt, say N.

entry.name: VIDEO_M32R_AR
entry.label: AR devices
entry.help: This is a video4linux driver for the Renesas AR (Artificial Retina) camera module.

entry.name: VIDEO_M32R_AR_M64278
entry.label: AR device with color module M64278(VGA)
entry.help:
This is a video4linux driver for the Renesas AR (Artificial Retina) with M64278E-800 camera module. This module supports VGA(640x480 pixels) resolutions.
To compile this driver as a module, choose M here: the module will be called arv.

entry.name: VIDEO_OMAP3

entry.help: Driver for an OMAP 3 camera controller.

entry.name: VIDEO_OMAP3_DEBUG

entry.name: VIDEO_S3C_CAMIF
entry.label: Samsung S3C24XX/S3C64XX SoC Camera Interface driver
entry.help:
This is a v4l2 driver for s3c24xx and s3c64xx SoC series camera host interface (CAMIF).
To compile this driver as a module, choose M here: the module will be called s3c-camif.

entry.name: SOC_CAMERA
entry.label: SoC camera support
entry.help: SoC Camera is a common API to several cameras, not connecting over a bus like PCI or USB. For example some i2c camera connected directly to the data bus of an SoC.

entry.name: SOC_CAMERA_PLATFORM
entry.label: platform camera support
entry.help: This is a generic SoC camera platform driver, useful for testing

entry.name: VIDEO_PXA27x
entry.label: PXA27x Quick Capture Interface driver
entry.help: This is a v4l2 driver for the PXA27x Quick Capture Interface

entry.name: VIDEO_RCAR_VIN_OLD
entry.label: R-Car Video Input (VIN) support (DEPRECATED)
entry.help: This is a v4l2 driver for the R-Car VIN Interface

entry.name: VIDEO_SH_MOBILE_CSI2

entry.help: This is a v4l2 driver for the SuperH MIPI CSI-2 Interface

entry.name: VIDEO_SH_MOBILE_CEU

entry.help: This is a v4l2 driver for the SuperH Mobile CEU Interface

entry.name: VIDEO_ATMEL_ISI
entry.label: ATMEL Image Sensor Interface (ISI) support

entry.name: VIDEO_SAMSUNG_EXYNOS4_IS
entry.label: Samsung S5P/EXYNOS4 SoC series Camera Subsystem driver
entry.help: Say Y here to enable camera host interface devices for Samsung S5P and EXYNOS SoC series.

entry.name: VIDEO_S5P_FIMC
entry.label: S5P/EXYNOS4 FIMC/CAMIF camera interface driver
entry.help:
This is a V4L2 driver for Samsung S5P and EXYNOS4 SoC camera host interface and video postprocessor (FIMC) devices.
To compile this driver as a module, choose M here: the module will be called s5p-fimc.

entry.name: VIDEO_S5P_MIPI_CSIS
entry.label: S5P/EXYNOS MIPI-CSI2 receiver (MIPI-CSIS) driver
entry.help:
This is a V4L2 driver for Samsung S5P and EXYNOS4 SoC MIPI-CSI2 receiver (MIPI-CSIS) devices.
To compile this driver as a module, choose M here: the module will be called s5p-csis.

entry.name: VIDEO_EXYNOS_FIMC_LITE
entry.label: EXYNOS FIMC-LITE camera interface driver
entry.help:
This is a V4L2 driver for Samsung EXYNOS4/5 SoC FIMC-LITE camera host interface.
To compile this driver as a module, choose M here: the module will be called exynos-fimc-lite.

entry.name: VIDEO_EXYNOS4_FIMC_IS
entry.label: EXYNOS4x12 FIMC-IS (Imaging Subsystem) driver
entry.help:
This is a V4L2 driver for Samsung EXYNOS4x12 SoC series FIMC-IS (Imaging Subsystem).
To compile this driver as a module, choose M here: the module will be called exynos4-fimc-is.

entry.name: VIDEO_EXYNOS4_ISP_DMA_CAPTURE
entry.label: EXYNOS4x12 FIMC-IS ISP Direct DMA capture support
entry.help: This option enables an additional video device node exposing a V4L2 video capture interface for the FIMC-IS ISP raw (Bayer) capture DMA.

entry.name: VIDEO_SAMSUNG_S5P_TV
entry.label: Samsung TV driver for S5P platform
entry.help: Say Y here to enable selecting the TV output devices for Samsung S5P platform.

entry.name: VIDEO_SAMSUNG_S5P_HDMI
entry.label: Samsung HDMI Driver
entry.help: Say Y here if you want support for the HDMI output interface in S5P Samsung SoC. The driver can be compiled as module. It is an auxiliary driver, that exposes a V4L2 subdev for use by other drivers. This driver requires hdmiphy driver to work correctly.

entry.name: VIDEO_SAMSUNG_S5P_HDMI_DEBUG
entry.label: Enable debug for HDMI Driver
entry.help: Enables debugging for HDMI driver.

entry.name: VIDEO_SAMSUNG_S5P_HDMIPHY
entry.label: Samsung HDMIPHY Driver
entry.help: Say Y here if you want support for the physical HDMI interface in S5P Samsung SoC. The driver can be compiled as module. It is an I2C driver, that exposes a V4L2 subdev for use by other drivers.

entry.name: VIDEO_SAMSUNG_S5P_SII9234
entry.label: Samsung SII9234 Driver
entry.help: Say Y here if you want support for the MHL interface in S5P Samsung SoC. The driver can be compiled as module. It is an I2C driver, that exposes a V4L2 subdev for use by other drivers.

entry.name: VIDEO_SAMSUNG_S5P_SDO
entry.label: Samsung Analog TV Driver
entry.help: Say Y here if you want support for the analog TV output interface in S5P Samsung SoC. The driver can be compiled as module. It is an auxiliary driver, that exposes a V4L2 subdev for use by other drivers. This driver requires hdmiphy driver to work correctly.

entry.name: VIDEO_SAMSUNG_S5P_MIXER
entry.label: Samsung Mixer and Video Processor Driver
entry.help: Say Y here if you want support for the Mixer in Samsung S5P SoCs. This device produce image data to one of output interfaces.

entry.name: VIDEO_SAMSUNG_S5P_MIXER_DEBUG
entry.label: Enable debug for Mixer Driver
entry.help: Enables debugging for Mixer driver.

entry.name: VIDEO_AM437X_VPFE
entry.label: TI AM437x VPFE video capture driver
entry.help:
Support for AM437x Video Processing Front End based Video Capture Driver.
To compile this driver as a module, choose M here. The module will be called am437x-vpfe.

entry.name: VIDEO_XILINX
entry.label: Xilinx Video IP (EXPERIMENTAL)
entry.help: Driver for Xilinx Video IP Pipelines

entry.name: VIDEO_XILINX_TPG
entry.label: Xilinx Video Test Pattern Generator
entry.help: Driver for the Xilinx Video Test Pattern Generator

entry.name: VIDEO_XILINX_VTC
entry.label: Xilinx Video Timing Controller
entry.help: Driver for the Xilinx Video Timing Controller

entry.name: VIDEO_RCAR_VIN

Support for Renesas R-Car Video Input (VIN) driver. Supports R-Car Gen2 SoCs.
To compile this driver as a module, choose M here: the module will be called rcar-vin.

entry.name: VIDEO_TI_CAL
entry.label: TI CAL (Camera Adaptation Layer) driver
entry.help: Support for the TI CAL (Camera Adaptation Layer) block found on DRA72X SoC. In TI Technical Reference Manual this module is referred as Camera Interface Subsystem (CAMSS).

entry.name: V4L_MEM2MEM_DRIVERS
entry.label: Memory-to-memory multimedia devices
entry.help: Say Y here to enable selecting drivers for V4L devices that use system memory for both source and destination buffers, as opposed to capture and output drivers, which use memory buffers for just one of those.

entry.name: VIDEO_CODA
entry.label: Chips&Media Coda multi-standard codec IP
entry.help: Coda is a range of video codec IPs that supports H.264, MPEG-4, and other video formats.

entry.name: VIDEO_MEDIATEK_VPU
entry.label: Mediatek Video Processor Unit
entry.help:
This driver provides downloading VPU firmware and communicating with VPU. This driver for hw video codec embedded in Mediatek's MT8173 SOCs. It is able to handle video decoding/encoding in a range of formats.
To compile this driver as a module, choose M here: the module will be called mtk-vpu.

entry.name: VIDEO_MEDIATEK_VCODEC
entry.label: Mediatek Video Codec driver
entry.help:
Mediatek video codec driver provides HW capability to encode and decode in a range of video formats This driver rely on VPU driver to communicate with VPU.
To compile this driver as a module, choose M here: the module will be called mtk-vcodec

entry.name: VIDEO_MEM2MEM_DEINTERLACE

entry.name: MEDIA_SUBDRV_AUTOSELECT

By default, a media driver auto-selects all possible ancillary devices such as tuners, sensors, video encoders/decoders and frontends, that are used by any of the supported devices.
This is generally the right thing to do, except when there are strict constraints with regards to the kernel size, like on embedded systems.
Use this option with care, as deselecting ancillary drivers which are, in fact, necessary will result in the lack of the needed functionality for your device (it may not tune or may not have the needed demodulators).

entry.name: AGP
entry.label: /dev/agpgart (AGP Support)
entry.help:
AGP (Accelerated Graphics Port) is a bus system mainly used to connect graphics cards to the rest of the system.
If you have an AGP system and you say Y here, it will be possible to use the AGP features of your 3D rendering video card. This code acts as a sort of "AGP driver" for the motherboard's chipset.
If you need more texture memory than you can get with the AGP GART (theoretically up to 256 MB, but in practice usually 64 or 128 MB due to kernel allocation issues), you could use PCI accesses and have up to a couple gigs of texture space.
Note that this is the only means to have X/GLX use write-combining with MTRR support on the AGP bus. Without it, OpenGL direct rendering will be a lot slower but still faster than PIO.
To compile this driver as a module, choose M here: the module will be called agpgart.
You should say Y here if you want to use GLX or DRI.
If unsure, say N.

entry.name: AGP_ALI
entry.label: ALI chipset support
entry.help:
This option gives you AGP support for the GLX component of X on the following ALi chipsets. The supported chipsets include M1541, M1621, M1631, M1632, M1641,M1647,and M1651. For the ALi-chipset question, ALi suggests you refer to <http://www.ali.com.tw/>.
The M1541 chipset can do AGP 1x and 2x, but note that there is an acknowledged incompatibility with Matrox G200 cards. Due to timing issues, this chipset cannot do AGP 2x with the G200. This is a hardware limitation. AGP 1x seems to be fine, though.

entry.help: Choose this if you have a i.MX5/6 system and want to use the Image Processing Unit. This option only enables IPU base support.

entry.name: DRM
entry.label: Direct Rendering Manager (XFree86 4.1.0 and higher DRI support)
entry.help: Kernel-level support for the Direct Rendering Infrastructure (DRI) introduced in XFree86 4.0. If you say Y here, you need to select the module that's right for your graphics card from the list below. These modules provide support for synchronization, security, and DMA transfers. Please see <http://dri.sourceforge.net/> for more details. You should also select and configure AGP (/dev/agpgart) support if it is available for your platform.

entry.name: DRM_DP_AUX_CHARDEV
entry.label: DRM DP AUX Interface
entry.help: Choose this option to enable a /dev/drm_dp_auxN node that allows to read and write values to arbitrary DPCD registers on the DP aux channel.

entry.name: DRM_KMS_HELPER
entry.help: CRTC helpers for KMS drivers.

entry.name: DRM_KMS_FB_HELPER
entry.help: FBDEV helpers for KMS drivers.

entry.name: DRM_FBDEV_EMULATION
entry.label: Enable legacy fbdev support for your modesetting driver
entry.help:
Choose this option if you have a need for the legacy fbdev support. Note that this support also provides the linux console support on top of your modesetting driver.
If in doubt, say "Y".

entry.name: DRM_LOAD_EDID_FIRMWARE
entry.label: Allow to specify an EDID data set instead of probing for it
entry.help: Say Y here, if you want to use EDID data to be loaded from the /lib/firmware directory or one of the provided built-in data sets. This may be necessary, if the graphics adapter or monitor are unable to provide appropriate EDID data. Since this feature is provided as a workaround for broken hardware, the default case is N. Details and instructions how to build your own EDID data are given in Documentation/EDID/HOWTO.txt.

entry.name: DRM_TTM
entry.help: GPU memory management subsystem for devices with multiple GPU memory types. Will be enabled automatically if a device driver uses it.

entry.name: DRM_GEM_CMA_HELPER
entry.help: Choose this if you need the GEM CMA helper functions

entry.name: DRM_KMS_CMA_HELPER
entry.help: Choose this if you need the KMS CMA helper functions

entry.name: DRM_I2C_CH7006
entry.label: Chrontel ch7006 TV encoder
entry.help:
Support for Chrontel ch7006 and similar TV encoders, found on some nVidia video cards.
This driver is currently only useful if you're also using the nouveau driver.

entry.name: DRM_I2C_SIL164
entry.label: Silicon Image sil164 TMDS transmitter
entry.help: Support for sil164 and similar single-link (or dual-link when used in pairs) TMDS transmitters, used in some nVidia video cards.

entry.name: DRM_I2C_NXP_TDA998X
entry.label: NXP Semiconductors TDA998X HDMI encoder
entry.help: Support for NXP Semiconductors TDA998X HDMI encoders.

entry.name: DRM_TDFX
entry.label: 3dfx Banshee/Voodoo3+
entry.help: Choose this option if you have a 3dfx Banshee or Voodoo3 (or later), graphics card. If M is selected, the module will be called tdfx.

entry.name: DRM_ARM
entry.help: Choose this option to select drivers for ARM's devices

entry.name: DRM_HDLCD
entry.label: ARM HDLCD
entry.help:
Choose this option if you have an ARM High Definition Colour LCD controller.
If M is selected the module will be called hdlcd.

entry.name: DRM_HDLCD_SHOW_UNDERRUN
entry.label: Show underrun conditions
entry.help: Enable this option to show in red colour the pixels that the HDLCD device did not fetch from framebuffer due to underrun conditions.

entry.name: DRM_MALI_DISPLAY
entry.label: ARM Mali Display Processor
entry.help:
Choose this option if you want to compile the ARM Mali Display Processor driver. It supports the DP500, DP550 and DP650 variants of the hardware.
If compiled as a module it will be called mali-dp.

entry.name: DRM_R128
entry.label: ATI Rage 128
entry.help: Choose this option if you have an ATI Rage 128 graphics card. If M is selected, the module will be called r128. AGP support for this card is strongly suggested (unless you have a PCI version).

entry.name: DRM_RADEON
entry.label: ATI Radeon
entry.help:
Choose this option if you have an ATI Radeon graphics card. There are both PCI and AGP versions. You don't need to choose this to run the Radeon in plain VGA mode.
If M is selected, the module will be called radeon.

entry.name: DRM_RADEON_USERPTR
entry.label: Always enable userptr support
entry.help: This option selects CONFIG_MMU_NOTIFIER if it isn't already selected to enabled full userptr support.

entry.name: DRM_AMDGPU
entry.label: AMD GPU
entry.help:
Choose this option if you have a recent AMD Radeon graphics card.
If M is selected, the module will be called amdgpu.

entry.name: DRM_AMDGPU_CIK
entry.label: Enable amdgpu support for CIK parts
entry.help:
Choose this option if you want to enable experimental support for CIK asics.
CIK is already supported in radeon. CIK support in amdgpu is for experimentation and testing.

entry.name: DRM_AMDGPU_USERPTR
entry.label: Always enable userptr write support
entry.help: This option selects CONFIG_MMU_NOTIFIER if it isn't already selected to enabled full userptr support.

entry.name: DRM_AMDGPU_GART_DEBUGFS
entry.label: Allow GART access through debugfs
entry.help: Selecting this option creates a debugfs file to inspect the mapped pages. Uses more memory for housekeeping, enable only for debugging.

entry.name: DRM_AMD_POWERPLAY
entry.label: Enable AMD powerplay component
entry.help: select this option will enable AMD powerplay component.

entry.name: DRM_AMD_ACP
entry.label: Enable AMD Audio CoProcessor IP support
entry.help: Choose this option to enable ACP IP support for AMD SOCs. This adds the ACP (Audio CoProcessor) IP driver and wires it up into the amdgpu driver. The ACP block provides the DMA engine for the i2s-based ALSA driver. It is required for audio on APUs which utilize an i2s codec.

entry.name: DRM_NOUVEAU
entry.label: Nouveau (NVIDIA) cards
entry.help: Choose this option for open-source NVIDIA support.

entry.name: NOUVEAU_PLATFORM_DRIVER
entry.label: Nouveau (NVIDIA) SoC GPUs
entry.help: Support for Nouveau platform driver, used for SoC GPUs as found on NVIDIA Tegra K1.

entry.name: NOUVEAU_DEBUG
entry.label: Maximum debug level
entry.help:
Selects the maximum debug level to compile support for.
0 - fatal 1 - error 2 - warning 3 - info 4 - debug 5 - trace (recommended) 6 - paranoia 7 - spam
The paranoia and spam levels will add a lot of extra checks which may potentially slow down driver operation.

entry.name: NOUVEAU_DEBUG_DEFAULT
entry.label: Default debug level
entry.help: Selects the default debug level

entry.name: DRM_NOUVEAU_BACKLIGHT
entry.label: Support for backlight control
entry.help: Say Y here if you want to control the backlight of your display (e.g. a laptop panel).

entry.name: DRM_I810
entry.label: Intel I810
entry.help: Choose this option if you have an Intel I810 graphics card. If M is selected, the module will be called i810. AGP support is required for this driver to work.

entry.name: DRM_I915
entry.label: Intel 8xx/9xx/G3x/G4x/HD Graphics
entry.help:
Choose this option if you have a system that has "Intel Graphics Media Accelerator" or "HD Graphics" integrated graphics, including 830M, 845G, 852GM, 855GM, 865G, 915G, 945G, 965G, G35, G41, G43, G45 chipsets and Celeron, Pentium, Core i3, Core i5, Core i7 as well as Atom CPUs with integrated graphics. If M is selected, the module will be called i915. AGP support is required for this driver to work. This driver is used by the Intel driver in X.org 6.8 and XFree86 4.4 and above. It replaces the older i830 module that supported a subset of the hardware in older X.org releases.
Note that the older i810/i815 chipsets require the use of the i810 driver instead, and the Atom z5xx series has an entirely different implementation.

entry.name: DRM_I915_PRELIMINARY_HW_SUPPORT
entry.label: Enable preliminary support for prerelease Intel hardware by default
entry.help:
Choose this option if you have prerelease Intel hardware and want the i915 driver to support it by default. You can enable such support at runtime with the module option i915.preliminary_hw_support=1; this option changes the default for that module option.
If in doubt, say "N".

entry.name: DRM_I915_USERPTR
entry.label: Always enable userptr support
entry.help:
This option selects CONFIG_MMU_NOTIFIER if it isn't already selected to enabled full userptr support.
If in doubt, say "Y".

entry.name: DRM_I915_GVT
entry.label: Enable Intel GVT-g graphics virtualization host support
entry.help:
Choose this option if you want to enable Intel GVT-g graphics virtualization technology host support with integrated graphics. With GVT-g, it's possible to have one integrated graphics device shared by multiple VMs under different hypervisors.
Note that at least one hypervisor like Xen or KVM is required for this driver to work, and it only supports newer device from Broadwell+. For further information and setup guide, you can visit: http://01.org/igvt-g.
Now it's just a stub to support the modifications of i915 for GVT device model. It requires at least one MPT modules for Xen/KVM and other components of GVT device model to work. Use it under you own risk.
If in doubt, say "N".

entry.name: DRM_I915_WERROR
entry.label: Force GCC to throw an error instead of a warning when compiling
entry.help:
Add -Werror to the build flags for (and only for) i915.ko. Do not enable this unless you are writing code for the i915.ko module.
Recommended for driver developers only.
If in doubt, say "N".

entry.name: DRM_I915_DEBUG
entry.label: Enable additional driver debugging
entry.help:
Choose this option to turn on extra driver debugging that may affect performance but will catch some internal issues.
Recommended for driver developers only.
If in doubt, say "N".

entry.name: DRM_I915_DEBUG_GEM
entry.label: Insert extra checks into the GEM internals
entry.help:
Enable extra sanity checks (including BUGs) along the GEM driver paths that may slow the system down and if hit hang the machine.
Recommended for driver developers only.
If in doubt, say "N".

entry.name: DRM_MGA
entry.label: Matrox g200/g400
entry.help: Choose this option if you have a Matrox G200, G400 or G450 graphics card. If M is selected, the module will be called mga. AGP support is required for this driver to work.

entry.name: DRM_SIS
entry.label: SiS video cards
entry.help: Choose this option if you have a SiS 630 or compatible video chipset. If M is selected the module will be called sis. AGP support is required for this driver to work.

entry.name: DRM_VIA
entry.label: Via unichrome video cards
entry.help: Choose this option if you have a Via unichrome or compatible video chipset. If M is selected the module will be called via.

entry.name: DRM_SAVAGE
entry.label: Savage video cards
entry.help: Choose this option if you have a Savage3D/4/SuperSavage/Pro/Twister chipset. If M is selected the module will be called savage.

entry.name: DRM_VGEM
entry.label: Virtual GEM provider
entry.help: Choose this option to get a virtual graphics memory manager, as used by Mesa's software renderer for enhanced performance. If M is selected the module will be called vgem.

entry.name: DRM_EXYNOS
entry.label: DRM Support for Samsung SoC EXYNOS Series
entry.help: Choose this option if you have a Samsung SoC EXYNOS chipset. If M is selected the module will be called exynosdrm.

entry.name: DRM_EXYNOS_FIMD
entry.label: FIMD
entry.help: Choose this option if you want to use Exynos FIMD for DRM.

entry.name: DRM_EXYNOS5433_DECON
entry.label: DECON on Exynos5433
entry.help: Choose this option if you want to use Exynos5433 DECON for DRM.

entry.name: DRM_EXYNOS7_DECON
entry.label: DECON on Exynos7
entry.help: Choose this option if you want to use Exynos DECON for DRM.

entry.name: DRM_EXYNOS_MIXER
entry.label: Mixer
entry.help: Choose this option if you want to use Exynos Mixer for DRM.

entry.name: DRM_EXYNOS_VIDI
entry.label: Virtual Display
entry.help: Choose this option if you want to use Exynos VIDI for DRM.

entry.name: DRM_EXYNOS_DPI
entry.label: Parallel output
entry.help: This enables support for Exynos parallel output.

entry.name: DRM_EXYNOS_DSI
entry.label: MIPI-DSI host
entry.help: This enables support for Exynos MIPI-DSI device.

entry.name: DRM_EXYNOS_DP
entry.label: EXYNOS specific extensions for Analogix DP driver
entry.help: This enables support for DP device.

entry.name: DRM_EXYNOS_HDMI
entry.label: HDMI
entry.help: Choose this option if you want to use Exynos HDMI for DRM.

entry.name: DRM_EXYNOS_MIC
entry.label: Mobile Image Compressor
entry.help: Choose this option if you want to use Exynos MIC for DRM.

entry.name: DRM_EXYNOS_G2D
entry.label: G2D
entry.help: Choose this option if you want to use Exynos G2D for DRM.

entry.name: DRM_EXYNOS_IPP
entry.label: Image Post Processor
entry.help: Choose this option if you want to use IPP feature for DRM.

entry.name: DRM_EXYNOS_FIMC
entry.label: FIMC
entry.help: Choose this option if you want to use Exynos FIMC for DRM.

entry.name: DRM_EXYNOS_ROTATOR
entry.label: Rotator
entry.help: Choose this option if you want to use Exynos Rotator for DRM.

entry.name: DRM_EXYNOS_GSC
entry.label: GScaler
entry.help: Choose this option if you want to use Exynos GSC for DRM.

entry.name: DRM_ROCKCHIP
entry.label: DRM Support for Rockchip
entry.help: Choose this option if you have a Rockchip soc chipset. This driver provides kernel mode setting and buffer management to userspace. This driver does not provide 2D or 3D acceleration; acceleration is performed by other IP found on the SoC.

entry.name: ROCKCHIP_ANALOGIX_DP
entry.label: Rockchip specific extensions for Analogix DP driver
entry.help: This selects support for Rockchip SoC specific extensions for the Analogix Core DP driver. If you want to enable DP on RK3288 based SoC, you should selet this option.

entry.name: ROCKCHIP_DW_HDMI
entry.label: Rockchip specific extensions for Synopsys DW HDMI
entry.help: This selects support for Rockchip SoC specific extensions for the Synopsys DesignWare HDMI driver. If you want to enable HDMI on RK3288 based SoC, you should selet this option.

entry.name: ROCKCHIP_DW_MIPI_DSI
entry.label: Rockchip specific extensions for Synopsys DW MIPI DSI
entry.help: This selects support for Rockchip SoC specific extensions for the Synopsys DesignWare HDMI driver. If you want to enable MIPI DSI on RK3288 based SoC, you should selet this option.

entry.name: ROCKCHIP_INNO_HDMI
entry.label: Rockchip specific extensions for Innosilicon HDMI
entry.help: This selects support for Rockchip SoC specific extensions for the Innosilicon HDMI driver. If you want to enable HDMI on RK3036 based SoC, you should select this option.

entry.name: DRM_VMWGFX
entry.label: DRM driver for VMware Virtual GPU
entry.help: Choose this option if you would like to run 3D acceleration in a VMware virtual machine. This is a KMS enabled DRM driver for the VMware SVGA2 virtual hardware. The compiled module will be called "vmwgfx.ko".

entry.name: DRM_VMWGFX_FBCON
entry.label: Enable framebuffer console under vmwgfx by default
entry.help: Choose this option if you are shipping a new vmwgfx userspace driver that supports using the kernel driver.

entry.name: DRM_GMA500
entry.label: Intel GMA5/600 KMS Framebuffer
entry.help: Say yes for an experimental 2D KMS framebuffer driver for the Intel GMA500 ('Poulsbo') and other Intel IMG based graphics devices.

entry.name: DRM_GMA600
entry.label: Intel GMA600 support (Experimental)
entry.help: Say yes to include support for GMA600 (Intel Moorestown/Oaktrail) platforms with LVDS ports. MIPI is not currently supported.

entry.name: DRM_GMA3600
entry.label: Intel GMA3600/3650 support (Experimental)
entry.help: Say yes to include basic support for Intel GMA3600/3650 (Intel Cedar Trail) platforms.

entry.name: DRM_MEDFIELD
entry.label: Intel Medfield support (Experimental)
entry.help: Say yes to include support for the Intel Medfield platform.

entry.name: DRM_UDL
entry.label: DisplayLink
entry.help: This is a KMS driver for the USB displaylink video adapters. Say M/Y to add support for these devices via drm/kms interfaces.

entry.name: DRM_AST
entry.label: AST server chips
entry.help: Say yes for experimental AST GPU driver. Do not enable this driver without having a working -modesetting, and a version of AST that knows to fail if KMS is bound to the driver. These GPUs are commonly found in server chipsets.

entry.name: DRM_MGAG200
entry.label: Kernel modesetting driver for MGA G200 server engines
entry.help: This is a KMS driver for the MGA G200 server chips, it does not support the original MGA G200 or any of the desktop chips. It requires 0.3.0 of the modesetting userspace driver, and a version of mga driver that will fail on KMS enabled devices.

entry.name: DRM_CIRRUS_QEMU
entry.label: Cirrus driver for QEMU emulated device
entry.help: This is a KMS driver for emulated cirrus device in qemu. It is *NOT* intended for real cirrus devices. This requires the modesetting userspace X.org driver.

entry.name: DRM_ARMADA
entry.label: DRM support for Marvell Armada SoCs
entry.help:
Support the "LCD" controllers found on the Marvell Armada 510 devices. There are two controllers on the device, each controller supports graphics and video overlays.
This driver provides no built-in acceleration; acceleration is performed by other IP found on the SoC. This driver provides kernel mode setting and buffer management to userspace.

entry.name: DRM_ATMEL_HLCDC
entry.label: DRM Support for ATMEL HLCDC Display Controller
entry.help: Choose this option if you have an ATMEL SoC with an HLCDC display controller (i.e. at91sam9n12, at91sam9x5 family or sama5d3 family).

entry.name: DRM_RCAR_DU
entry.label: DRM Support for R-Car Display Unit
entry.help: Choose this option if you have an R-Car chipset. If M is selected the module will be called rcar-du-drm.

entry.name: DRM_RCAR_HDMI
entry.label: R-Car DU HDMI Encoder Support
entry.help: Enable support for external HDMI encoders.

entry.name: DRM_RCAR_LVDS
entry.label: R-Car DU LVDS Encoder Support
entry.help: Enable support for the R-Car Display Unit embedded LVDS encoders.

entry.name: DRM_RCAR_VSP
entry.label: R-Car DU VSP Compositor Support
entry.help: Enable support to expose the R-Car VSP Compositor as KMS planes.

entry.name: DRM_SHMOBILE
entry.label: DRM Support for SH Mobile
entry.help: Choose this option if you have an SH Mobile chipset. If M is selected the module will be called shmob-drm.

entry.name: DRM_SUN4I
entry.label: DRM Support for Allwinner A10 Display Engine
entry.help: Choose this option if you have an Allwinner SoC with a Display Engine. If M is selected the module will be called sun4i-drm.

entry.name: DRM_OMAP
entry.label: OMAP DRM
entry.help: DRM display driver for OMAP2/3/4 based boards.

entry.name: DRM_OMAP_NUM_CRTCS
entry.label: Number of CRTCs
entry.help: Select the number of video overlays which can be used as framebuffers. The remaining overlays are reserved for video.

entry.name: OMAP2_DSS
entry.label: OMAP2+ Display Subsystem support
entry.help: OMAP2+ Display Subsystem support.

entry.name: OMAP2_DSS_DEBUG
entry.label: Debug support
entry.help: This enables printing of debug messages. Alternatively, debug messages can also be enabled by setting CONFIG_DYNAMIC_DEBUG and then setting appropriate flags in <debugfs>/dynamic_debug/control.

entry.name: OMAP2_DSS_DEBUGFS
entry.label: Debugfs filesystem support
entry.help: This enables debugfs for OMAPDSS at <debugfs>/omapdss. This enables querying about clock configuration and register configuration of dss, dispc, dsi, hdmi and rfbi.

entry.name: OMAP2_DSS_COLLECT_IRQ_STATS
entry.label: Collect DSS IRQ statistics
entry.help:
Collect DSS IRQ statistics, printable via debugfs.
The statistics can be found from <debugfs>/omapdss/dispc_irq for DISPC interrupts, and <debugfs>/omapdss/dsi_irq for DSI interrupts.

entry.name: OMAP2_DSS_DPI
entry.label: DPI support
entry.help: DPI Interface. This is the Parallel Display Interface.

entry.name: OMAP2_DSS_RFBI
entry.label: RFBI support
entry.help:
MIPI DBI support (RFBI, Remote Framebuffer Interface, in Texas Instrument's terminology).
DBI is a bus between the host processor and a peripheral, such as a display or a framebuffer chip.
See http://www.mipi.org/ for DBI specifications.

entry.name: OMAP2_DSS_VENC
entry.label: VENC support
entry.help: OMAP Video Encoder support for S-Video and composite TV-out.

entry.name: OMAP4_DSS_HDMI
entry.label: HDMI support for OMAP4
entry.help: HDMI support for OMAP4 based SoCs.

entry.name: OMAP5_DSS_HDMI
entry.label: HDMI support for OMAP5
entry.help: HDMI Interface for OMAP5 and similar cores. This adds the High Definition Multimedia Interface. See http://www.hdmi.org/ for HDMI specification.

entry.name: OMAP2_DSS_SDI
entry.label: SDI support
entry.help:
SDI (Serial Display Interface) support.
SDI is a high speed one-way display serial bus between the host processor and a display.

entry.name: OMAP2_DSS_DSI
entry.label: DSI support
entry.help:
MIPI DSI (Display Serial Interface) support.
DSI is a high speed half-duplex serial interface between the host processor and a peripheral, such as a display or a framebuffer chip.
See http://www.mipi.org/ for DSI specifications.

entry.name: OMAP2_DSS_MIN_FCK_PER_PCK
entry.label: Minimum FCK/PCK ratio (for scaling)
entry.help:
This can be used to adjust the minimum FCK/PCK ratio.
With this you can make sure that DISPC FCK is at least n x PCK. Video plane scaling requires higher FCK than normally.
If this is set to 0, there's no extra constraint on the DISPC FCK. However, the FCK will at minimum be 2xPCK (if active matrix) or 3xPCK (if passive matrix).
Max FCK is 173MHz, so this doesn't work if your PCK is very high.

entry.name: OMAP2_DSS_SLEEP_AFTER_VENC_RESET
entry.label: Sleep 20ms after VENC reset
entry.help:
There is a 20ms sleep after VENC reset which seemed to fix the reset. The reason for the bug is unclear, and it's also unclear on what platforms this happens.
This option enables the sleep, and is enabled by default. You can disable the sleep if it doesn't cause problems on your platform.

entry.name: DRM_OMAP_ENCODER_OPA362
entry.label: OPA362 external analog amplifier
entry.help: Driver for OPA362 external analog TV amplifier controlled through a GPIO.

entry.name: DRM_OMAP_ENCODER_TFP410
entry.label: TFP410 DPI to DVI Encoder
entry.help: Driver for TFP410 DPI to DVI encoder.

entry.name: DRM_OMAP_ENCODER_TPD12S015
entry.label: TPD12S015 HDMI ESD protection and level shifter
entry.help: Driver for TPD12S015, which offers HDMI ESD protection and level shifting.

entry.name: DRM_OMAP_CONNECTOR_DVI
entry.label: DVI Connector
entry.help: Driver for a generic DVI connector.

entry.name: DRM_OMAP_CONNECTOR_HDMI
entry.label: HDMI Connector
entry.help: Driver for a generic HDMI connector.

entry.name: DRM_OMAP_CONNECTOR_ANALOG_TV
entry.label: Analog TV Connector
entry.help: Driver for a generic analog TV connector.

entry.name: DRM_OMAP_PANEL_DPI
entry.label: Generic DPI panel
entry.help: Driver for generic DPI panels.

entry.name: DRM_OMAP_PANEL_DSI_CM
entry.label: Generic DSI Command Mode Panel
entry.help: Driver for generic DSI command mode panels.

entry.name: DRM_OMAP_PANEL_SONY_ACX565AKM
entry.label: ACX565AKM Panel
entry.help: This is the LCD panel used on Nokia N900

entry.name: DRM_OMAP_PANEL_LGPHILIPS_LB035Q02
entry.label: LG.Philips LB035Q02 LCD Panel
entry.help: LCD Panel used on the Gumstix Overo Palo35

entry.name: DRM_OMAP_PANEL_SHARP_LS037V7DW01
entry.label: Sharp LS037V7DW01 LCD Panel
entry.help: LCD Panel used in TI's SDP3430 and EVM boards

entry.name: DRM_OMAP_PANEL_TPO_TD028TTEC1
entry.label: TPO TD028TTEC1 LCD Panel
entry.help: LCD panel used in Openmoko.

entry.name: DRM_OMAP_PANEL_TPO_TD043MTEA1
entry.label: TPO TD043MTEA1 LCD Panel
entry.help: LCD Panel used in OMAP3 Pandora

entry.name: DRM_OMAP_PANEL_NEC_NL8048HL11
entry.label: NEC NL8048HL11 Panel
entry.help: This NEC NL8048HL11 panel is TFT LCD used in the Zoom2/3/3630 sdp boards.

entry.name: DRM_TILCDC
entry.label: DRM Support for TI LCDC Display Controller
entry.help: Choose this option if you have an TI SoC with LCDC display controller, for example AM33xx in beagle-bone, DA8xx, or OMAP-L1xx. This driver replaces the FB_DA8XX fbdev driver.

entry.name: DRM_TILCDC_SLAVE_COMPAT
entry.label: Support device tree blobs using TI LCDC Slave binding
entry.help: Choose this option if you need a kernel that is compatible with device tree blobs using the obsolete "ti,tilcdc,slave" binding. If you find "ti,tilcdc,slave"-string from your DTB, you probably need this. Otherwise you do not.

entry.name: DRM_QXL
entry.label: QXL virtual GPU
entry.help: QXL virtual GPU for Spice virtualization desktop integration. Do not enable this driver unless your distro ships a corresponding X.org QXL driver that can handle kernel modesetting.

entry.name: DRM_BOCHS
entry.label: DRM Support for bochs dispi vga interface (qemu stdvga)
entry.help: Choose this option for qemu. If M is selected the module will be called bochs-drm.

entry.name: DRM_VIRTIO_GPU
entry.label: Virtio GPU driver
entry.help:
This is the virtual GPU driver for virtio. It can be used with QEMU based VMMs (like KVM or Xen).
If unsure say M.

entry.name: DRM_MSM
entry.label: MSM DRM
entry.help: DRM/KMS driver for MSM/snapdragon.

entry.name: DRM_MSM_REGISTER_LOGGING
entry.label: MSM DRM register logging
entry.help: Compile in support for logging register reads/writes in a format that can be parsed by envytools demsm tool. If enabled, register logging can be switched on via msm.reglog=y module param.

entry.name: DRM_MSM_HDMI_HDCP
entry.label: Enable HDMI HDCP support in MSM DRM driver
entry.help: Choose this option to enable HDCP state machine

entry.name: DRM_MSM_DSI
entry.label: Enable DSI support in MSM DRM driver
entry.help: Choose this option if you have a need for MIPI DSI connector support.

entry.name: DRM_MSM_DSI_PLL
entry.label: Enable DSI PLL driver in MSM DRM
entry.help: Choose this option to enable DSI PLL driver which provides DSI source clocks under common clock framework.

entry.name: DRM_MSM_DSI_28NM_PHY
entry.label: Enable DSI 28nm PHY driver in MSM DRM
entry.help: Choose this option if the 28nm DSI PHY is used on the platform.

entry.name: FB
entry.label: Support for frame buffer devices
entry.help:
The frame buffer device provides an abstraction for the graphics hardware. It represents the frame buffer of some video hardware and allows application software to access the graphics hardware through a well-defined interface, so the software doesn't need to know anything about the low-level (hardware register) stuff.
Frame buffer devices work identically across the different architectures supported by Linux and make the implementation of application programs easier and more portable; at this point, an X server exists which uses the frame buffer device exclusively. On several non-X86 architectures, the frame buffer device is the only way to use the graphics hardware.
The device is accessed through special device nodes, usually located in the /dev directory, i.e. /dev/fb*.
You need an utility program called fbset to make full use of frame buffer devices. Please read <file:Documentation/fb/framebuffer.txt> and the Framebuffer-HOWTO at <http://www.munted.org.uk/programming/Framebuffer-HOWTO-1.3.html> for more information.
Say Y here and to the driver for your graphics board below if you are compiling a kernel for a non-x86 architecture.
If you are compiling for the x86 architecture, you can say Y if you want to play with it, but it is not essential. Please note that running graphical applications that directly touch the hardware (e.g. an accelerated X server) and that are not frame buffer device-aware may cause unexpected results. If unsure, say N.

entry.name: FIRMWARE_EDID
entry.label: Enable firmware EDID
entry.help:
This enables access to the EDID transferred from the firmware. On the i386, this is from the Video BIOS. Enable this if DDC/I2C transfers do not work for your driver and if you are using nvidiafb, i810fb or savagefb.
In general, choosing Y for this option is safe. If you experience extremely long delays while booting before you get something on your display, try setting this to N. Matrox cards in combination with certain motherboards and monitors are known to suffer from this problem.

entry.name: FB_BOOT_VESA_SUPPORT
entry.help: If true, at least one selected framebuffer driver can take advantage of VESA video modes set at an early boot stage via the vga= parameter.

entry.name: FB_CFB_FILLRECT
entry.help: Include the cfb_fillrect function for generic software rectangle filling. This is used by drivers that don't provide their own (accelerated) version.

entry.name: FB_CFB_COPYAREA
entry.help: Include the cfb_copyarea function for generic software area copying. This is used by drivers that don't provide their own (accelerated) version.

entry.name: FB_CFB_IMAGEBLIT

entry.name: FB_CFB_REV_PIXELS_IN_BYTE
entry.help: Allow generic frame-buffer functions to work on displays with 1, 2 and 4 bits per pixel depths which has opposite order of pixels in byte order to bytes in long order.

entry.name: FB_SYS_FILLRECT
entry.help: Include the sys_fillrect function for generic software rectangle filling. This is used by drivers that don't provide their own (accelerated) version and the framebuffer is in system RAM.

entry.name: FB_SYS_COPYAREA

entry.name: FB_SYS_IMAGEBLIT

entry.name: FB_FOREIGN_ENDIAN
entry.label: Framebuffer foreign endianness support
entry.help: This menu will let you enable support for the framebuffers with non-native endianness (e.g. Little-Endian framebuffer on a Big-Endian machine). Most probably you don't have such hardware, so it's safe to say "n" here.

entry.name: FB_BOTH_ENDIAN
entry.label: Support for Big- and Little-Endian framebuffers

entry.name: FB_SVGALIB
entry.help: Common utility functions useful to fbdev drivers of VGA-based cards.

entry.name: FB_MODE_HELPERS
entry.label: Enable Video Mode Handling Helpers
entry.help: This enables functions for handling video modes using the Generalized Timing Formula and the EDID parser. A few drivers rely on this feature such as the radeonfb, rivafb, and the i810fb. If your driver does not take advantage of this feature, choosing Y will just increase the kernel size by about 5K.

entry.name: FB_TILEBLITTING
entry.label: Enable Tile Blitting Support
entry.help:
This enables tile blitting. Tile blitting is a drawing technique where the screen is divided into rectangular sections (tiles), whereas the standard blitting divides the screen into pixels. Because the default drawing element is a tile, drawing functions will be passed parameters in terms of number of tiles instead of number of pixels. For example, to draw a single character, instead of using bitmaps, an index to an array of bitmaps will be used. To clear or move a rectangular section of a screen, the rectangle will be described in terms of number of tiles in the x- and y-axis.
This is particularly important to one driver, matroxfb. If unsure, say N.

entry.name: FB_GRVGA
entry.label: Aeroflex Gaisler framebuffer support
entry.help: This enables support for the SVGACTRL framebuffer in the GRLIB IP library from Aeroflex Gaisler.

entry.name: FB_CIRRUS
entry.label: Cirrus Logic support
entry.help:
This enables support for Cirrus Logic GD542x/543x based boards on Amiga: SD64, Piccolo, Picasso II/II+, Picasso IV, or EGS Spectrum.
If you have a PCI-based system, this enables support for these chips: GD-543x, GD-544x, GD-5480.
Please read the file <file:Documentation/fb/cirrusfb.txt>.
Say N unless you have such a graphics board or plan to get one before you next recompile the kernel.

entry.name: FB_PM2
entry.label: Permedia2 support
entry.help:
This is the frame buffer device driver for cards based on the 3D Labs Permedia, Permedia 2 and Permedia 2V chips. The driver was tested on the following cards: Diamond FireGL 1000 PRO AGP ELSA Gloria Synergy PCI Appian Jeronimo PRO (both heads) PCI 3DLabs Oxygen ACX aka EONtronics Picasso P2 PCI Techsource Raptor GFX-8P (aka Sun PGX-32) on SPARC ASK Graphic Blaster Exxtreme AGP
To compile this driver as a module, choose M here: the module will be called pm2fb.

entry.name: FB_PM2_FIFO_DISCONNECT
entry.label: enable FIFO disconnect feature
entry.help: Support the Permedia2 FIFO disconnect feature.

entry.name: FB_ARMCLCD
entry.label: ARM PrimeCell PL110 support
entry.help:
This framebuffer device driver is for the ARM PrimeCell PL110 Colour LCD controller. ARM PrimeCells provide the building blocks for System on a Chip devices.
If you want to compile this as a module (=code which can be inserted into and removed from the running kernel), say M here and read <file:Documentation/kbuild/modules.txt>. The module will be called amba-clcd.

entry.name: FB_ACORN
entry.label: Acorn VIDC support
entry.help: This is the frame buffer device driver for the Acorn VIDC graphics hardware found in Acorn RISC PCs and other ARM-based machines. If unsure, say N.

entry.name: FB_CLPS711X
entry.label: CLPS711X LCD support
entry.help: Say Y to enable the Framebuffer driver for the Cirrus Logic CLPS711X CPUs.

entry.name: FB_SA1100
entry.label: SA-1100 LCD support
entry.help:
This is a framebuffer device for the SA-1100 LCD Controller. See <http://www.linux-fbdev.org/> for information on framebuffer devices.
If you plan to use the LCD display with your SA-1100 system, say Y here.

entry.help: This enables support for the Integraphics CyberPro 20x0 and 5000 VGA chips used in the Rebel.com Netwinder and other machines. Say Y if you have a NetWinder or a graphics card containing this device, otherwise say N.

entry.name: FB_CYBER2000_DDC
entry.label: DDC for CyberPro support
entry.help: Say Y here if you want DDC support for your CyberPro graphics card. This is only I2C bus support, driver does not use EDID.

entry.name: FB_CYBER2000_I2C
entry.label: CyberPro 2000/2010/5000 I2C support
entry.help: Enable support for the I2C video decoder interface on the Integraphics CyberPro 20x0 and 5000 VGA chips. This is used on the Netwinder machines for the SAA7111 video capture.

entry.name: FB_AMIGA
entry.label: Amiga native chipset support
entry.help:
This is the frame buffer device driver for the builtin graphics chipset found in Amigas.
To compile this driver as a module, choose M here: the module will be called amifb.

entry.name: FB_AMIGA_OCS
entry.label: Amiga OCS chipset support
entry.help: This enables support for the original Agnus and Denise video chips, found in the Amiga 1000 and most A500's and A2000's. If you intend to run Linux on any of these systems, say Y; otherwise say N.

entry.name: FB_AMIGA_ECS
entry.label: Amiga ECS chipset support
entry.help: This enables support for the Enhanced Chip Set, found in later A500's, later A2000's, the A600, the A3000, the A3000T and CDTV. If you intend to run Linux on any of these systems, say Y; otherwise say N.

entry.name: FB_AMIGA_AGA
entry.label: Amiga AGA chipset support
entry.help: This enables support for the Advanced Graphics Architecture (also known as the AGA or AA) Chip Set, found in the A1200, A4000, A4000T and CD32. If you intend to run Linux on any of these systems, say Y; otherwise say N.

entry.name: FB_FM2
entry.label: Amiga FrameMaster II/Rainbow II support
entry.help: This is the frame buffer device driver for the Amiga FrameMaster card from BSC (exhibited 1992 but not shipped as a CBM product).

entry.name: FB_ARC
entry.label: Arc Monochrome LCD board support
entry.help: This enables support for the Arc Monochrome LCD board. The board is based on the KS-108 lcd controller and is typically a matrix of 2*n chips. This driver was tested with a 128x64 panel. This driver supports it for use with x86 SBCs through a 16 bit GPIO interface (8 bit data, 8 bit control). If you anticipate using this driver, say Y or M; otherwise say N. You must specify the GPIO IO address to be used for setting control and data.

entry.name: FB_ATARI
entry.label: Atari native chipset support
entry.help: This is the frame buffer device driver for the builtin graphics chipset found in Ataris.

entry.name: FB_OF

entry.name: FB_VALKYRIE

entry.name: FB_ASILIANT

entry.name: FB_IMSTT

entry.name: FB_BF54X_LQ043
entry.label: SHARP LQ043 TFT LCD (BF548 EZKIT)
entry.help: This is the framebuffer device driver for a SHARP LQ043T1DG01 TFT LCD

entry.name: FB_BFIN_T350MCQB

entry.help: This is the framebuffer device driver for a Varitronix VL-PS-COG-T350MCQB-01 display TFT LCD This display is a QVGA 320x240 24-bit RGB display interfaced by an 8-bit wide PPI It uses PPI[0..7] PPI_FS1, PPI_FS2 and PPI_CLK.

entry.name: FB_BFIN_LQ035Q1

This is the framebuffer device driver for a SHARP LQ035Q1DH02 TFT display found on the Blackfin Landscape LCD EZ-Extender Card. This display is a QVGA 320x240 18-bit RGB display interfaced by an 16-bit wide PPI It uses PPI[0..15] PPI_FS1, PPI_FS2 and PPI_CLK.
To compile this driver as a module, choose M here: the module will be called bfin-lq035q1-fb.

entry.name: FB_BF537_LQ035

This is the framebuffer device for a SHARP LQ035Q7DB03 TFT LCD attached to a BF537.
To compile this driver as a module, choose M here: the module will be called bf537-lq035.

entry.name: FB_BFIN_7393
entry.label: Blackfin ADV7393 Video encoder
entry.help:
This is the framebuffer device for a ADV7393 video encoder attached to a Blackfin on the PPI port. If your Blackfin board has a ADV7393 select Y.
To compile this driver as a module, choose M here: the module will be called bfin_adv7393fb.

entry.name: FB_STI
entry.label: HP STI frame buffer device support
entry.help:
STI refers to the HP "Standard Text Interface" which is a set of BIOS routines contained in a ROM chip in HP PA-RISC based machines. Enabling this option will implement the linux framebuffer device using calls to the STI BIOS routines for initialisation.
If you enable this option, you will get a planar framebuffer device /dev/fb which will work on the most common HP graphic cards of the NGLE family, including the artist chips (in the 7xx and Bxxx series), HCRX, HCRX24, CRX, CRX24 and VisEG series.
It is safe to enable this option, so you should probably say "Y".

entry.name: FB_TGA
entry.label: TGA/SFB+ framebuffer support
entry.help:
This is the frame buffer device driver for generic TGA and SFB+ graphic cards. These include DEC ZLXp-E1, -E2 and -E3 PCI cards, also known as PBXGA-A, -B and -C, and DEC ZLX-E1, -E2 and -E3 TURBOchannel cards, also known as PMAGD-A, -B and -C.
Due to hardware limitations ZLX-E2 and E3 cards are not supported for DECstation 5000/200 systems. Additionally due to firmware limitations these cards may cause troubles with booting DECstation 5000/240 and /260 systems, but are fully supported under Linux if you manage to get it going. ;-)
Say Y if you have one of those.

entry.name: FB_UVESA
entry.label: Userspace VESA VGA graphics support
entry.help:
This is the frame buffer driver for generic VBE 2.0 compliant graphic cards. It can also take advantage of VBE 3.0 features, such as refresh rate adjustment.
This driver generally provides more features than vesafb but requires a userspace helper application called 'v86d'. See <file:Documentation/fb/uvesafb.txt> for more information.
If unsure, say N.

entry.name: FB_VESA
entry.label: VESA VGA graphics support
entry.help: This is the frame buffer device driver for generic VESA 2.0 compliant graphic cards. The older VESA 1.2 cards are not supported. You will get a boot time penguin logo at no additional cost. Please read <file:Documentation/fb/vesafb.txt>. If unsure, say Y.

entry.name: FB_EFI
entry.label: EFI-based Framebuffer Support
entry.help: This is the EFI frame buffer device driver. If the firmware on your platform is EFI 1.10 or UEFI 2.0, select Y to add support for using the EFI framebuffer as your console.

entry.name: FB_N411
entry.label: N411 Apollo/Hecuba devkit support
entry.help: This enables support for the Apollo display controller in its Hecuba form using the n411 devkit.

entry.name: FB_HGA
entry.label: Hercules mono graphics support
entry.help:
Say Y here if you have a Hercules mono graphics card.
To compile this driver as a module, choose M here: the module will be called hgafb.
As this card technology is at least 25 years old, most people will answer N here.

entry.name: FB_GBE
entry.label: SGI Graphics Backend frame buffer support
entry.help: This is the frame buffer device driver for SGI Graphics Backend. This chip is used in SGI O2 and Visual Workstation 320/540.

entry.name: FB_GBE_MEM
entry.label: Video memory size in MB
entry.help: This is the amount of memory reserved for the framebuffer, which can be any value between 1MB and 8MB.

entry.name: FB_SBUS
entry.label: SBUS and UPA framebuffers
entry.help: Say Y if you want support for SBUS or UPA based frame buffer device.

entry.name: FB_BW2
entry.label: BWtwo support
entry.help: This is the frame buffer device driver for the BWtwo frame buffer.

entry.name: FB_CG3
entry.label: CGthree support
entry.help: This is the frame buffer device driver for the CGthree frame buffer.

entry.name: FB_CG6
entry.label: CGsix (GX,TurboGX) support
entry.help: This is the frame buffer device driver for the CGsix (GX, TurboGX) frame buffer.

entry.name: FB_FFB
entry.label: Creator/Creator3D/Elite3D support
entry.help: This is the frame buffer device driver for the Creator, Creator3D, and Elite3D graphics boards.

entry.name: FB_TCX

entry.help: This is the frame buffer device driver for the TCX 24/8bit frame buffer.

entry.name: FB_CG14

entry.name: FB_P9100

entry.name: FB_LEO

entry.help: This is the frame buffer device driver for the SBUS-based Sun ZX (leo) frame buffer cards.

entry.name: FB_IGA
entry.label: IGA 168x display support
entry.help: This is the framebuffer device for the INTERGRAPHICS 1680 and successor frame buffer cards.

entry.name: FB_XVR500
entry.label: Sun XVR-500 3DLABS Wildcat support
entry.help: This is the framebuffer device for the Sun XVR-500 and similar graphics cards based upon the 3DLABS Wildcat chipset. The driver only works on sparc64 systems where the system firmware has mostly initialized the card already. It is treated as a completely dumb framebuffer device.

entry.name: FB_XVR2500
entry.label: Sun XVR-2500 3DLABS Wildcat support
entry.help: This is the framebuffer device for the Sun XVR-2500 and similar graphics cards based upon the 3DLABS Wildcat chipset. The driver only works on sparc64 systems where the system firmware has mostly initialized the card already. It is treated as a completely dumb framebuffer device.

entry.name: FB_XVR1000
entry.label: Sun XVR-1000 support
entry.help: This is the framebuffer device for the Sun XVR-1000 and similar graphics cards. The driver only works on sparc64 systems where the system firmware has mostly initialized the card already. It is treated as a completely dumb framebuffer device.

entry.name: FB_PVR2
entry.label: NEC PowerVR 2 display support
entry.help:
Say Y here if you have a PowerVR 2 card in your box. If you plan to run linux on your Dreamcast, you will have to say Y here. This driver may or may not work on other PowerVR 2 cards, but is totally untested. Use at your own risk. If unsure, say N.
To compile this driver as a module, choose M here: the module will be called pvr2fb.
You can pass several parameters to the driver at boot time or at module load time. The parameters look like "video=pvr2:XXX", where the meaning of XXX can be found at the end of the main source file (<file:drivers/video/pvr2fb.c>). Please see the file <file:Documentation/fb/pvr2fb.txt>.

entry.name: FB_OPENCORES
entry.label: OpenCores VGA/LCD core 2.0 framebuffer support
entry.help:
This enables support for the OpenCores VGA/LCD core.
The OpenCores VGA/LCD core is typically used together with softcore CPUs (e.g. OpenRISC or Microblaze) or hard processor systems (e.g. Altera socfpga or Xilinx Zynq) on FPGAs.
The source code and specification for the core is available at <http://opencores.org/project,vga_lcd>

entry.name: FB_I810_GTF
entry.label: use VESA Generalized Timing Formula
entry.help:
If you say Y, then the VESA standard, Generalized Timing Formula or GTF, will be used to calculate the required video timing values per video mode. Since the GTF allows nondiscrete timings (nondiscrete being a range of values as opposed to discrete being a set of values), you'll be able to use any combination of horizontal and vertical resolutions, and vertical refresh rates without having to specify your own timing parameters. This is especially useful to maximize the performance of an aging display, or if you just have a display with nonstandard dimensions. A VESA compliant monitor is recommended, but can still work with non-compliant ones. If you need or want this, then select this option. The timings may not be compliant with Intel's recommended values. Use at your own risk.
If you say N, the driver will revert to discrete video timings using a set recommended by Intel in their documentation.
If unsure, say N.

Say Y if you have and plan to use such a board.

config FB_MATROX tristate "Matrox acceleration" depends on FB && PCI select FB_CFB_FILLRECT select FB_CFB_COPYAREA select FB_CFB_IMAGEBLIT select FB_TILEBLITTING select FB_MACMODES if PPC_PMAC ---help--- Say Y here if you have a Matrox Millennium, Matrox Millennium II, Matrox Mystique, Matrox Mystique 220, Matrox Productiva G100, Matrox Mystique G200, Matrox Millennium G200, Matrox Marvel G200 video, Matrox G400, G450 or G550 card in your box.
To compile this driver as a module, choose M here: the module will be called matroxfb.
You can pass several parameters to the driver at boot time or at module load time. The parameters look like "video=matroxfb:XXX", and are described in <file:Documentation/fb/matroxfb.txt>.
config FB_MATROX_MILLENIUM bool "Millennium I/II support" depends on FB_MATROX help Say Y here if you have a Matrox Millennium or Matrox Millennium II video card. If you select "Advanced lowlevel driver options" below, you should check 4 bpp packed pixel, 8 bpp packed pixel, 16 bpp packed pixel, 24 bpp packed pixel and 32 bpp packed pixel. You can also use font widths different from 8.
config FB_MATROX_MYSTIQUE bool "Mystique support" depends on FB_MATROX help Say Y here if you have a Matrox Mystique or Matrox Mystique 220 video card. If you select "Advanced lowlevel driver options" below, you should check 8 bpp packed pixel, 16 bpp packed pixel, 24 bpp packed pixel and 32 bpp packed pixel. You can also use font widths different from 8.
config FB_MATROX_G bool "G100/G200/G400/G450/G550 support" depends on FB_MATROX ---help--- Say Y here if you have a Matrox G100, G200, G400, G450 or G550 based video card. If you select "Advanced lowlevel driver options", you should check 8 bpp packed pixel, 16 bpp packed pixel, 24 bpp packed pixel and 32 bpp packed pixel. You can also use font widths different from 8.
If you need support for G400 secondary head, you must say Y to "Matrox I2C support" and "G400 second head support" right below. G450/G550 secondary head and digital output are supported without additional modules.
The driver starts in monitor mode. You must use the matroxset tool (available at <ftp://platan.vc.cvut.cz/pub/linux/matrox-latest/>) to swap primary and secondary head outputs, or to change output mode. Secondary head driver always start in 640x480 resolution and you must use fbset to change it.
Do not forget that second head supports only 16 and 32 bpp packed pixels, so it is a good idea to compile them into the kernel too. You can use only some font widths, as the driver uses generic painting procedures (the secondary head does not use acceleration engine).
G450/G550 hardware can display TV picture only from secondary CRTC, and it performs no scaling, so picture must have 525 or 625 lines.
config FB_MATROX_I2C tristate "Matrox I2C support" depends on FB_MATROX select FB_DDC ---help--- This drivers creates I2C buses which are needed for accessing the DDC (I2C) bus present on all Matroxes, an I2C bus which interconnects Matrox optional devices, like MGA-TVO on G200 and G400, and the secondary head DDC bus, present on G400 only.
You can say Y or M here if you want to experiment with monitor detection code. You must say Y or M here if you want to use either second head of G400 or MGA-TVO on G200 or G400.
If you compile it as module, it will create a module named i2c-matroxfb.
config FB_MATROX_MAVEN tristate "G400 second head support" depends on FB_MATROX_G && FB_MATROX_I2C ---help--- WARNING !!! This support does not work with G450 !!!
Say Y or M here if you want to use a secondary head (meaning two monitors in parallel) on G400 or MGA-TVO add-on on G200. Secondary head is not compatible with accelerated XFree 3.3.x SVGA servers - secondary head output is blanked while you are in X. With XFree 3.9.17 preview you can use both heads if you use SVGA over fbdev or the fbdev driver on first head and the fbdev driver on second head.
If you compile it as module, two modules are created, matroxfb_crtc2 and matroxfb_maven. Matroxfb_maven is needed for both G200 and G400, matroxfb_crtc2 is needed only by G400. You must also load i2c-matroxfb to get it to run.
The driver starts in monitor mode and you must use the matroxset tool (available at <ftp://platan.vc.cvut.cz/pub/linux/matrox-latest/>) to switch it to PAL or NTSC or to swap primary and secondary head outputs. Secondary head driver also always start in 640x480 resolution, you must use fbset to change it.
Also do not forget that second head supports only 16 and 32 bpp packed pixels, so it is a good idea to compile them into the kernel too. You can use only some font widths, as the driver uses generic painting procedures (the secondary head does not use acceleration engine).
