entry.label: ChaCha20-Poly1305 AEAD support
entry.help:
ChaCha20-Poly1305 AEAD support, RFC7539.
Support for the AEAD wrapper using the ChaCha20 stream cipher combined with the Poly1305 authenticator. It is defined in RFC7539 for use in IETF protocols.

entry.name: CRYPTO_SEQIV
entry.label: Sequence Number IV Generator
entry.help: This IV generator generates an IV based on a sequence number by xoring it with a salt. This algorithm is mainly useful for CTR

entry.name: CRYPTO_ECHAINIV
entry.label: Encrypted Chain IV Generator
entry.help: This IV generator generates an IV based on the encryption of a sequence number xored with a salt. This is the default algorithm for CBC.

entry.name: CRYPTO_CBC
entry.label: CBC support
entry.help: CBC: Cipher Block Chaining mode This block cipher algorithm is required for IPSec.

entry.name: CRYPTO_CTR
entry.label: CTR support
entry.help: CTR: Counter mode This block cipher algorithm is required for IPSec.

entry.name: CRYPTO_CTS
entry.label: CTS support
entry.help: CTS: Cipher Text Stealing This is the Cipher Text Stealing mode as described by Section 8 of rfc2040 and referenced by rfc3962. (rfc3962 includes errata information in its Appendix A) This mode is required for Kerberos gss mechanism support for AES encryption.

entry.name: CRYPTO_ECB
entry.label: ECB support
entry.help: ECB: Electronic CodeBook mode This is the simplest block cipher algorithm. It simply encrypts the input block by block.

entry.name: CRYPTO_LRW
entry.label: LRW support
entry.help: LRW: Liskov Rivest Wagner, a tweakable, non malleable, non movable narrow block cipher mode for dm-crypt. Use it with cipher specification string aes-lrw-benbi, the key must be 256, 320 or 384. The first 128, 192 or 256 bits in the key are used for AES and the rest is used to tie each cipher block to its logical position.

entry.name: CRYPTO_PCBC
entry.label: PCBC support
entry.help: PCBC: Propagating Cipher Block Chaining mode This block cipher algorithm is required for RxRPC.

entry.name: CRYPTO_XTS
entry.label: XTS support
entry.help: XTS: IEEE1619/D16 narrow block cipher use with aes-xts-plain, key size 256, 384 or 512 bits. This implementation currently can't handle a sectorsize which is not a multiple of 16 bytes.

entry.name: CRYPTO_KEYWRAP
entry.label: Key wrapping support
entry.help: Support for key wrapping (NIST SP800-38F / RFC3394) without padding.

entry.name: CRYPTO_CMAC
entry.label: CMAC support
entry.help:
Cipher-based Message Authentication Code (CMAC) specified by The National Institute of Standards and Technology (NIST).
https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc4493 http://csrc.nist.gov/publications/nistpubs/800-38B/SP_800-38B.pdf

entry.name: CRYPTO_HMAC
entry.label: HMAC support
entry.help: HMAC: Keyed-Hashing for Message Authentication (RFC2104). This is required for IPSec.

entry.name: CRYPTO_XCBC
entry.label: XCBC support
entry.help: XCBC: Keyed-Hashing with encryption algorithm http://www.ietf.org/rfc/rfc3566.txt http://csrc.nist.gov/encryption/modes/proposedmodes/ xcbc-mac/xcbc-mac-spec.pdf

entry.name: CRYPTO_VMAC
entry.label: VMAC support
entry.help:
VMAC is a message authentication algorithm designed for very high speed on 64-bit architectures.
See also: <http://fastcrypto.org/vmac>

entry.name: CRYPTO_CRC32C
entry.label: CRC32c CRC algorithm
entry.help: Castagnoli, et al Cyclic Redundancy-Check Algorithm. Used by iSCSI for header and data digests and by others. See Castagnoli93. Module will be crc32c.

entry.name: CRYPTO_CRC32C_INTEL
entry.label: CRC32c INTEL hardware acceleration
entry.help: In Intel processor with SSE4.2 supported, the processor will support CRC32C implementation using hardware accelerated CRC32 instruction. This option will create 'crc32c-intel' module, which will enable any routine to use the CRC32 instruction to gain performance compared with software implementation. Module will be crc32c-intel.

entry.name: CRYPT_CRC32C_VPMSUM
entry.label: CRC32c CRC algorithm (powerpc64)
entry.help: CRC32c algorithm implemented using vector polynomial multiply-sum (vpmsum) instructions, introduced in POWER8. Enable on POWER8 and newer processors for improved performance.

entry.name: CRYPTO_CRC32C_SPARC64
entry.label: CRC32c CRC algorithm (SPARC64)
entry.help: CRC32c CRC algorithm implemented using sparc64 crypto instructions, when available.

entry.name: CRYPTO_CRC32
entry.label: CRC32 CRC algorithm
entry.help: CRC-32-IEEE 802.3 cyclic redundancy-check algorithm. Shash crypto api wrappers to crc32_le function.

entry.name: CRYPTO_CRC32_PCLMUL
entry.label: CRC32 PCLMULQDQ hardware acceleration
entry.help: From Intel Westmere and AMD Bulldozer processor with SSE4.2 and PCLMULQDQ supported, the processor will support CRC32 PCLMULQDQ implementation using hardware accelerated PCLMULQDQ instruction. This option will create 'crc32-plcmul' module, which will enable any routine to use the CRC-32-IEEE 802.3 checksum and gain better performance as compared with the table implementation.

entry.name: CRYPTO_CRCT10DIF
entry.label: CRCT10DIF algorithm
entry.help: CRC T10 Data Integrity Field computation is being cast as a crypto transform. This allows for faster crc t10 diff transforms to be used if they are available.

entry.name: CRYPTO_CRCT10DIF_PCLMUL
entry.label: CRCT10DIF PCLMULQDQ hardware acceleration
entry.help: For x86_64 processors with SSE4.2 and PCLMULQDQ supported, CRC T10 DIF PCLMULQDQ computation can be hardware accelerated PCLMULQDQ instruction. This option will create 'crct10dif-plcmul' module, which is faster when computing the crct10dif checksum as compared with the generic table implementation.

entry.name: CRYPTO_GHASH
entry.label: GHASH digest algorithm
entry.help: GHASH is message digest algorithm for GCM (Galois/Counter Mode).

entry.name: CRYPTO_POLY1305
entry.label: Poly1305 authenticator algorithm
entry.help:
Poly1305 authenticator algorithm, RFC7539.
Poly1305 is an authenticator algorithm designed by Daniel J. Bernstein. It is used for the ChaCha20-Poly1305 AEAD, specified in RFC7539 for use in IETF protocols. This is the portable C implementation of Poly1305.

entry.name: CRYPTO_POLY1305_X86_64
entry.label: Poly1305 authenticator algorithm (x86_64/SSE2/AVX2)
entry.help:
Poly1305 authenticator algorithm, RFC7539.
Poly1305 is an authenticator algorithm designed by Daniel J. Bernstein. It is used for the ChaCha20-Poly1305 AEAD, specified in RFC7539 for use in IETF protocols. This is the x86_64 assembler implementation using SIMD instructions.

entry.name: CRYPTO_MD4
entry.label: MD4 digest algorithm
entry.help: MD4 message digest algorithm (RFC1320).

entry.name: CRYPTO_MD5
entry.label: MD5 digest algorithm
entry.help: MD5 message digest algorithm (RFC1321).

entry.name: CRYPTO_MD5_OCTEON
entry.label: MD5 digest algorithm (OCTEON)
entry.help: MD5 message digest algorithm (RFC1321) implemented using OCTEON crypto instructions, when available.

entry.name: CRYPTO_MD5_PPC
entry.label: MD5 digest algorithm (PPC)
entry.help: MD5 message digest algorithm (RFC1321) implemented in PPC assembler.

entry.name: CRYPTO_MD5_SPARC64
entry.label: MD5 digest algorithm (SPARC64)
entry.help: MD5 message digest algorithm (RFC1321) implemented using sparc64 crypto instructions, when available.

entry.name: CRYPTO_MICHAEL_MIC
entry.label: Michael MIC keyed digest algorithm
entry.help: Michael MIC is used for message integrity protection in TKIP (IEEE 802.11i). This algorithm is required for TKIP, but it should not be used for other purposes because of the weakness of the algorithm.

entry.name: CRYPTO_RMD128
entry.label: RIPEMD-128 digest algorithm
entry.help:
RIPEMD-128 (ISO/IEC 10118-3:2004).
RIPEMD-128 is a 128-bit cryptographic hash function. It should only be used as a secure replacement for RIPEMD. For other use cases, RIPEMD-160 should be used.
Developed by Hans Dobbertin, Antoon Bosselaers and Bart Preneel. See <http://homes.esat.kuleuven.be/~bosselae/ripemd160.html>

entry.name: CRYPTO_RMD160
entry.label: RIPEMD-160 digest algorithm
entry.help:
RIPEMD-160 (ISO/IEC 10118-3:2004).
RIPEMD-160 is a 160-bit cryptographic hash function. It is intended to be used as a secure replacement for the 128-bit hash functions MD4, MD5 and it's predecessor RIPEMD (not to be confused with RIPEMD-128).
It's speed is comparable to SHA1 and there are no known attacks against RIPEMD-160.
Developed by Hans Dobbertin, Antoon Bosselaers and Bart Preneel. See <http://homes.esat.kuleuven.be/~bosselae/ripemd160.html>

entry.name: CRYPTO_RMD256
entry.label: RIPEMD-256 digest algorithm
entry.help:
RIPEMD-256 is an optional extension of RIPEMD-128 with a 256 bit hash. It is intended for applications that require longer hash-results, without needing a larger security level (than RIPEMD-128).
Developed by Hans Dobbertin, Antoon Bosselaers and Bart Preneel. See <http://homes.esat.kuleuven.be/~bosselae/ripemd160.html>

entry.name: CRYPTO_RMD320
entry.label: RIPEMD-320 digest algorithm
entry.help:
RIPEMD-320 is an optional extension of RIPEMD-160 with a 320 bit hash. It is intended for applications that require longer hash-results, without needing a larger security level (than RIPEMD-160).
Developed by Hans Dobbertin, Antoon Bosselaers and Bart Preneel. See <http://homes.esat.kuleuven.be/~bosselae/ripemd160.html>

entry.name: CRYPTO_SHA1
entry.label: SHA1 digest algorithm
entry.help: SHA-1 secure hash standard (FIPS 180-1/DFIPS 180-2).

entry.name: CRYPTO_SHA1_SSSE3
entry.label: SHA1 digest algorithm (SSSE3/AVX/AVX2/SHA-NI)
entry.help: SHA-1 secure hash standard (FIPS 180-1/DFIPS 180-2) implemented using Supplemental SSE3 (SSSE3) instructions or Advanced Vector Extensions (AVX/AVX2) or SHA-NI(SHA Extensions New Instructions), when available.

entry.name: CRYPTO_SHA256_SSSE3
entry.label: SHA256 digest algorithm (SSSE3/AVX/AVX2/SHA-NI)
entry.help: SHA-256 secure hash standard (DFIPS 180-2) implemented using Supplemental SSE3 (SSSE3) instructions, or Advanced Vector Extensions version 1 (AVX1), or Advanced Vector Extensions version 2 (AVX2) instructions, or SHA-NI (SHA Extensions New Instructions) when available.

entry.name: CRYPTO_SHA512_SSSE3
entry.label: SHA512 digest algorithm (SSSE3/AVX/AVX2)
entry.help: SHA-512 secure hash standard (DFIPS 180-2) implemented using Supplemental SSE3 (SSSE3) instructions, or Advanced Vector Extensions version 1 (AVX1), or Advanced Vector Extensions version 2 (AVX2) instructions, when available.

entry.name: CRYPTO_SHA1_OCTEON
entry.label: SHA1 digest algorithm (OCTEON)
entry.help: SHA-1 secure hash standard (FIPS 180-1/DFIPS 180-2) implemented using OCTEON crypto instructions, when available.

entry.name: CRYPTO_SHA1_SPARC64
entry.label: SHA1 digest algorithm (SPARC64)
entry.help: SHA-1 secure hash standard (FIPS 180-1/DFIPS 180-2) implemented using sparc64 crypto instructions, when available.

entry.name: CRYPTO_SHA1_PPC
entry.label: SHA1 digest algorithm (powerpc)
entry.help: This is the powerpc hardware accelerated implementation of the SHA-1 secure hash standard (FIPS 180-1/DFIPS 180-2).

entry.name: CRYPTO_SHA1_PPC_SPE
entry.label: SHA1 digest algorithm (PPC SPE)
entry.help: SHA-1 secure hash standard (DFIPS 180-4) implemented using powerpc SPE SIMD instruction set.

entry.name: CRYPTO_SHA1_MB
entry.label: SHA1 digest algorithm (x86_64 Multi-Buffer, Experimental)
entry.help: SHA-1 secure hash standard (FIPS 180-1/DFIPS 180-2) implemented using multi-buffer technique. This algorithm computes on multiple data lanes concurrently with SIMD instructions for better throughput. It should not be enabled by default but used when there is significant amount of work to keep the keep the data lanes filled to get performance benefit. If the data lanes remain unfilled, a flush operation will be initiated to process the crypto jobs, adding a slight latency.

entry.name: CRYPTO_SHA256_MB
entry.label: SHA256 digest algorithm (x86_64 Multi-Buffer, Experimental)
entry.help: SHA-256 secure hash standard (FIPS 180-1/DFIPS 180-2) implemented using multi-buffer technique. This algorithm computes on multiple data lanes concurrently with SIMD instructions for better throughput. It should not be enabled by default but used when there is significant amount of work to keep the keep the data lanes filled to get performance benefit. If the data lanes remain unfilled, a flush operation will be initiated to process the crypto jobs, adding a slight latency.

entry.name: CRYPTO_SHA512_MB
entry.label: SHA512 digest algorithm (x86_64 Multi-Buffer, Experimental)
entry.help: SHA-512 secure hash standard (FIPS 180-1/DFIPS 180-2) implemented using multi-buffer technique. This algorithm computes on multiple data lanes concurrently with SIMD instructions for better throughput. It should not be enabled by default but used when there is significant amount of work to keep the keep the data lanes filled to get performance benefit. If the data lanes remain unfilled, a flush operation will be initiated to process the crypto jobs, adding a slight latency.

entry.name: CRYPTO_SHA256
entry.label: SHA224 and SHA256 digest algorithm
entry.help:
SHA256 secure hash standard (DFIPS 180-2).
This version of SHA implements a 256 bit hash with 128 bits of security against collision attacks.
This code also includes SHA-224, a 224 bit hash with 112 bits of security against collision attacks.

entry.name: CRYPTO_SHA256_PPC_SPE
entry.label: SHA224 and SHA256 digest algorithm (PPC SPE)
entry.help: SHA224 and SHA256 secure hash standard (DFIPS 180-2) implemented using powerpc SPE SIMD instruction set.

entry.name: CRYPTO_SHA256_OCTEON
entry.label: SHA224 and SHA256 digest algorithm (OCTEON)
entry.help: SHA-256 secure hash standard (DFIPS 180-2) implemented using OCTEON crypto instructions, when available.

entry.name: CRYPTO_SHA256_SPARC64
entry.label: SHA224 and SHA256 digest algorithm (SPARC64)
entry.help: SHA-256 secure hash standard (DFIPS 180-2) implemented using sparc64 crypto instructions, when available.

entry.name: CRYPTO_SHA512
entry.label: SHA384 and SHA512 digest algorithms
entry.help:
SHA512 secure hash standard (DFIPS 180-2).
This version of SHA implements a 512 bit hash with 256 bits of security against collision attacks.
This code also includes SHA-384, a 384 bit hash with 192 bits of security against collision attacks.

entry.name: CRYPTO_SHA512_OCTEON
entry.label: SHA384 and SHA512 digest algorithms (OCTEON)
entry.help: SHA-512 secure hash standard (DFIPS 180-2) implemented using OCTEON crypto instructions, when available.

entry.name: CRYPTO_SHA512_SPARC64
entry.label: SHA384 and SHA512 digest algorithm (SPARC64)
entry.help: SHA-512 secure hash standard (DFIPS 180-2) implemented using sparc64 crypto instructions, when available.

entry.name: CRYPTO_SHA3
entry.label: SHA3 digest algorithm
entry.help:
SHA-3 secure hash standard (DFIPS 202). It's based on cryptographic sponge function family called Keccak.
References: http://keccak.noekeon.org/

entry.name: CRYPTO_TGR192
entry.label: Tiger digest algorithms
entry.help:
Tiger hash algorithm 192, 160 and 128-bit hashes
Tiger is a hash function optimized for 64-bit processors while still having decent performance on 32-bit processors. Tiger was developed by Ross Anderson and Eli Biham.
See also: <http://www.cs.technion.ac.il/~biham/Reports/Tiger/>.

entry.name: CRYPTO_WP512
entry.label: Whirlpool digest algorithms
entry.help:
Whirlpool hash algorithm 512, 384 and 256-bit hashes
Whirlpool-512 is part of the NESSIE cryptographic primitives. Whirlpool will be part of the ISO/IEC 10118-3:2003(E) standard
See also: <http://www.larc.usp.br/~pbarreto/WhirlpoolPage.html>

entry.name: CRYPTO_GHASH_CLMUL_NI_INTEL
entry.label: GHASH digest algorithm (CLMUL-NI accelerated)
entry.help: GHASH is message digest algorithm for GCM (Galois/Counter Mode). The implementation is accelerated by CLMUL-NI of Intel.

entry.name: CRYPTO_AES
entry.label: AES cipher algorithms
entry.help:
AES cipher algorithms (FIPS-197). AES uses the Rijndael algorithm.
Rijndael appears to be consistently a very good performer in both hardware and software across a wide range of computing environments regardless of its use in feedback or non-feedback modes. Its key setup time is excellent, and its key agility is good. Rijndael's very low memory requirements make it very well suited for restricted-space environments, in which it also demonstrates excellent performance. Rijndael's operations are among the easiest to defend against power and timing attacks.
The AES specifies three key sizes: 128, 192 and 256 bits
See <http://csrc.nist.gov/CryptoToolkit/aes/> for more information.

entry.name: CRYPTO_AES_SPARC64
entry.label: AES cipher algorithms (SPARC64)
entry.help:
Use SPARC64 crypto opcodes for AES algorithm.
AES cipher algorithms (FIPS-197). AES uses the Rijndael algorithm.
Rijndael appears to be consistently a very good performer in both hardware and software across a wide range of computing environments regardless of its use in feedback or non-feedback modes. Its key setup time is excellent, and its key agility is good. Rijndael's very low memory requirements make it very well suited for restricted-space environments, in which it also demonstrates excellent performance. Rijndael's operations are among the easiest to defend against power and timing attacks.
The AES specifies three key sizes: 128, 192 and 256 bits
See <http://csrc.nist.gov/encryption/aes/> for more information.
In addition to AES cipher algorithm support, the acceleration for some popular block cipher mode is supported too, including ECB and CBC.

entry.name: CRYPTO_AES_PPC_SPE
entry.label: AES cipher algorithms (PPC SPE)
entry.help: AES cipher algorithms (FIPS-197). Additionally the acceleration for popular block cipher modes ECB, CBC, CTR and XTS is supported. This module should only be used for low power (router) devices without hardware AES acceleration (e.g. caam crypto). It reduces the size of the AES tables from 16KB to 8KB + 256 bytes and mitigates timining attacks. Nevertheless it might be not as secure as other architecture specific assembler implementations that work on 1KB tables or 256 bytes S-boxes.

entry.name: CRYPTO_ANUBIS
entry.label: Anubis cipher algorithm
entry.help:
Anubis cipher algorithm.
Anubis is a variable key length cipher which can use keys from 128 bits to 320 bits in length. It was evaluated as a entrant in the NESSIE competition.
See also: <https://www.cosic.esat.kuleuven.be/nessie/reports/> <http://www.larc.usp.br/~pbarreto/AnubisPage.html>

entry.name: CRYPTO_ARC4
entry.label: ARC4 cipher algorithm
entry.help:
ARC4 cipher algorithm.
ARC4 is a stream cipher using keys ranging from 8 bits to 2048 bits in length. This algorithm is required for driver-based WEP, but it should not be for other purposes because of the weakness of the algorithm.

entry.name: CRYPTO_BLOWFISH
entry.label: Blowfish cipher algorithm
entry.help:
Blowfish cipher algorithm, by Bruce Schneier.
This is a variable key length cipher which can use keys from 32 bits to 448 bits in length. It's fast, simple and specifically designed for use on "large microprocessors".
See also: <http://www.schneier.com/blowfish.html>

entry.name: CRYPTO_BLOWFISH_COMMON
entry.help:
Common parts of the Blowfish cipher algorithm shared by the generic c and the assembler implementations.
See also: <http://www.schneier.com/blowfish.html>

entry.name: CRYPTO_BLOWFISH_X86_64
entry.label: Blowfish cipher algorithm (x86_64)
entry.help:
Blowfish cipher algorithm (x86_64), by Bruce Schneier.
This is a variable key length cipher which can use keys from 32 bits to 448 bits in length. It's fast, simple and specifically designed for use on "large microprocessors".
See also: <http://www.schneier.com/blowfish.html>

entry.name: CRYPTO_CAMELLIA
entry.label: Camellia cipher algorithms
entry.help:
Camellia cipher algorithms module.
Camellia is a symmetric key block cipher developed jointly at NTT and Mitsubishi Electric Corporation.
The Camellia specifies three key sizes: 128, 192 and 256 bits.
See also: <https://info.isl.ntt.co.jp/crypt/eng/camellia/index_s.html>

Camellia cipher algorithm module (x86_64/AES-NI/AVX2).

entry.name: CRYPTO_CAST_COMMON
entry.help: Common parts of the CAST cipher algorithms shared by the generic c and the assembler implementations.

entry.name: CRYPTO_CAST5
entry.label: CAST5 (CAST-128) cipher algorithm
entry.help: The CAST5 encryption algorithm (synonymous with CAST-128) is described in RFC2144.

entry.name: CRYPTO_CAST5_AVX_X86_64
entry.label: CAST5 (CAST-128) cipher algorithm (x86_64/AVX)
entry.help:
The CAST5 encryption algorithm (synonymous with CAST-128) is described in RFC2144.
This module provides the Cast5 cipher algorithm that processes sixteen blocks parallel using the AVX instruction set.

entry.name: CRYPTO_CAST6
entry.label: CAST6 (CAST-256) cipher algorithm
entry.help: The CAST6 encryption algorithm (synonymous with CAST-256) is described in RFC2612.

entry.name: CRYPTO_CAST6_AVX_X86_64
entry.label: CAST6 (CAST-256) cipher algorithm (x86_64/AVX)
entry.help:
The CAST6 encryption algorithm (synonymous with CAST-256) is described in RFC2612.
This module provides the Cast6 cipher algorithm that processes eight blocks parallel using the AVX instruction set.

entry.name: CRYPTO_DES
entry.label: DES and Triple DES EDE cipher algorithms
entry.help: DES cipher algorithm (FIPS 46-2), and Triple DES EDE (FIPS 46-3).

entry.name: CRYPTO_DES_SPARC64
entry.label: DES and Triple DES EDE cipher algorithms (SPARC64)
entry.help: DES cipher algorithm (FIPS 46-2), and Triple DES EDE (FIPS 46-3), optimized using SPARC64 crypto opcodes.

entry.name: CRYPTO_DES3_EDE_X86_64
entry.label: Triple DES EDE cipher algorithm (x86-64)
entry.help:
Triple DES EDE (FIPS 46-3) algorithm.
This module provides implementation of the Triple DES EDE cipher algorithm that is optimized for x86-64 processors. Two versions of algorithm are provided; regular processing one input block and one that processes three blocks parallel.

entry.name: CRYPTO_FCRYPT
entry.label: FCrypt cipher algorithm
entry.help: FCrypt algorithm used by RxRPC.

entry.name: CRYPTO_KHAZAD
entry.label: Khazad cipher algorithm
entry.help:
Khazad cipher algorithm.
Khazad was a finalist in the initial NESSIE competition. It is an algorithm optimized for 64-bit processors with good performance on 32-bit processors. Khazad uses an 128 bit key size.
See also: <http://www.larc.usp.br/~pbarreto/KhazadPage.html>

entry.name: CRYPTO_SALSA20
entry.label: Salsa20 stream cipher algorithm
entry.help:
Salsa20 stream cipher algorithm.
Salsa20 is a stream cipher submitted to eSTREAM, the ECRYPT Stream Cipher Project. See <http://www.ecrypt.eu.org/stream/>
The Salsa20 stream cipher algorithm is designed by Daniel J. Bernstein <djb@cr.yp.to>. See <http://cr.yp.to/snuffle.html>

entry.name: CRYPTO_SALSA20_586
entry.label: Salsa20 stream cipher algorithm (i586)
entry.help:
Salsa20 stream cipher algorithm.
Salsa20 is a stream cipher submitted to eSTREAM, the ECRYPT Stream Cipher Project. See <http://www.ecrypt.eu.org/stream/>
The Salsa20 stream cipher algorithm is designed by Daniel J. Bernstein <djb@cr.yp.to>. See <http://cr.yp.to/snuffle.html>

entry.name: CRYPTO_SALSA20_X86_64
entry.label: Salsa20 stream cipher algorithm (x86_64)
entry.help:
Salsa20 stream cipher algorithm.
Salsa20 is a stream cipher submitted to eSTREAM, the ECRYPT Stream Cipher Project. See <http://www.ecrypt.eu.org/stream/>
The Salsa20 stream cipher algorithm is designed by Daniel J. Bernstein <djb@cr.yp.to>. See <http://cr.yp.to/snuffle.html>

entry.name: CRYPTO_CHACHA20
entry.label: ChaCha20 cipher algorithm
entry.help:
ChaCha20 cipher algorithm, RFC7539.
ChaCha20 is a 256-bit high-speed stream cipher designed by Daniel J. Bernstein and further specified in RFC7539 for use in IETF protocols. This is the portable C implementation of ChaCha20.
See also: <http://cr.yp.to/chacha/chacha-20080128.pdf>

entry.name: CRYPTO_CHACHA20_X86_64
entry.label: ChaCha20 cipher algorithm (x86_64/SSSE3/AVX2)
entry.help:
ChaCha20 cipher algorithm, RFC7539.
ChaCha20 is a 256-bit high-speed stream cipher designed by Daniel J. Bernstein and further specified in RFC7539 for use in IETF protocols. This is the x86_64 assembler implementation using SIMD instructions.
See also: <http://cr.yp.to/chacha/chacha-20080128.pdf>

entry.name: CRYPTO_SEED
entry.label: SEED cipher algorithm
entry.help:
SEED cipher algorithm (RFC4269).
SEED is a 128-bit symmetric key block cipher that has been developed by KISA (Korea Information Security Agency) as a national standard encryption algorithm of the Republic of Korea. It is a 16 round block cipher with the key size of 128 bit.
See also: <http://www.kisa.or.kr/kisa/seed/jsp/seed_eng.jsp>

entry.name: CRYPTO_SERPENT
entry.label: Serpent cipher algorithm
entry.help:
Serpent cipher algorithm, by Anderson, Biham & Knudsen.
Keys are allowed to be from 0 to 256 bits in length, in steps of 8 bits. Also includes the 'Tnepres' algorithm, a reversed variant of Serpent for compatibility with old kerneli.org code.
See also: <http://www.cl.cam.ac.uk/~rja14/serpent.html>

entry.name: CRYPTO_SERPENT_SSE2_X86_64
entry.label: Serpent cipher algorithm (x86_64/SSE2)
entry.help:
Serpent cipher algorithm, by Anderson, Biham & Knudsen.
Keys are allowed to be from 0 to 256 bits in length, in steps of 8 bits.
This module provides Serpent cipher algorithm that processes eight blocks parallel using SSE2 instruction set.
See also: <http://www.cl.cam.ac.uk/~rja14/serpent.html>

entry.name: CRYPTO_SERPENT_SSE2_586
entry.label: Serpent cipher algorithm (i586/SSE2)
entry.help:
Serpent cipher algorithm, by Anderson, Biham & Knudsen.
Keys are allowed to be from 0 to 256 bits in length, in steps of 8 bits.
This module provides Serpent cipher algorithm that processes four blocks parallel using SSE2 instruction set.
See also: <http://www.cl.cam.ac.uk/~rja14/serpent.html>

entry.name: CRYPTO_SERPENT_AVX_X86_64
entry.label: Serpent cipher algorithm (x86_64/AVX)
entry.help:
Serpent cipher algorithm, by Anderson, Biham & Knudsen.
Keys are allowed to be from 0 to 256 bits in length, in steps of 8 bits.
This module provides the Serpent cipher algorithm that processes eight blocks parallel using the AVX instruction set.
See also: <http://www.cl.cam.ac.uk/~rja14/serpent.html>

entry.name: CRYPTO_SERPENT_AVX2_X86_64
entry.label: Serpent cipher algorithm (x86_64/AVX2)
entry.help:
Serpent cipher algorithm, by Anderson, Biham & Knudsen.
Keys are allowed to be from 0 to 256 bits in length, in steps of 8 bits.
This module provides Serpent cipher algorithm that processes 16 blocks parallel using AVX2 instruction set.
See also: <http://www.cl.cam.ac.uk/~rja14/serpent.html>

entry.name: CRYPTO_TEA
entry.label: TEA, XTEA and XETA cipher algorithms
entry.help:
TEA cipher algorithm.
Tiny Encryption Algorithm is a simple cipher that uses many rounds for security. It is very fast and uses little memory.
Xtendend Tiny Encryption Algorithm is a modification to the TEA algorithm to address a potential key weakness in the TEA algorithm.
Xtendend Encryption Tiny Algorithm is a mis-implementation of the XTEA algorithm for compatibility purposes.

entry.name: CRYPTO_TWOFISH
entry.label: Twofish cipher algorithm
entry.help:
Twofish cipher algorithm.
Twofish was submitted as an AES (Advanced Encryption Standard) candidate cipher by researchers at CounterPane Systems. It is a 16 round block cipher supporting key sizes of 128, 192, and 256 bits.
See also: <http://www.schneier.com/twofish.html>

entry.name: CRYPTO_TWOFISH_COMMON
entry.help: Common parts of the Twofish cipher algorithm shared by the generic c and the assembler implementations.

entry.name: CRYPTO_TWOFISH_586
entry.label: Twofish cipher algorithms (i586)
entry.help:
Twofish cipher algorithm.
Twofish was submitted as an AES (Advanced Encryption Standard) candidate cipher by researchers at CounterPane Systems. It is a 16 round block cipher supporting key sizes of 128, 192, and 256 bits.
See also: <http://www.schneier.com/twofish.html>

entry.name: CRYPTO_TWOFISH_X86_64
entry.label: Twofish cipher algorithm (x86_64)
entry.help:
Twofish cipher algorithm (x86_64).
Twofish was submitted as an AES (Advanced Encryption Standard) candidate cipher by researchers at CounterPane Systems. It is a 16 round block cipher supporting key sizes of 128, 192, and 256 bits.
See also: <http://www.schneier.com/twofish.html>

entry.name: CRYPTO_TWOFISH_X86_64_3WAY
entry.label: Twofish cipher algorithm (x86_64, 3-way parallel)
entry.help:
Twofish cipher algorithm (x86_64, 3-way parallel).
Twofish was submitted as an AES (Advanced Encryption Standard) candidate cipher by researchers at CounterPane Systems. It is a 16 round block cipher supporting key sizes of 128, 192, and 256 bits.
This module provides Twofish cipher algorithm that processes three blocks parallel, utilizing resources of out-of-order CPUs better.
See also: <http://www.schneier.com/twofish.html>

entry.name: CRYPTO_TWOFISH_AVX_X86_64
entry.label: Twofish cipher algorithm (x86_64/AVX)
entry.help:
Twofish cipher algorithm (x86_64/AVX).
Twofish was submitted as an AES (Advanced Encryption Standard) candidate cipher by researchers at CounterPane Systems. It is a 16 round block cipher supporting key sizes of 128, 192, and 256 bits.
This module provides the Twofish cipher algorithm that processes eight blocks parallel using the AVX Instruction Set.
See also: <http://www.schneier.com/twofish.html>

entry.name: CRYPTO_DEFLATE
entry.label: Deflate compression algorithm
entry.help:
This is the Deflate algorithm (RFC1951), specified for use in IPSec with the IPCOMP protocol (RFC3173, RFC2394).
You will most probably want this if using IPSec.

entry.name: CRYPTO_LZO
entry.label: LZO compression algorithm
entry.help: This is the LZO algorithm.

entry.name: CRYPTO_842
entry.label: 842 compression algorithm
entry.help: This is the 842 algorithm.

entry.name: CRYPTO_LZ4
entry.label: LZ4 compression algorithm
entry.help: This is the LZ4 algorithm.

entry.name: CRYPTO_LZ4HC
entry.label: LZ4HC compression algorithm
entry.help: This is the LZ4 high compression mode algorithm.

entry.name: CRYPTO_ANSI_CPRNG
entry.label: Pseudo Random Number Generation for Cryptographic modules
entry.help: This option enables the generic pseudo random number generator for cryptographic modules. Uses the Algorithm specified in ANSI X9.31 A.2.4. Note that this option must be enabled if CRYPTO_FIPS is selected

entry.name: CRYPTO_DRBG_MENU
entry.label: NIST SP800-90A DRBG
entry.help: NIST SP800-90A compliant DRBG. In the following submenu, one or more of the DRBG types must be selected.

entry.name: CRYPTO_DRBG_HASH
entry.label: Enable Hash DRBG
entry.help: Enable the Hash DRBG variant as defined in NIST SP800-90A.

entry.name: CRYPTO_DRBG_CTR
entry.label: Enable CTR DRBG
entry.help: Enable the CTR DRBG variant as defined in NIST SP800-90A.

entry.name: CRYPTO_JITTERENTROPY
entry.label: Jitterentropy Non-Deterministic Random Number Generator
entry.help: The Jitterentropy RNG is a noise that is intended to provide seed to another RNG. The RNG does not perform any cryptographic whitening of the generated random numbers. This Jitterentropy RNG registers with the kernel crypto API and can be used by any caller.

entry.name: CRYPTO_USER_API_HASH
entry.label: User-space interface for hash algorithms
entry.help: This option enables the user-spaces interface for hash algorithms.

entry.name: CRYPTO_USER_API_SKCIPHER
entry.label: User-space interface for symmetric key cipher algorithms
entry.help: This option enables the user-spaces interface for symmetric key cipher algorithms.

entry.name: CRYPTO_USER_API_RNG
entry.label: User-space interface for random number generator algorithms
entry.help: This option enables the user-spaces interface for random number generator algorithms.

entry.name: CRYPTO_USER_API_AEAD
entry.label: User-space interface for AEAD cipher algorithms
entry.help: This option enables the user-spaces interface for AEAD cipher algorithms.

entry.name: CRYPTO_HW
entry.label: Hardware crypto devices
entry.help:
Say Y here to get to see options for hardware crypto devices and processors. This option alone does not add any kernel code.
If you say N, all options in this submenu will be skipped and disabled.

entry.name: CRYPTO_DEV_PADLOCK
entry.label: Support for VIA PadLock ACE
entry.help:
Some VIA processors come with an integrated crypto engine (so called VIA PadLock ACE, Advanced Cryptography Engine) that provides instructions for very fast cryptographic operations with supported algorithms.
The instructions are used only when the CPU supports them. Otherwise software encryption is used.

entry.name: CRYPTO_DEV_PADLOCK_AES
entry.label: PadLock driver for AES algorithm
entry.help:
Use VIA PadLock for AES algorithm.
Available in VIA C3 and newer CPUs.
If unsure say M. The compiled module will be called padlock-aes.

entry.name: CRYPTO_DEV_PADLOCK_SHA
entry.label: PadLock driver for SHA1 and SHA256 algorithms
entry.help:
Use VIA PadLock for SHA1/SHA256 algorithms.
Available in VIA C7 and newer processors.
If unsure say M. The compiled module will be called padlock-sha.

entry.name: CRYPTO_DEV_GEODE
entry.label: Support for the Geode LX AES engine
entry.help:
Say 'Y' here to use the AMD Geode LX processor on-board AES engine for the CryptoAPI AES algorithm.
To compile this driver as a module, choose M here: the module will be called geode-aes.

entry.name: ZCRYPT
entry.label: Support for PCI-attached cryptographic adapters
entry.help: Select this option if you want to use a PCI-attached cryptographic adapter like: + PCI Cryptographic Accelerator (PCICA) + PCI Cryptographic Coprocessor (PCICC) + PCI-X Cryptographic Coprocessor (PCIXCC) + Crypto Express2 Coprocessor (CEX2C) + Crypto Express2 Accelerator (CEX2A) + Crypto Express3 Coprocessor (CEX3C) + Crypto Express3 Accelerator (CEX3A)

entry.name: CRYPTO_SHA1_S390
entry.label: SHA1 digest algorithm
entry.help:
This is the s390 hardware accelerated implementation of the SHA-1 secure hash standard (FIPS 180-1/DFIPS 180-2).
It is available as of z990.

entry.name: CRYPTO_SHA256_S390
entry.label: SHA256 digest algorithm
entry.help:
This is the s390 hardware accelerated implementation of the SHA256 secure hash standard (DFIPS 180-2).
It is available as of z9.

entry.name: CRYPTO_SHA512_S390
entry.label: SHA384 and SHA512 digest algorithm
entry.help:
This is the s390 hardware accelerated implementation of the SHA512 secure hash standard.
It is available as of z10.

entry.name: CRYPTO_DES_S390
entry.label: DES and Triple DES cipher algorithms
entry.help:
This is the s390 hardware accelerated implementation of the DES cipher algorithm (FIPS 46-2), and Triple DES EDE (FIPS 46-3).
As of z990 the ECB and CBC mode are hardware accelerated. As of z196 the CTR mode is hardware accelerated.

entry.name: CRYPTO_AES_S390
entry.label: AES cipher algorithms
entry.help:
This is the s390 hardware accelerated implementation of the AES cipher algorithms (FIPS-197).
As of z9 the ECB and CBC modes are hardware accelerated for 128 bit keys. As of z10 the ECB and CBC modes are hardware accelerated for all AES key sizes. As of z196 the CTR mode is hardware accelerated for all AES key sizes and XTS mode is hardware accelerated for 256 and 512 bit keys.

entry.name: S390_PRNG
entry.label: Pseudo random number generator device driver
entry.help:
Select this option if you want to use the s390 pseudo random number generator. The PRNG is part of the cryptographic processor functions and uses triple-DES to generate secure random numbers like the ANSI X9.17 standard. User-space programs access the pseudo-random-number device through the char device /dev/prandom.
It is available as of z9.

entry.name: CRYPTO_GHASH_S390
entry.label: GHASH digest algorithm
entry.help:
This is the s390 hardware accelerated implementation of the GHASH message digest algorithm for GCM (Galois/Counter Mode).
It is available as of z196.

entry.name: CRYPTO_CRC32_S390
entry.label: CRC-32 algorithms
entry.help:
Select this option if you want to use hardware accelerated implementations of CRC algorithms. With this option, you can optimize the computation of CRC-32 (IEEE 802.3 Ethernet) and CRC-32C (Castagnoli).
It is available with IBM z13 or later.

entry.name: CRYPTO_DEV_MV_CESA
entry.label: Marvell's Cryptographic Engine
entry.help:
This driver allows you to utilize the Cryptographic Engines and Security Accelerator (CESA) which can be found on the Marvell Orion and Kirkwood SoCs, such as QNAP's TS-209.
Currently the driver supports AES in ECB and CBC mode without DMA.

entry.name: CRYPTO_DEV_MARVELL_CESA
entry.label: New Marvell's Cryptographic Engine driver
entry.help:
This driver allows you to utilize the Cryptographic Engines and Security Accelerator (CESA) which can be found on the Armada 370. This driver supports CPU offload through DMA transfers.
This driver is aimed at replacing the mv_cesa driver. This will only happen once it has received proper testing.

entry.name: CRYPTO_DEV_NIAGARA2
entry.label: Niagara2 Stream Processing Unit driver
entry.help: Each core of a Niagara2 processor contains a Stream Processing Unit, which itself contains several cryptographic sub-units. One set provides the Modular Arithmetic Unit, used for SSL offload. The other set provides the Cipher Group, which can perform encryption, decryption, hashing, checksumming, and raw copies.

entry.name: CRYPTO_DEV_HIFN_795X
entry.label: Driver HIFN 795x crypto accelerator chips
entry.help: This option allows you to have support for HIFN 795x crypto adapters.

entry.name: CRYPTO_DEV_HIFN_795X_RNG
entry.label: HIFN 795x random number generator
entry.help: Select this option if you want to enable the random number generator on the HIFN 795x crypto adapters.

entry.name: CRYPTO_DEV_FSL_CAAM
entry.label: Freescale CAAM-Multicore driver backend
entry.help:
Enables the driver module for Freescale's Cryptographic Accelerator and Assurance Module (CAAM), also known as the SEC version 4 (SEC4). This module creates job ring devices, and configures h/w to operate as a DPAA component automatically, depending on h/w feature availability.
To compile this driver as a module, choose M here: the module will be called caam.

entry.name: CRYPTO_DEV_FSL_CAAM_JR
entry.label: Freescale CAAM Job Ring driver backend
entry.help:
Enables the driver module for Job Rings which are part of Freescale's Cryptographic Accelerator and Assurance Module (CAAM). This module adds a job ring operation interface.
To compile this driver as a module, choose M here: the module will be called caam_jr.

entry.name: CRYPTO_DEV_FSL_CAAM_RINGSIZE
entry.label: Job Ring size
entry.help: Select size of Job Rings as a power of 2, within the range 2-9 (ring size 4-512). Examples: 2 => 4 3 => 8 4 => 16 5 => 32 6 => 64 7 => 128 8 => 256 9 => 512

entry.name: CRYPTO_DEV_FSL_CAAM_INTC
entry.label: Job Ring interrupt coalescing
entry.help:
Enable the Job Ring's interrupt coalescing feature.
Note: the driver already provides adequate interrupt coalescing in software.

entry.name: CRYPTO_DEV_FSL_CAAM_INTC_COUNT_THLD
entry.label: Job Ring interrupt coalescing count threshold
entry.help: Select number of descriptor completions to queue before raising an interrupt, in the range 1-255. Note that a selection of 1 functionally defeats the coalescing feature, and a selection equal or greater than the job ring size will force timeouts.

entry.name: CRYPTO_DEV_FSL_CAAM_INTC_TIME_THLD
entry.label: Job Ring interrupt coalescing timer threshold
entry.help: Select number of bus clocks/64 to timeout in the case that one or more descriptor completions are queued without reaching the count threshold. Range is 1-65535.

entry.name: CRYPTO_DEV_FSL_CAAM_CRYPTO_API
entry.label: Register algorithm implementations with the Crypto API
entry.help:
Selecting this will offload crypto for users of the scatterlist crypto API (such as the linux native IPSec stack) to the SEC4 via job ring.
To compile this as a module, choose M here: the module will be called caamalg.

entry.name: CRYPTO_DEV_FSL_CAAM_AHASH_API
entry.label: Register hash algorithm implementations with Crypto API
entry.help:
Selecting this will offload ahash for users of the scatterlist crypto API to the SEC4 via job ring.
To compile this as a module, choose M here: the module will be called caamhash.

entry.name: CRYPTO_DEV_FSL_CAAM_PKC_API
entry.label: Register public key cryptography implementations with Crypto API
entry.help: Selecting this will allow SEC Public key support for RSA. Supported cryptographic primitives: encryption, decryption, signature and verification. To compile this as a module, choose M here: the module will be called caam_pkc.

entry.name: CRYPTO_DEV_FSL_CAAM_RNG_API
entry.label: Register caam device for hwrng API
entry.help:
Selecting this will register the SEC4 hardware rng to the hw_random API for suppying the kernel entropy pool.
To compile this as a module, choose M here: the module will be called caamrng.

entry.name: CRYPTO_DEV_FSL_CAAM_DEBUG
entry.label: Enable debug output in CAAM driver
entry.help: Selecting this will enable printing of various debug information in the CAAM driver.

entry.name: CRYPTO_DEV_TALITOS
entry.label: Talitos Freescale Security Engine (SEC)
entry.help:
Say 'Y' here to use the Freescale Security Engine (SEC) to offload cryptographic algorithm computation.
The Freescale SEC is present on PowerQUICC 'E' processors, such as the MPC8349E and MPC8548E.
To compile this driver as a module, choose M here: the module will be called talitos.

entry.name: CRYPTO_DEV_TALITOS1
entry.label: SEC1 (SEC 1.0 and SEC Lite 1.2)
entry.help: Say 'Y' here to use the Freescale Security Engine (SEC) version 1.0 found on MPC82xx or the Freescale Security Engine (SEC Lite) version 1.2 found on MPC8xx

entry.name: CRYPTO_DEV_TALITOS2
entry.label: SEC2+ (SEC version 2.0 or upper)
entry.help: Say 'Y' here to use the Freescale Security Engine (SEC) version 2 and following as found on MPC83xx, MPC85xx, etc ...

entry.name: CRYPTO_DEV_IXP4XX
entry.label: Driver for IXP4xx crypto hardware acceleration
entry.help: Driver for the IXP4xx NPE crypto engine.

entry.name: CRYPTO_DEV_PPC4XX
entry.label: Driver AMCC PPC4xx crypto accelerator
entry.help: This option allows you to have support for AMCC crypto acceleration.

entry.name: HW_RANDOM_PPC4XX
entry.label: PowerPC 4xx generic true random number generator support
entry.help: This option provides the kernel-side support for the TRNG hardware found in the security function of some PowerPC 4xx SoCs.

entry.name: CRYPTO_DEV_OMAP_SHAM
entry.label: Support for OMAP MD5/SHA1/SHA2 hw accelerator
entry.help: OMAP processors have MD5/SHA1/SHA2 hw accelerator. Select this if you want to use the OMAP module for MD5/SHA1/SHA2 algorithms.

entry.name: CRYPTO_DEV_OMAP_AES
entry.label: Support for OMAP AES hw engine
entry.help: OMAP processors have AES module accelerator. Select this if you want to use the OMAP module for AES algorithms.

entry.name: CRYPTO_DEV_OMAP_DES
entry.label: Support for OMAP DES/3DES hw engine
entry.help: OMAP processors have DES/3DES module accelerator. Select this if you want to use the OMAP module for DES and 3DES algorithms. Currently the ECB and CBC modes of operation are supported by the driver. Also accesses made on unaligned boundaries are supported.

entry.name: CRYPTO_DEV_PICOXCELL
entry.label: Support for picoXcell IPSEC and Layer2 crypto engines
entry.help:
This option enables support for the hardware offload engines in the Picochip picoXcell SoC devices. Select this for IPSEC ESP offload and for 3gpp Layer 2 ciphering support.
Saying m here will build a module named pipcoxcell_crypto.

entry.name: CRYPTO_DEV_SAHARA
entry.label: Support for SAHARA crypto accelerator
entry.help: This option enables support for the SAHARA HW crypto accelerator found in some Freescale i.MX chips.

entry.name: CRYPTO_DEV_MXC_SCC
entry.label: Support for Freescale Security Controller (SCC)
entry.help: This option enables support for the Security Controller (SCC) found in Freescale i.MX25 chips.

entry.name: CRYPTO_DEV_S5P
entry.label: Support for Samsung S5PV210/Exynos crypto accelerator
entry.help: This option allows you to have support for S5P crypto acceleration. Select this to offload Samsung S5PV210 or S5PC110, Exynos from AES algorithms execution.

entry.name: CRYPTO_DEV_NX
entry.label: Support for IBM PowerPC Nest (NX) cryptographic acceleration
entry.help: This enables support for the NX hardware cryptographic accelerator coprocessor that is in IBM PowerPC P7+ or later processors. This does not actually enable any drivers, it only allows you to select which acceleration type (encryption and/or compression) to enable.

entry.name: CRYPTO_DEV_NX_ENCRYPT
entry.label: Encryption acceleration support on pSeries platform
entry.help: Support for PowerPC Nest (NX) encryption acceleration. This module supports acceleration for AES and SHA2 algorithms on the pSeries platform. If you choose 'M' here, this module will be called nx_crypto.

entry.name: CRYPTO_DEV_NX_COMPRESS
entry.label: Compression acceleration support
entry.help: Support for PowerPC Nest (NX) compression acceleration. This module supports acceleration for compressing memory with the 842 algorithm using the cryptographic API. One of the platform drivers must be selected also. If you choose 'M' here, this module will be called nx_compress.

entry.name: CRYPTO_DEV_NX_COMPRESS_PSERIES
entry.label: Compression acceleration support on pSeries platform
entry.help: Support for PowerPC Nest (NX) compression acceleration. This module supports acceleration for compressing memory with the 842 algorithm. This supports NX hardware on the pSeries platform. If you choose 'M' here, this module will be called nx_compress_pseries.

entry.name: CRYPTO_DEV_NX_COMPRESS_POWERNV
entry.label: Compression acceleration support on PowerNV platform
entry.help: Support for PowerPC Nest (NX) compression acceleration. This module supports acceleration for compressing memory with the 842 algorithm. This supports NX hardware on the PowerNV platform. If you choose 'M' here, this module will be called nx_compress_powernv.

entry.name: CRYPTO_DEV_UX500
entry.label: Driver for ST-Ericsson UX500 crypto hardware acceleration
entry.help: Driver for ST-Ericsson UX500 crypto engine.

entry.name: CRYPTO_DEV_UX500_CRYP
entry.label: UX500 crypto driver for CRYP block
entry.help: This selects the crypto driver for the UX500_CRYP hardware. It supports AES-ECB, CBC and CTR with keys sizes of 128, 192 and 256 bit sizes.

entry.name: CRYPTO_DEV_UX500_HASH
entry.label: UX500 crypto driver for HASH block
entry.help: This selects the hash driver for the UX500_HASH hardware. Depends on UX500/STM DMA if running in DMA mode.

entry.name: CRYPTO_DEV_UX500_DEBUG
entry.label: Activate ux500 platform debug-mode for crypto and hash block
entry.help: Say Y if you want to add debug prints to ux500_hash and ux500_cryp devices.

entry.name: CRYPTO_DEV_BFIN_CRC
entry.label: Support for Blackfin CRC hardware
entry.help: Newer Blackfin processors have CRC hardware. Select this if you want to use the Blackfin CRC module.

entry.name: CRYPTO_DEV_ATMEL_AES
entry.label: Support for Atmel AES hw accelerator
entry.help:
Some Atmel processors have AES hw accelerator. Select this if you want to use the Atmel module for AES algorithms.
To compile this driver as a module, choose M here: the module will be called atmel-aes.

entry.name: CRYPTO_DEV_ATMEL_TDES
entry.label: Support for Atmel DES/TDES hw accelerator
entry.help:
Some Atmel processors have DES/TDES hw accelerator. Select this if you want to use the Atmel module for DES/TDES algorithms.
To compile this driver as a module, choose M here: the module will be called atmel-tdes.

entry.name: CRYPTO_DEV_ATMEL_SHA
entry.label: Support for Atmel SHA hw accelerator
entry.help:
Some Atmel processors have SHA1/SHA224/SHA256/SHA384/SHA512 hw accelerator. Select this if you want to use the Atmel module for SHA1/SHA224/SHA256/SHA384/SHA512 algorithms.
To compile this driver as a module, choose M here: the module will be called atmel-sha.

entry.name: CRYPTO_DEV_CCP
entry.label: Support for AMD Cryptographic Coprocessor
entry.help: The AMD Cryptographic Coprocessor provides hardware offload support for encryption, hashing and related operations.

entry.name: CRYPTO_DEV_CCP_DD
entry.label: Cryptographic Coprocessor device driver
entry.help: Provides the interface to use the AMD Cryptographic Coprocessor which can be used to offload encryption operations such as SHA, AES and more. If you choose 'M' here, this module will be called ccp.

entry.name: CRYPTO_DEV_CCP_CRYPTO
entry.label: Encryption and hashing offload support
entry.help: Support for using the cryptographic API with the AMD Cryptographic Coprocessor. This module supports offload of SHA and AES algorithms. If you choose 'M' here, this module will be called ccp_crypto.

entry.name: CRYPTO_DEV_MXS_DCP
entry.label: Support for Freescale MXS DCP
entry.help:
The Freescale i.MX23/i.MX28 has SHA1/SHA256 and AES128 CBC/ECB co-processor on the die.
To compile this driver as a module, choose M here: the module will be called mxs-dcp.

entry.name: CRYPTO_DEV_QAT_DH895xCC
entry.label: Support for Intel(R) DH895xCC
entry.help:
Support for Intel(R) DH895xcc with Intel(R) QuickAssist Technology for accelerating crypto and compression workloads.
To compile this as a module, choose M here: the module will be called qat_dh895xcc.

entry.name: CRYPTO_DEV_QAT_C3XXX
entry.label: Support for Intel(R) C3XXX
entry.help:
Support for Intel(R) C3xxx with Intel(R) QuickAssist Technology for accelerating crypto and compression workloads.
To compile this as a module, choose M here: the module will be called qat_c3xxx.

entry.name: CRYPTO_DEV_QAT_C62X
entry.label: Support for Intel(R) C62X
entry.help:
Support for Intel(R) C62x with Intel(R) QuickAssist Technology for accelerating crypto and compression workloads.
To compile this as a module, choose M here: the module will be called qat_c62x.

entry.name: CRYPTO_DEV_QAT_DH895xCCVF
entry.label: Support for Intel(R) DH895xCC Virtual Function
entry.help:
Support for Intel(R) DH895xcc with Intel(R) QuickAssist Technology Virtual Function for accelerating crypto and compression workloads.
To compile this as a module, choose M here: the module will be called qat_dh895xccvf.

entry.name: CRYPTO_DEV_QAT_C3XXXVF
entry.label: Support for Intel(R) C3XXX Virtual Function
entry.help:
Support for Intel(R) C3xxx with Intel(R) QuickAssist Technology Virtual Function for accelerating crypto and compression workloads.
To compile this as a module, choose M here: the module will be called qat_c3xxxvf.

entry.name: CRYPTO_DEV_QAT_C62XVF
entry.label: Support for Intel(R) C62X Virtual Function
entry.help:
Support for Intel(R) C62x with Intel(R) QuickAssist Technology Virtual Function for accelerating crypto and compression workloads.
To compile this as a module, choose M here: the module will be called qat_c62xvf.

entry.name: CRYPTO_DEV_QCE
entry.label: Qualcomm crypto engine accelerator
entry.help: This driver supports Qualcomm crypto engine accelerator hardware. To compile this driver as a module, choose M here. The module will be called qcrypto.

entry.name: CRYPTO_DEV_VMX
entry.label: Support for VMX cryptographic acceleration instructions
entry.help: Support for VMX cryptographic acceleration instructions.

entry.name: CRYPTO_DEV_VMX_ENCRYPT
entry.label: Encryption acceleration support on P8 CPU
entry.help: Support for VMX cryptographic acceleration instructions on Power8 CPU. This module supports acceleration for AES and GHASH in hardware. If you choose 'M' here, this module will be called vmx-crypto.

entry.name: CRYPTO_DEV_IMGTEC_HASH
entry.label: Imagination Technologies hardware hash accelerator
entry.help: This driver interfaces with the Imagination Technologies hardware hash accelerator. Supporting MD5/SHA1/SHA224/SHA256 hashing algorithms.

entry.name: CRYPTO_DEV_SUN4I_SS
entry.label: Support for Allwinner Security System cryptographic accelerator
entry.help:
Some Allwinner SoC have a crypto accelerator named Security System. Select this if you want to use it. The Security System handle AES/DES/3DES ciphers in CBC mode and SHA1 and MD5 hash algorithms.
To compile this driver as a module, choose M here: the module will be called sun4i-ss.

entry.name: CRYPTO_DEV_ROCKCHIP
entry.label: Rockchip's Cryptographic Engine driver
entry.help: This driver interfaces with the hardware crypto accelerator. Supporting cbc/ecb chainmode, and aes/des/des3_ede cipher mode.

entry.name: ASYMMETRIC_KEY_TYPE
entry.label: Asymmetric (public-key cryptographic) key type
entry.help: This option provides support for a key type that holds the data for the asymmetric keys used for public key cryptographic operations such as encryption, decryption, signature generation and signature verification.

entry.name: ASYMMETRIC_PUBLIC_KEY_SUBTYPE
entry.label: Asymmetric public-key crypto algorithm subtype
entry.help: This option provides support for asymmetric public key type handling. If signature generation and/or verification are to be used, appropriate hash algorithms (such as SHA-1) must be available. ENOPKG will be reported if the requisite algorithm is unavailable.

entry.name: X509_CERTIFICATE_PARSER
entry.label: X.509 certificate parser
entry.help: This option provides support for parsing X.509 format blobs for key data and provides the ability to instantiate a crypto key from a public key packet found inside the certificate.

entry.name: PKCS7_MESSAGE_PARSER
entry.label: PKCS
entry.help: This option provides support for parsing PKCS#7 format messages for signature data and provides the ability to verify the signature.

entry.name: PKCS7_TEST_KEY
entry.label: PKCS
entry.help:
This option provides a type of key that can be loaded up from a PKCS#7 message - provided the message is signed by a trusted key. If it is, the PKCS#7 wrapper is discarded and reading the key returns just the payload. If it isn't, adding the key will fail with an error.
This is intended for testing the PKCS#7 parser.

entry.name: SIGNED_PE_FILE_VERIFICATION
entry.label: Support for PE file signature verification
entry.help: This option provides support for verifying the signature(s) on a signed PE binary.

entry.name: EFI_SIGNATURE_LIST_PARSER
entry.label: EFI signature list parser
entry.help: This option provides support for parsing EFI signature lists for X.509 certificates and turning them into keys.

entry.name: MODULE_SIG_KEY
entry.label: File name or PKCS
entry.help:
Provide the file name of a private key/certificate in PEM format, or a PKCS#11 URI according to RFC7512. The file should contain, or the URI should identify, both the certificate and its corresponding private key.
If this option is unchanged from its default "certs/signing_key.pem", then the kernel will automatically generate the private key and certificate as described in Documentation/module-signing.txt

entry.name: SYSTEM_TRUSTED_KEYRING
entry.label: Provide system-wide ring of trusted keys
entry.help:
Provide a system keyring to which trusted keys can be added. Keys in the keyring are considered to be trusted. Keys may be added at will by the kernel from compiled-in data and from hardware key stores, but userspace may only add extra keys if those keys can be verified by keys already in the keyring.
Keys in this keyring are used by module signature checking.

entry.name: SYSTEM_TRUSTED_KEYS
entry.label: Additional X.509 keys for default system keyring
entry.help:
If set, this option should be the filename of a PEM-formatted file containing trusted X.509 certificates to be included in the default system keyring. Any certificate used for module signing is implicitly also trusted.
NOTE: If you previously provided keys for the system keyring in the form of DER-encoded *.x509 files in the top-level build directory, those are no longer used. You will need to set this option instead.

entry.name: SYSTEM_EXTRA_CERTIFICATE
entry.label: Reserve area for inserting a certificate without recompiling
entry.help: If set, space for an extra certificate will be reserved in the kernel image. This allows introducing a trusted certificate to the default system keyring without recompiling the kernel.

entry.name: SYSTEM_EXTRA_CERTIFICATE_SIZE
entry.label: Number of bytes to reserve for the extra certificate
entry.help: This is the number of bytes reserved in the kernel image for a certificate to be inserted.

entry.name: SECONDARY_TRUSTED_KEYRING
entry.label: Provide a keyring to which extra trustable keys may be added
entry.help: If set, provide a keyring to which extra keys may be added, provided those keys are not blacklisted and are vouched for by a key built into the kernel or already in the secondary trusted keyring.

entry.name: VIRTUALIZATION
entry.label: Virtualization
entry.help:
Say Y here to get to see options for using your Linux host to run other operating systems inside virtual machines (guests). This option alone does not add any kernel code.
If you say N, all options in this submenu will be skipped and disabled.

entry.name: KVM
entry.label: Kernel-based Virtual Machine (KVM) support
entry.help:
Support hosting fully virtualized guest machines using hardware virtualization extensions. You will need a fairly recent processor equipped with virtualization extensions. You will also need to select one or more of the processor modules below.
This module provides access to the hardware capabilities through a character device node named /dev/kvm.
To compile this as a module, choose M here: the module will be called kvm.
If unsure, say N.

entry.name: KVM_INTEL
entry.label: KVM for Intel processors support
entry.help:
Provides support for KVM on Intel processors equipped with the VT extensions.
To compile this as a module, choose M here: the module will be called kvm-intel.

entry.name: KVM_AMD
entry.label: KVM for AMD processors support
entry.help:
Provides support for KVM on AMD processors equipped with the AMD-V (SVM) extensions.
To compile this as a module, choose M here: the module will be called kvm-amd.

entry.name: KVM_MMU_AUDIT
entry.label: Audit KVM MMU
entry.help: This option adds a R/W kVM module parameter 'mmu_audit', which allows auditing of KVM MMU events at runtime.

entry.name: KVM_DEVICE_ASSIGNMENT
entry.label: KVM legacy PCI device assignment support (DEPRECATED)
entry.help:
Provide support for legacy PCI device assignment through KVM. The kernel now also supports a full featured userspace device driver framework through VFIO, which supersedes this support and provides better security.
If unsure, say N.

entry.name: VHOST_NET
entry.label: Host kernel accelerator for virtio net
entry.help:
This kernel module can be loaded in host kernel to accelerate guest networking with virtio_net. Not to be confused with virtio_net module itself which needs to be loaded in guest kernel.
To compile this driver as a module, choose M here: the module will be called vhost_net.

entry.name: VHOST_SCSI
entry.label: VHOST_SCSI TCM fabric driver
entry.help: Say M here to enable the vhost_scsi TCM fabric module for use with virtio-scsi guests

entry.name: VHOST_VSOCK
entry.label: vhost virtio-vsock driver
entry.help:
This kernel module can be loaded in the host kernel to provide AF_VSOCK sockets for communicating with guests. The guests must have the virtio_transport.ko driver loaded to use the virtio-vsock device.
To compile this driver as a module, choose M here: the module will be called vhost_vsock.

entry.name: VHOST
entry.help: This option is selected by any driver which needs to access the core of vhost.

entry.name: VHOST_CROSS_ENDIAN_LEGACY
entry.label: Cross-endian support for vhost
entry.help:
This option allows vhost to support guests with a different byte ordering from host while using legacy virtio.
Userspace programs can control the feature using the VHOST_SET_VRING_ENDIAN and VHOST_GET_VRING_ENDIAN ioctls.
This is only useful on a few platforms (ppc64 and arm64). Since it adds some overhead, it is disabled by default.
If unsure, say "N".

entry.name: LGUEST
entry.label: Linux hypervisor example code
entry.help:
This is a very simple module which allows you to run multiple instances of the same Linux kernel, using the "lguest" command found in the tools/lguest directory.
Note that "lguest" is pronounced to rhyme with "fell quest", not "rustyvisor". See tools/lguest/lguest.txt.
If unsure, say N. If curious, say M. If masochistic, say Y.

entry.name: HAVE_ARCH_BITREVERSE
entry.help: This option enables the use of hardware bit-reversal instructions on architectures which support such operations.

entry.name: CRC_CCITT
entry.label: CRC-CCITT functions
entry.help: This option is provided for the case where no in-kernel-tree modules require CRC-CCITT functions, but a module built outside the kernel tree does. Such modules that use library CRC-CCITT functions require M here.

entry.name: CRC16
entry.label: CRC16 functions
entry.help: This option is provided for the case where no in-kernel-tree modules require CRC16 functions, but a module built outside the kernel tree does. Such modules that use library CRC16 functions require M here.

entry.name: CRC_T10DIF
entry.label: CRC calculation for the T10 Data Integrity Field
entry.help: This option is only needed if a module that's not in the kernel tree needs to calculate CRC checks for use with the SCSI data integrity subsystem.

entry.name: CRC_ITU_T
entry.label: CRC ITU-T V.41 functions
entry.help: This option is provided for the case where no in-kernel-tree modules require CRC ITU-T V.41 functions, but a module built outside the kernel tree does. Such modules that use library CRC ITU-T V.41 functions require M here.

entry.name: CRC32
entry.label: CRC32/CRC32c functions
entry.help: This option is provided for the case where no in-kernel-tree modules require CRC32/CRC32c functions, but a module built outside the kernel tree does. Such modules that use library CRC32/CRC32c functions require M here.

entry.name: CRC32_SELFTEST
entry.label: CRC32 perform self test on init
entry.help: This option enables the CRC32 library functions to perform a self test on initialization. The self test computes crc32_le and crc32_be over byte strings with random alignment and length and computes the total elapsed time and number of bytes processed.

entry.name: CRC32_SLICEBY8
entry.label: Slice by 8 bytes
entry.help:
Calculate checksum 8 bytes at a time with a clever slicing algorithm. This is the fastest algorithm, but comes with a 8KiB lookup table. Most modern processors have enough cache to hold this table without thrashing the cache.
This is the default implementation choice. Choose this one unless you have a good reason not to.

entry.name: CRC32_SLICEBY4
entry.label: Slice by 4 bytes
entry.help:
Calculate checksum 4 bytes at a time with a clever slicing algorithm. This is a bit slower than slice by 8, but has a smaller 4KiB lookup table.
Only choose this option if you know what you are doing.

entry.name: CRC32_SARWATE
entry.label: Sarwate's Algorithm (one byte at a time)
entry.help:
Calculate checksum a byte at a time using Sarwate's algorithm. This is not particularly fast, but has a small 256 byte lookup table.
Only choose this option if you know what you are doing.

entry.name: CRC32_BIT
entry.label: Classic Algorithm (one bit at a time)
entry.help:
Calculate checksum one bit at a time. This is VERY slow, but has no lookup table. This is provided as a debugging option.
Only choose this option if you are debugging crc32.

entry.name: CRC7
entry.label: CRC7 functions
entry.help: This option is provided for the case where no in-kernel-tree modules require CRC7 functions, but a module built outside the kernel tree does. Such modules that use library CRC7 functions require M here.

entry.name: LIBCRC32C
entry.label: CRC32c (Castagnoli, et al) Cyclic Redundancy-Check
entry.help: This option is provided for the case where no in-kernel-tree modules require CRC32c functions, but a module built outside the kernel tree does. Such modules that use library CRC32c functions require M here. See Castagnoli93. Module will be libcrc32c.

entry.name: CRC8
entry.label: CRC8 function
entry.help: This option provides CRC8 function. Drivers may select this when they need to do cyclic redundancy check according CRC8 algorithm. Module will be called crc8.

entry.name: RANDOM32_SELFTEST
entry.label: PRNG perform self test on init
entry.help: This option enables the 32 bit PRNG library functions to perform a self test on initialization.

entry.name: XZ_DEC
entry.label: XZ decompression support
entry.help: LZMA2 compression algorithm and BCJ filters are supported using the .xz file format as the container. For integrity checking, CRC32 is supported. See Documentation/xz.txt for more information.

entry.name: XZ_DEC_X86
entry.label: x86 BCJ filter decoder" if EXPERT

entry.name: XZ_DEC_POWERPC
entry.label: PowerPC BCJ filter decoder" if EXPERT

entry.name: XZ_DEC_IA64
entry.label: IA-64 BCJ filter decoder" if EXPERT

entry.name: XZ_DEC_ARM
entry.label: ARM BCJ filter decoder" if EXPERT

entry.name: XZ_DEC_ARMTHUMB
entry.label: ARM-Thumb BCJ filter decoder" if EXPERT

entry.name: XZ_DEC_SPARC
entry.label: SPARC BCJ filter decoder" if EXPERT

entry.name: XZ_DEC_TEST
entry.label: XZ decompressor tester
entry.help:
This allows passing .xz files to the in-kernel XZ decoder via a character special file. It calculates CRC32 of the decompressed data and writes diagnostics to the system log.
Unless you are developing the XZ decoder, you don't need this and should say N.

entry.name: BCH_CONST_PARAMS
entry.help: Drivers may select this option to force specific constant values for parameters 'm' (Galois field order) and 't' (error correction capability). Those specific values must be set by declaring default values for symbols BCH_CONST_M and BCH_CONST_T. Doing so will enable extra compiler optimizations, improving encoding and decoding performance up to 2x for usual (m,t) values (typically such that m*t < 200). When this option is selected, the BCH library supports only a single (m,t) configuration. This is mainly useful for NAND flash board drivers requiring known, fixed BCH parameters.

entry.name: BCH_CONST_M
entry.help: Constant value for Galois field order 'm'. If 'k' is the number of data bits to protect, 'm' should be chosen such that (k + m*t) <= 2**m - 1. Drivers should declare a default value for this symbol if they select option BCH_CONST_PARAMS.

entry.name: BCH_CONST_T
entry.help: Constant value for error correction capability in bits 't'. Drivers should declare a default value for this symbol if they select option BCH_CONST_PARAMS.

entry.name: INTERVAL_TREE
entry.help:
Simple, embeddable, interval-tree. Can find the start of an overlapping range in log(n) time and then iterate over all overlapping nodes. The algorithm is implemented as an augmented rbtree.
See:
Documentation/rbtree.txt
for more information.

entry.name: ASSOCIATIVE_ARRAY
entry.help:
Generic associative array. Can be searched and iterated over whilst it is being modified. It is also reasonably quick to search and modify. The algorithms are non-recursive, and the trees are highly capacious.
See:
Documentation/assoc_array.txt
for more information.

entry.name: CPUMASK_OFFSTACK
entry.label: Force CPU masks off stack" if DEBUG_PER_CPU_MAPS
entry.help: Use dynamic allocation for cpumask_var_t, instead of putting them on the stack. This is a bit more expensive, but avoids stack overflow.

entry.name: GLOB
entry.help:
This option provides a glob_match function for performing simple text pattern matching. It originated in the ATA code to blacklist particular drive models, but other device drivers may need similar functionality.
All drivers in the Linux kernel tree that require this function should automatically select this option. Say N unless you are compiling an out-of tree driver which tells you that it depends on this.

entry.name: GLOB_SELFTEST
entry.label: glob self-test on init
entry.help:
This option enables a simple self-test of the glob_match function on startup. It is primarily useful for people working on the code to ensure they haven't introduced any regressions.
It only adds a little bit of code and slows kernel boot (or module load) by a small amount, so you're welcome to play with it, but you probably don't need it.

entry.name: CORDIC
entry.label: CORDIC algorithm
entry.help: This option provides an implementation of the CORDIC algorithm; calculations are in fixed point. Module will be called cordic.

entry.name: DDR
entry.label: JEDEC DDR data
entry.help: Data from JEDEC specs for DDR SDRAM memories, particularly the AC timing parameters and addressing information. This data is useful for drivers handling DDR SDRAM controllers.

entry.name: IRQ_POLL
entry.label: IRQ polling library
entry.help: Helper library to poll interrupt mitigation using polling.

entry.name: MPILIB
entry.help: Multiprecision maths library from GnuPG. It is used to implement RSA digital signature verification, which is used by IMA/EVM digital signature extension.

entry.name: SIGNATURE
entry.help: Digital signature verification. Currently only RSA is supported. Implementation is done using GnuPG MPI library

entry.name: OID_REGISTRY
entry.help: Enable fast lookup object identifier registry.

entry.name: FONTS
entry.label: Select compiled-in fonts
entry.help:
Say Y here if you would like to use fonts other than the default your frame buffer console usually use.
Note that the answer to this question won't directly affect the kernel: saying N will just cause the configurator to skip all the questions about foreign fonts.
If unsure, say N (the default choices are safe).

entry.name: FONT_8x8
entry.label: VGA 8x8 font" if FONTS
entry.help:
This is the "high resolution" font for the VGA frame buffer (the one provided by the text console 80x50 (and higher) modes).
Note that this is a poor quality font. The VGA 8x16 font is quite a lot more readable.
Given the resolution provided by the frame buffer device, answer N here is safe.

entry.name: FONT_8x16
entry.label: VGA 8x16 font" if FONTS
entry.help:
This is the "high resolution" font for the VGA frame buffer (the one provided by the VGA text console 80x25 mode.
If unsure, say Y.

entry.name: FONT_6x11
entry.label: Mac console 6x11 font (not supported by all drivers)" if FONTS
entry.help: Small console font with Macintosh-style high-half glyphs. Some Mac framebuffer drivers don't support this one at all.

entry.name: FONT_7x14
entry.label: console 7x14 font (not supported by all drivers)" if FONTS
entry.help: Console font with characters just a bit smaller than the default. If the standard 8x16 font is a little too big for you, say Y. Otherwise, say N.

entry.name: FONT_PEARL_8x8
entry.label: Pearl (old m68k) console 8x8 font" if FONTS
entry.help: Small console font with PC-style control-character and high-half glyphs.

entry.name: FONT_ACORN_8x8
entry.label: Acorn console 8x8 font" if FONTS
entry.help: Small console font with PC-style control characters and high-half glyphs.

entry.name: FONT_6x10
entry.label: Medium-size 6x10 font
entry.help: Medium-size console font. Suitable for framebuffer consoles on embedded devices with a 320x240 screen, to get a reasonable number of characters (53x24) that are still at a readable size.

entry.name: FONT_SUN8x16
entry.label: Sparc console 8x16 font
entry.help: This is the high resolution console font for Sun machines. Say Y.

entry.name: FONT_SUN12x22
entry.label: Sparc console 12x22 font (not supported by all drivers)
entry.help: This is the high resolution console font for Sun machines with very big letters (like the letters used in the SPARC PROM). If the standard font is unreadable for you, say Y, otherwise say N.

entry.name: FONT_10x18
entry.label: console 10x18 font (not supported by all drivers)" if FONTS
entry.help: This is a high resolution console font for machines with very big letters. It fits between the sun 12x22 and the normal 8x16 font. If other fonts are too big or too small for you, say Y, otherwise say N.

entry.name: SG_SPLIT
entry.help: Provides a helper to split scatterlists into chunks, each chunk being a scatterlist. This should be selected by a driver or an API which whishes to split a scatterlist amongst multiple DMA channels.

entry.name: SG_POOL
entry.help: Provides a helper to allocate chained scatterlists. This should be selected by a driver or an API which whishes to allocate chained scatterlist.
